    <item>
      <title>How the first world war liberated women's wardrobes</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/may/13/how-the-first-world-war-liberated-womens-wardrobes</link>
      <description><p>The Fashion and Freedom exhibition looks at the way clothes restricted women before the war – and shows how lines and silhouettes relaxed during the conflict as women entered the workplace</p><p>There were many upsides to Britain’s victory in the first world war – most notably peace, albeit of a temporary sort, in Europe. Less often noted is how the war liberated women from their corsets and full skirts when they were drafted in to run the country while the men were dying in muddy ditches across northern France. After finding that you can’t conduct a bus or forge steel in a floor-length silk day dress very well with a full bustle, these emancipating women started to experiment with far more practical clothes and hairstyles as they carried out their new roles in society.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/may/13/how-the-first-world-war-liberated-womens-wardrobes">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/fashion">Fashion</category>
      <pubDate>Fri, 13 May 2016 06:30:07 GMT</pubDate>

    <item>
      <title>Is the new non-sweat cycle shirt for commuters worth it?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/may/12/is-the-new-non-sweat-cycle-shirt-for-commuters-worth-it</link>
      <description><p>A shirt that promises to stop you sweating – or stinking – has gone on sale for £139. We asked an editor to try it out for size</p><p>Many offices now have shower facilities for cyclists, and those that don’t at least have toilet cubicles for commuters to change out of their kit. But if you’ve not got the time, or can’t be bothered carrying a spare set of clothes, or use your bike to get between meetings during the day, then a shirt that stops you sweating – and stinking out the joint – could be a thing of joy and wonder. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/may/12/is-the-new-non-sweat-cycle-shirt-for-commuters-worth-it">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>From Anna Kendrick this year to Angelina Jolie in 2007, why the Croisette is all yellow<br></p><p>There’s something quite route one about choosing a yellow dress for Cannes, the most sunshine-y of red carpets.     <item>
      <title>Raptor applause: the new red-carpet pose</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/may/12/raptor-applause-the-new-red-carpet-pose</link>
      <description><p>The teapot pose is 10 years old. Even if you don’t know what that means, you’ve seen it. High time we had a new pose? Then meet the raptor arm</p><p>The teapot arm is 10 years old, more or less. That’s ten years of turning one arm into a handle and one into a spout, and 10 years of looking great not stout. Its maturation is impossible to trace given it has been used as both an exercise in arm-thinning and something for ex-smokers to do with their hands, but according to Jezebel (which specialises in red-carpet kinesics) at the Oscars in 2006 around 60% of the actors were doing it, so here we are.<br tabindex="-1"></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/may/12/raptor-applause-the-new-red-carpet-pose">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>M&S addresses critics with ‘see now, buy now’ autumn collection</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/may/11/ms-see-now-buy-now-autumn-collection</link>
      <description><p>Retailer joins move towards immediacy with clothes that aim for an overarching contemporary feel in order to chime with next season’s collection</p><p>A surprise new look from a household name has dropped on to the internet. Beyoncé with another visual album? Justin Bieber with dreadlocks? No. The latest figure to exercise the very 2016 power of the online surprise is Marks &amp; Spencer.</p><p>The headline news at the M&amp;S autumn fashion showcase is that the alluring white off-the-shoulder sweater with side-tie detailing (£35), the soft caramel leather wide-cropped trousers (£199) and many others in the collection can be bought online, and in 26 stores, simultaneously with Wednesday’s unveiling to the press. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/may/11/ms-see-now-buy-now-autumn-collection">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Crotch of the matter: to bulge or not to bulge?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/may/11/crotch-of-the-matter-to-bulge-or-not-to-bulge</link>
      <description><p>As Ryan Gosling hides his modesty on a US talk show, what are the rules about going full-on peacock?</p><p>Shuffling on stage like a geisha in a kimono three sizes too small, Ryan Gosling appeared on the Jimmy Kimmel show this week in a houndstooth suit and a white shirt. “I have to admit something,” he told the presenter, “I didn’t try this suit on before I came out and I realised that it’s so tight.” As the studio audience bellowed with bawdy approval, Gosling squawked: “I can’t feel my calves.” As for his crotch area, the actor played wallflower at a prom: primly crossing his legs, he kept his hands over the offending area and looked extremely awkward. The actor was the embodiment of the modern male conundrum: to bulge or not to bulge?</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/may/11/crotch-of-the-matter-to-bulge-or-not-to-bulge">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Pop-culture style tips for men – from Drake’s shearling to Peaky Blinders caps</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/may/10/pop-culture-style-men-drakes-shearling-peaky-blinders-caps-catwalk-summer-2016</link>
      <description>Trade the catwalk show for the box set, and your look for summer 2016 will say ‘culturally informed’ as much as ‘style buff’ <br /><p>OK, so some spoilsports are saying that the Stan Smith is now <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/dec/22/2015-stan-smith-went-mass-adidas-sneakers-trainer" title="">too popular</a> to really have any fashion credibility this year. But take heart and look to the other bits of Adidas’s back catalogue. <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/24/1980s-films-nostalgia-history-richard-linklater-everybody-wants-some" title=""><strong>Everybody Wants Some!!</strong></a><strong> <u>(1)</u></strong> , out on Friday, is set in 1980, with a bunch of baseball players as the main cast, so it’s got the lot. From Sambas to Superstars, all are welcome. Add a pair of chunky white socks with stripes and short-shorts for the full look. Note: avoid the handlebar moustache for fear of resembling an American Apparel ad from 2008.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/may/10/pop-culture-style-men-drakes-shearling-peaky-blinders-caps-catwalk-summer-2016">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Stylewatch: Hole in 1995</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/may/10/stylewatch-hole-in-1995</link>
      <description><p>It’s rumoured that Courtney Love’s band might reform – making this the perfect time to revive their influential 90s look </p><p>Courtney Love has always been a woman with the appeal of Marmite. The love/hate thing dates back to the 90s – and has links to a style of dress that came to be known as “<a draggable="true" href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/mar/11/90s-are-back-how-to-get-the-look">Kinderwhore</a>”. Think slip dresses, ripped tights, peroxide hair and lipstick applied with the dexterity of a six-year-old. </p><p>Love was courting controversy from the start with the thrift-store mixture of childlike shapes, cute hairgrips and the rips and tears of punk, and she was also challenging the slick glamour of 80s femininity. The look was worn by women in the grunge scene – including <a draggable="true" href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/feb/03/cult-heroes-babes-in-toylands-kat-bjelland-overlooked-90s-punk-powerhouse">Kat Bjelland of Babes in Toyland</a>, who supposedly coined the term – they were grown-ups dressed as dolls left out in the garden over night: pretty but grubby. The look went viral when it was faithfully replicated by Hole’s fans, who had been watching the <a draggable="true" href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mS1Ckczz0LQ">Miss World</a> video on repeat. Those haters inevitably hated.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/may/10/stylewatch-hole-in-1995">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Survey finds that 78% of models in fashion adverts are white</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/may/10/survey-finds-that-78-of-models-in-fashion-adverts-are-white</link>
      <description><p>Report found that of all models featured in spring’s editorial campaigns, only 22% were black, Asian or Hispanic</p><p>According to a new report, 78.2% of all the models featured in spring 2016’s fashion adverts were white. In a breakdown of the statistics, 8.3% of models featured in ads were black, 4% were Asian and 3.8% were Hispanic. </p><p>Although low, the percentage of non-white models has actually increased from 2015 when the total was 84.7%. The results, complied by <a href="http://www.thefashionspot.com/runway-news/690669-diversity-report-spring-2016-fashion-ads/">The Fashion Spot</a>, come from a survey of 236 fashion print campaigns and 422 models. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/may/10/survey-finds-that-78-of-models-in-fashion-adverts-are-white">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>The Baftas 2016: how the dandy dominated</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/may/09/the-baftas-2016-how-the-dandy-dominated</link>
      <description><p>From big statement jewellery to velvet bow ties, the awards ceremony got subtly more experimental with its fashion</p><p>The TV Baftas is the only awards ceremony where the atmosphere pivots between “icy family Christmas meal” and “alarming geopolitical moment”. This tense, comic dynamic is a result of divergent celebrity microcultures being forced to rub shoulders with each other. It’s where Mark Rylance was probably forced to utter the sentence: “So, erm, what have you got coming up next?” to Towie’s Mark Wright, as they stared awkwardly at the floor in the queue for the urinals. Which, obviously, also makes for interesting trends on the red carpet.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/may/09/the-baftas-2016-how-the-dandy-dominated">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/fashion-blog/2016/may/09/why-the-pop-merchandise-store-is-the-most-fashionable-place-to-shop</link>
      <description><p>From Beyoncé to Vetements, the intersection between fashion and pop-star merch has never been closer</p><p>As anyone who has listened to<a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/apr/29/beyonce-lemonade-jay-z-explainer "> Lemonade </a>knows, it’s best not to mess with Beyoncé Knowles. First, it was Jay Z under fire on the “visual album”; now, Knowles has taken the Miami police force to task after they said <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/feb/19/miami-police-union-calls-for-boycott-of-beyonce-show-javier-ortiz">they would boycott her concerts</a>. In a class A power play, T-shirts sold on the merch stand of her Formation tour read: “Boycott Beyoncé”. Just like that, Beyoncé once again comes <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ob7vObnFUJc">out on top</a>. </p><p lang="en" dir="ltr">Beyoncé is selling BOYCOTT BEYONCÉ t-shirts as tour merch  <a href="https://t.co/zjD3HcV7XG">pic.twitter.com/zjD3HcV7XG</a></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/fashion-blog/2016/may/09/why-the-pop-merchandise-store-is-the-most-fashionable-place-to-shop">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Seven summer style hacks for 2016</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/may/08/winter-wardrobe-style-hack-summer-fashion-good-weather</link>
      <description><p>Was anyone ready for May’s weather ambush – with sandals bought, triceps curled, outfits ordered? No? Don’t panic. What’s needed are speedy wardrobe solutions. Here’s how to do it</p><p>Or better still, get out the one you bought last summer and have not worn. Because these tops still have cachet. We’ve got over calling them <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/may/27/how-to-wear-the-bardot-the-summers-most-unexpectedly-flattering-trend">Bardot tops</a> now (bit of a stretch, wasn’t it?), but their usefulness has given them longevity. Bare shoulders say summer and don’t make grownups panic about their upper arms. Ditto the so-called cold-shoulder tops that are also everywhere. If naked shoulders feels too louche for an air-conditioned office, note that slinging a cashmere sweater over your shoulders like <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/mar/24/jeremy-irons-have-natural-tendency-benign-dictator-batman-v-superman">Jeremy Irons</a> is totally acceptable.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/may/08/winter-wardrobe-style-hack-summer-fashion-good-weather">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Beauty: the best lightweight facial sunblocks | Sali Hughes</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/may/07/best-lightweight-facial-sunblock-beauty-sali-hughes</link>
      <description><p>These days, we’re spoiled for choice </p><p>I can almost chart the arrival of spring by the dramatically increasing number of tweets, letters and emails asking for sunblock recommendations. Almost without exception, men and women say they want something that feels weightless and non-greasy, and that won’t slide off the face as soon as humidity strikes. My own requirements are much the same, though I’d want something broad spectrum (ie, protecting against both UVA and UVB; the law demands only the latter) that doesn’t peel off in tiny balls as soon as I try to blend makeup over the top (so wearying).</p><p>While I’m heartened that readers want to protect&nbsp;their faces in the sun, until a year or two ago I could rarely deliver on their ideal texture. Nowadays, though, I’m spoiled for choice, and the quality of formulations is increasing year on year. Ticking every box is the wonderful <a href="http://www.johnlewis.com/murad-luminous-shield-spf-50-pa-30ml/p2507151" title=""><strong>Murad Luminous Shield SPF50</strong></a> (£55). I should warn you that this particular product comes from the White Brilliance range, which hints heavily at that glaring and almost universally unflattering lavender-white&nbsp;imparted by many sunblocks, so rendering it&nbsp;entirely unsuitable for non-white skins, but I&nbsp;promise that here the name is misleading (I was so alarmed that I forced a dark-skinned friend to wear it for a day and she looked great).</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/may/07/best-lightweight-facial-sunblock-beauty-sali-hughes">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>What I wore this week: athleisure | Jess Cartner-Morley</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/may/06/athleisure-polo-shirt-skirt-jess-cartner-morley</link>
      <description><p>The polo shirt is the athleisure update on the T-shirt, in the same way that the sweatshirt is the new crewneck </p><p>Shall we have an athleisure recap? Right, so here’s an omnibus edition of what you may have missed. I&nbsp;won’t bore you with the fastest-growing-retail-sector stuff. What you&nbsp;need to know is that (a) the sweatshirt is the new crewneck; (b)&nbsp;tracksuit bottoms are now several rungs higher on the fashion pecking order than jeans; and (c), Olympics or no Olympics, it’s a safe bet that whoever is declared overall winner of 2016 will be wearing a tracksuit, probably the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/mar/25/take-the-money-and-run-the-rise-of-the-1000-tracksuit">sold-out deconstructed one by Parisian label Vetements</a>.</p><p>Where do polo shirts fit into this? The polo shirt is the athleisure update on the T-shirt, in the same way that the sweatshirt is the new crewneck. The tone of fashion is shifting from that architectural-minimalist, “I probably work in an art gallery” look to something both sportier and a bit more brassy. Looks that would have been a bit naff – a&nbsp;bit Westfield, if you know what I&nbsp;mean – are now deeply fashionable. Tracksuits, say. And polo shirts.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/may/06/athleisure-polo-shirt-skirt-jess-cartner-morley">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Socks and sandals: a fashion faux pas reinvented for summer</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/may/06/socks-and-sandals-a-fashion-faux-pas-reinvented-for-summer</link>
      <description><p>Forget the idea of pensioners on the beach. From Versace to Calvin Klein, this staple of normcore dad dressing has had a makeover</p><p>Summer’s here and ... you’re not ready, are you? Between finding out that your sunglasses are broken, your wide-brimmed hat has been hijacked by James Bay and the bassist featured on your favourite band T-shirt has been implicated in an off-shore expenses scandal, it’s a minefield of sartorial indecision. The biggest question for men though has to be: what is the right piece of footwear to sport during the hot weather? The answer is pretty unexpected: it is sandals paired with socks. The combination has been reinvented so any associations with “pensioners on a beach” don’t apply any more. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/may/06/socks-and-sandals-a-fashion-faux-pas-reinvented-for-summer">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Levi Roots: ‘I haven’t cut my hair for 25 years’</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/may/07/levi-roots-personal-style-how-i-get-ready</link>
      <description><p>The musician and food entrepreneur on what influences his personal style</p><p>It’s a good thing I live alone, because I hog the mirror and take a lot of time to get ready. I have a shower, then put olive oil on my face. As a black man in this country, I have to cream my face, especially in winter, when my skin gets very dry and cracks. In&nbsp;summer, when you sweat more, black skin is more supple, but in winter we need oil. I like to think of myself as a Rastafarian, so my locks are about my inward belief and my path in life, not a fashion thing. I&nbsp;haven’t cut my hair for 25 years, but I wash it every two days and put in a bit of coconut oil.</p><p>As a businessman, I’ve become known for wearing suits, and I’m a sucker for <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/ozwald-boateng">Ozwald Boateng</a>, the king of Savile Row. I have big feet – size 12 – so I tend to have my shoes made at <a href="http://www.johnlobb.com/uk/?utm_source=google_UK&amp;utm_medium=ppc_UK&amp;utm_campaign=john-lobb_UK&amp;gclid=CKiR_Izqn8wCFagy0wodpFQAPg">Lobb</a>, the shop where Prince Charles goes. I buy black lace-ups – you can’t go into a business meeting in brown shoes, no matter what suit you have on. When I am on stage <a href="http://www.leviroots.com/music/">playing the guitar</a>, I don’t wear a suit, I am a stereotypical Rastaman. No one ever saw Bob Marley in a suit.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/may/07/levi-roots-personal-style-how-i-get-ready">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Game of Thrones and the return of the man-bun</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/may/05/game-of-thrones-and-the-return-of-the-man-bun</link>
      <description><p>Jon Snow and Gareth Bale have resurrected this style, but can we stomach it a second time round?</p><p>The news that the beloved Game Of Thrones character Jon Snow is returning to the show with a <a href="http://i.dailymail.co.uk/i/pix/2015/09/25/19/2CC3B40100000578-0-image-a-1_1443204342773.jpg">man-bun</a> is disturbing on a number of levels, chiefly because the phrase “the second wave of the man-bun” has slid across our minds like a mental image we can’t unsee. Thanks Snow, Brooklyn Beckham and Gareth Bale. Thanks a lot. </p><p>In the lexicon of male hairstyles, the man-bun sits like Jeremy Hunt at an NHS AGM. More disliked than the cheeky mullet or the culturally insensitive white dreadlock, it’s associated with that modern urban pariah, the east London hipster. It’s more than a hairstyle; it is a signifier of a certain well-heeled individual who exists in a twilight period between yoga-retreat sabbatical and “working at my dad’s bank”. With Snow getting one, this previously niche form of hair hara-kiri threatens to get even more mass (Game Of Thrones has a massive fan base and viewing figures of 2 million), and that is nothing but a cause for concern. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/may/05/game-of-thrones-and-the-return-of-the-man-bun">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Say my name: the return of the statement necklace</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/may/05/say-my-name-the-return-of-the-statement-necklace</link>
      <description><p>How name necklaces went from SATC hasbeen to become the selfie detail du jour</p><p>Remember <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/fashion-blog/2014/jul/23/the-top-30-brands-mentioned-in-sex-and-the-city">SATC</a> fever at its height, when everyone wanted to be a bit like Carrie Bradshaw – the Big dramz, Jimmy Choo shoe collection and black MacBook? Key to getting the look was the name necklace: “Carrie” spelt out in wavy, 70s-style lettering. Everywhere in the late 90s, their fashionability rose and fell with Carrie’s star. Once SATC left our screens in 2004 for a path of dodgy feature films, the name necklace disappeared too.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/may/05/say-my-name-the-return-of-the-statement-necklace">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Give the gladiator sandals another summer | Letters</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/may/10/give-the-gladiator-sandals-another-summer</link>
      <description>Female fertility | DNA database | Prison reform | Disposable fashion | Last English king<p>I was surprised to be informed (<a href="http://www.theguardian.com/society/2016/may/10/foul-reign-of-the-biological-clock" title="">The foul reign of the biological clock</a>, 10 May) that 1.5 is “the number of children the average American woman had in 1976”. At a rough estimate this means 120 million children were born in 1976. There’s an old joke about an American asking “Do you have children?”, and a British person answering “Not if I can help it.” But it’s not apparently a distinction that your editors are aware of.<br><strong>Vivian Cook</strong><br><em>Colchester</em></p><p>• The case for a universal national DNA database has once again been made by the case of Melanie Road, killed over 30 years ago, but whose murder has only recently been solved following the fluke sampling of the killer’s daughter’s DNA after she was arrested for criminal damage (<a href="http://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2016/may/09/bristol-man-pleads-guilty-to-1984-of-melanie-road" title="">Report</a>, 10 May). Of course a compulsory DNA database invades individual privacy but, provided there are adequate safeguards, I believe it is a price well worth paying to remedy the gross inadequacies in the justice system.<br><strong>Benedict Birnberg</strong><br><em>London</em></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/may/10/give-the-gladiator-sandals-another-summer">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/fashion">Fashion</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/uk/ukcrime">Crime</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/politics/dna-database">DNA database</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/society/prisons-and-probation">Prisons and probation</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/politics/politics">Politics</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/law/criminal-justice">UK criminal justice</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/uk/uk">UK news</category>

    <item>
      <title>What do Britain’s best suitmakers think about Robert Peston’s tie-free chat show?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/shortcuts/2016/may/09/robert-peston-allegra-stratton-fashion</link>
      <description>ITV’s new Sunday morning politics show has been ruffling collars by erring on the casual side of smart-casual. Is this the end of the necktie as we know it?<p>Robert Peston’s <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/may/08/robert-peston-goes-for-the-jugular-with-george-osborne-in-new-sunday-show" title="">new talk show</a> opened with him muttering “break a leg!” to co-host Allegra Stratton, which was either unintentional or a radical teardown of the fourth wall on Sunday-morning ITV. The casual vibe continued as Peston appeared in an open-necked shirt, and admitted to being “bleeding nervous”. This was not the Andrew Marr show, where an hour earlier, Marr in a tie had interviewed Michael Gove in a tie and Prince Harry in, erm, a polo shirt.</p><p>This is about British sartorial standards (and, as usual, Peston’s hair). Peston, who has long been described as “dishevelled”, looked wilfully smart-casual to the extent that his first guest, George Osborne, had also jettisoned the tie. And they’re not the only men in positions of power prone to flashing a bit of neck. Evan Davis, Barack Obama, BBC chief Tim Davie, Google’s European boss, Matt Brittin, and obviously Jeremy Corbyn are all at it, too.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/shortcuts/2016/may/09/robert-peston-allegra-stratton-fashion">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/mens-fashion">Men's fashion</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/fashion">Fashion</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/lifeandstyle">Life and style</category>
      <pubDate>Mon, 09 May 2016 14:53:23 GMT</pubDate>
      <guid>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/shortcuts/2016/may/09/robert-peston-allegra-stratton-fashion</guid>
      <media:content width="140" url="https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/1ddd4f1f6c6cb2c36e1980a389d1d9042458625f/23_170_3555_2133/3555.jpg?w=140&q=55&auto=format&usm=12&fit=max&s=6dbf6d50ae7b99a4670dc6a73a325fd3">
        <media:credit scheme="urn:ebu">Photograph: Ken McKay/ITV/Rex/Shutterstock</media:credit>
      </media:content>
      <media:content width="460" url="https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/1ddd4f1f6c6cb2c36e1980a389d1d9042458625f/23_170_3555_2133/3555.jpg?w=460&q=55&auto=format&usm=12&fit=max&s=8ccaccfc34f1fef1b07f571a6022d426">

    <item>
      <title>Dyson's Supersonic hairdryer – worth £299 or just a blast of hot air?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/shortcuts/2016/apr/27/dyson-supersonic-hairdryer-worth-299-test</link>
      <description><p>The humble blow dryer is the latest product to be Dyson’d. Is it as noisy as the cult brand’s other tools? Let’s put it to the test</p><p>Catherine the Great once described the wind as giving you either imagination or a headache. She hadn’t, of course, accounted for Dyson, which, for the past 20 years, has had the monopoly on harnessing blown air in its award-winning vacuum cleaners, hand-dryers and fans. These products have made Dyson, the man and the company, one of the UK’s greatest stories of innovation and profit. Last year, product sales were up almost 25%, a figure that should soon be bolstered by the next device to be Dyson’d: the hairdryer, and last bastion of air-based appliances.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/shortcuts/2016/apr/27/dyson-supersonic-hairdryer-worth-299-test">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/beauty">Beauty</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/fashion">Fashion</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/lifeandstyle">Life and style</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/technology">Technology</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/dyson-ltd">Dyson Ltd</category>
      <pubDate>Wed, 27 Apr 2016 04:30:03 GMT</pubDate>
      <guid>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/shortcuts/2016/apr/27/dyson-supersonic-hairdryer-worth-299-test</guid>
      <media:content width="140" url="https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/d0660022f1f5b17800bf42ccf3814c81dc11e132/0_98_4256_2554/4256.jpg?w=140&q=55&auto=format&usm=12&fit=max&s=5901130eaa63e423fac4307bb4fa83fd">

    <item>
      <title>Stylewatch: Wimbledon 2016 uniforms</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/may/05/stylewatch-wimbledon-2016-uniforms</link>
      <description><p>All the trends come to centre court in Ralph Lauren’s uniforms for ball boys and girls this year.</p><p>Question: what do you do when you have been responsible for <a draggable="true" href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/gallery/2014/jun/23/wimbledon-fashion-a-history-in-pictures">Wimbledon</a>’s uniforms for 11 years? Judging by <a draggable="true" href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/oct/02/its-not-about-fabric-its-about-dreams-how-ralph-lauren-created-an-empire">Ralph Lauren</a>’s latest designs, the answer is to bring a take on current trends to centre court. The tracksuit designs for ball boys are totally athleisure, and with the tracksuit a bit of a thing right now, we imagine said ball boys might be wearing this off court too. Other designs that bring a Serena-worthy serve of style include a ball girl skirt that could feature in the world of Beyonce’s <a draggable="true" href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/apr/01/beyonce-stamps-her-unmistakable-brand-on-sportswear-fashion">Ivy Park</a>, and the classic cable knit jumper. Worn oversized, and with matching white bootleg trousers, it’s quite Annie Hall, so totally allowed in 2016’s vintage-influenced fashion moment. And the umpire’s uniform of trench coat, hat and striped shirt? It wouldn’t be out of place in the wardrobe of <a draggable="true" href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/dec/07/scream-queens-alpha-fashion-at-its-most-evil">Scream Queens</a>’ Chad Radwell. That’s match-winning dressing right there. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/may/05/stylewatch-wimbledon-2016-uniforms">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>How cult label Palace went from UK skate kids to hip-hop royalty</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/may/03/cult-label-palace-uk-skate-kids-hip-hop-royalty-brand-rihanna-jay-z-teens-dads-leve-tanju</link>
      <description>The skatewear brand has won over Rihanna and Jay Z as well as teens and their dads. It’s all down to authenticity, explains founder Lev Tanju<p>You might not have heard of skate brand <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/apr/27/how-skatewear-grew-up">Palace</a>, but you will almost certainly have seen their logo. A triangle with Palace written along each side, it’s spotted on the backs of hoodies worn by suburban teenagers, on shirts worn by Jay Z, on boys staring at the big screen in pubs, on the dancefloor of gay clubs and, in 2014, on England shirts produced by Umbro. It has even, thanks to her dad’s tailor, been <a href="http://www.lamoda.co.uk/blog/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/north-west-palace-style-look-lamoda.jpg">worn by North West</a>, the indisputable trendsetter of the toddler world. Ring a bell now? Thought so.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/may/03/cult-label-palace-uk-skate-kids-hip-hop-royalty-brand-rihanna-jay-z-teens-dads-leve-tanju">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>From Hotline Bling to fashion king: bearded Drake ramps up regal charisma</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/apr/29/drake-views-album-hotline-bling-fashion-kate-middleton-beard-moncler-jacket</link>
      <description><p>The rapper became ‘the new Kate Middleton’ with his success beard and Moncler jacket. Now, in his latest album, Views, he’s looking like Henry VIII – or 007</p><p>When <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/drake">Drake</a> wears something, the world takes notice. The look he wore in last year’s <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uxpDa-c-4Mc">Hotline Bling video</a>: deconstructed Mountie meets normcore dad, was hugely influential. Not only did he give a second life to everyone’s sand-coloured walking boots (his were Nike ACG Manoa<em>)</em>, the knock-on effect on the <a href="https://www.google.co.uk/search?q=padded+moncler&amp;source=lnms&amp;tbm=isch&amp;sa=X&amp;ved=0ahUKEwjRvt-Yg7TMAhUMKywKHSg5CaMQ_AUICCgC&amp;biw=2560&amp;bih=1274">padded Moncler</a> was instant. The cherry red jacket (a snip at $1,150) sold out a day after the video premiered. For all his fashion influences, Vanity Fair called Drake “<a href="http://www.vanityfair.com/news/2015/10/drake-hotline-bling-moncler-jacket">the new Kate Middleton</a>”. Key to this look was his “success beard”: a sleek, streamlined vision of maturity that drove the internet crazy. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/apr/29/drake-views-album-hotline-bling-fashion-kate-middleton-beard-moncler-jacket">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Cutting edge: could crop tops for men return?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/may/04/cutting-edge-could-crop-tops-for-men-return</link>
      <description><p>It’s featured in new film Everybody Wants Some!! as a period piece, but could the ‘half shirt’ be the shape of things to come in menswear?</p><p>There’s a scene in <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/richard-linklater">Richard Linklater</a>’s new comedy, the 1980 set <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/mar/11/everybody-wants-some-review-richard-linklater">Everybody Wants Some!!</a> that stands out. Hot headed McReynolds (Tyler Hoechlin) is hitting baseballs with an axe in order to chop them in two. It’s one of the most alpha scenes in an alpha movie, but what’s interesting is that McReynolds is chopping dressed in a black, netted crop top. In 2016, the male crop top is creeping back into view – a sartorial metaphor for the industry’s increasing <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/apr/05/gucci-to-combine-mens-and-womens-shows">blurring of gender lines</a>.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/may/04/cutting-edge-could-crop-tops-for-men-return">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Gingham style: the fabric that owns spring</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/may/02/gingham-style-the-fabric-that-owns-spring</link>
      <description><p>We are having a love affair with the wholesome cotton cloth, but does it mean we are all turning into Taylor Swift?</p><p>We all know what wearing leopard print means. It means you are sexy and womanly and a <em>bit</em> daring but very much within socially acceptable boundaries. It means being rock’n’roll up to, but not beyond, the two-martinis-on-a-schoolnight watermark. You put on your leopard-print pencil skirt and you’re, like, mentally high-fiving Diane von Fürstenberg as you leave for the office.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/may/02/gingham-style-the-fabric-that-owns-spring">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Don’t wait for winter – buy your padded jacket now</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/apr/26/dont-wait-for-winter-padded-jacket-now-looks-for-autumn</link>
      <description>Holding on for next season is so last season, as proved by fashion’s current must-have. Plus: five other looks that will last you into autumn<br /><p>The trophy piece on the fashion insiders’ shopping hit lists right now isn’t what you think. Cold-shoulder tops? Been wearing them since February. Crochet bikini? Everyone’s over those post-Coachella. Satin bomber jacket? Old&nbsp;news, babes.</p><p>The piece that will have us running into stores when it arrives – at the end of May, in Topshop’s case, not that we’re counting the days or anything – is the padded jacket, the breakout star of the most recent Paris fashion week. The padded jacket used to be your coat-cupboard’s guilty secret, the piece you reached for when it was too cold to care about fashion. But that has all changed. Balenciaga’s red quilted jacket, worn <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/fashion-blog/2016/mar/30/shawling-how-to-wear-your-winter-coat-into-spring" title="">grandly off-the-shoulder in the manner of a mink coat at the opera</a>, is to next season what the Chloé tracksuit is to this one. The Stella McCartney padded coat, in metallic bronze and in luxe navy velvet, confirmed the quilted coat’s leap into high fashion.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/apr/26/dont-wait-for-winter-padded-jacket-now-looks-for-autumn">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Why the term 'African fashion' is reductive</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/apr/26/africa-mainstream-fashion-monlithic-fashion-cities-africa-hannah-azieb-pool-</link>
      <description><p>While western designers reduce ‘African fashion’ to tribal clichés, there’s a whole host of local designers producing material more reflective of this diverse continent </p><p>Whether in London or Lagos, Nairobi or New York, fashion is a pillar of identity: it’s a way to take risks and contextualise a sense of self and place. So why, then, does the mainstream fashion industry – be it the media, designers or international fashion houses – still reduce “African fashion” to a single, monolithic entity? </p><p> This season, it’s the likes of Valentino reaching for the “tribal” clichés (featuring mostly white models with the obligatory cornrows); Junya Watanabe’s bizarre attempt at Afrofuturism without any black models, and Isabel Marant and Alberta Ferretti’s Afro-boho collections. Others referencing Africa on the catwalk include Chloe, Louis Vuitton, Missoni and Issey Miyake. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/apr/26/africa-mainstream-fashion-monlithic-fashion-cities-africa-hannah-azieb-pool-">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/fashion">Fashion</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/world/africa">Africa</category>

    <item>
      <title>Prince: how his androgynous style influenced fashion</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/apr/22/prince-how-his-androgynous-style-influenced-fashion</link>
      <description><p>From his dancing curls to his high-stacked heels, the legend influenced Versace, Justin Bieber and Matthew Williamson</p><ul><li><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/apr/22/prince-sex-femininity-suzanne-moore">Suzanne Moore: Prince didn’t write about sex. He was sex</a></li></ul><p>In the late 70s and throughout the 80s, the yearly advent of a new Prince album brought with it a visual image as strong and defining as the music contained within. “I wear what I want because I don’t really like clothes,” he lied once, in a rare interview. Like David Bowie, Prince toyed with the ideas of the “other”: the feminine, the alien, the raceless. Through costume and artwork, he created the Prince that became iconic: the wistful <em>flâneur</em> with Egyptian-style eyeliner. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/apr/22/prince-how-his-androgynous-style-influenced-fashion">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>French dressing: First Dates’ Fred on looks for love</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/apr/23/french-dressing-first-dates-fred-mens-fashion</link>
      <description><p>What should a man wear on that crucial first date? Fred Sirieix, maître d’ of TV’s First Dates restaurant, models three options – and offers his dating tips</p><p>The most charming Frenchman in London is sipping peppermint tea and dishing out heavily accented lessons in the art of love. “If you don’t have self-love, how are you going to love someone else? It’s about confidence and being happy. Then someone will want to be happy with you,” <a href="http://theartofservice.co.uk/#about-fred-sirieix">Fred Sirieix</a> declares, sitting on a low armchair in the 1930s-style bar at <a href="http://www.galvinatwindows.com">Galvin at Windows</a> on Park Lane in London, where he has been maître d’ for 10 years.</p><p>What makes this fine-dining expert such an authority on love? For three years, he has been the host of <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/tvandradioblog/2014/oct/06/first-dates-channel-4-better-than-gogglebox">First Dates</a>, Channel 4’s dating show, filmed in a restaurant in which every diner is on a blind date. It has become a primetime hit and the format has now sold to production companies abroad. But it is Sirieix who largely steals the show, by twinkling his clear blue eyes straight down the lens and doling out aphorisms: “No man is an island”, “Everybody needs someone to cuddle with”. Today, he does not disappoint, quoting Sartre, Shakespeare and Philip Larkin, while explaining how the art of service and the art of love are inextricable.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/apr/23/french-dressing-first-dates-fred-mens-fashion">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Can you cut it: what your hairstyle says about you</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/apr/22/can-you-cut-it-what-your-hairstyle-says-about-you</link>
      <description><p>Once, it was all about the beard: this season it’s time to experiment with what’s on top. But should you go for a Johnny Depp or a Don Draper?</p><p>When did men’s hair get so adventurous? Look across a crowded bar and never mind the beards, it’s the hair that will grab your attention. Zigzag sides, bleached burns, auburn frosted tips: we are living in the age of the male superhairo (and I don’t mean <a href="https://media1.popsugar-assets.com/files/2016/04/04/636/n/1922398/3f12127c_edit_img_cover_file_15741499_1459778152_GettyImages-51PXzwJ4.xxxlarge.jpg">Justin Bieber’s dreadful dreadlocks</a>).</p><p><br>The trend emerged during the merry-go-round whirl of awards season. In among all the red carpet coverage, one thing was obvious: male hair was going through a post-man‑bun renaissance. There was <a href="http://www.billboard.com/files/media/oscars-pharrell-2016-billboard-1000.jpg">Pharrell’s golden bleached crop</a> at the Oscars, <a href="http://media.gettyimages.com/photos/73rd-annual-golden-globe-awards-pictured-actor-sam-heughan-arrives-to-picture-id504387518">a mullet-slicker do from Outlander’s Sam Heughan</a> at the Golden Globes, and rapper <a href="http://www.vogue.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/15/wiz-khalifa-grammys-2016.jpg">Wiz Khalifa’s dip-dyed hippy dreads</a> at the Grammys, every do as desirable as the next. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/apr/22/can-you-cut-it-what-your-hairstyle-says-about-you">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Scam or subversion? How a DHL T-shirt became this year’s must-have</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/apr/19/dhl-t-shirt-vetements-fashion-paris-catwalk</link>
      <description><p>Vetements’ DHL T-shirt, first dispatched on to the Paris catwalk, sold out in weeks, despite costing £185. But what message does this surprise package deliver?</p><p>On 1 October 2015, a man walked out on to the Vetements catwalk in Paris. He wore Dr Martens boots, shiny black trousers, an open black shirt and what was to become the It item of spring/summer 2016: a DHL T-shirt. The reaction fell into two camps: one, furiously snapping pictures to post on Instagram; the other, quizzical. Paris is traditionally the world of sequin gowns, champagne on trays and sets that cost millions, after all.</p><p>A T-shirt with such a prosaic logo really threw down the gauntlet. Vetements – a label known for wonky 90s-influenced streetwear, real-world models and oversized fits, designed by a collective headed by Demna Gvasalia – had arguably brought anti-fashion back to fashion.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/apr/19/dhl-t-shirt-vetements-fashion-paris-catwalk">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Miles Davis: from buttoned-down Ivy League to Issey Miyake flamboyance</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/apr/20/miles-davis-from-buttoned-down-ivy-league-to-issey-miyake-flamboyance</link>
      <description><p>New biopic Miles Ahead celebrates the life of one of the most influential musicians of the 20th century. But the jazz trumpeter was also a huge style icon, going from birth of cool preppy chic to Gucci-style glasses via a leather jacket that saved his life ...</p><p>Blue is the colour of the sky – and also of cool and melancholy understatement. So naturally, it’s synonymous with jazz, especially through 1959’s A Kind of Blue by Miles Davis, the bestselling jazz album of all time. </p><p>Yet it was green, and in particular a green button-down shirt, that announced Davis’s arrival as a style icon in postwar Britain. “He wore it on the cover of the Milestones album,” says John Simons, founder of Chiltern Street’s classic tailor <br>J Simons. “In terms of style, it was a very important image. He was beautifully dressed during this period – very neat and sharp.”</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/apr/20/miles-davis-from-buttoned-down-ivy-league-to-issey-miyake-flamboyance">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>I sniffed the end of the world, and it smells like bile and dread</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/shortcuts/2016/apr/17/thompson-craighead-bible-amageddon-apocalypse-carroll-fletcher-art</link>
      <description>Artists Thomson and Craighead have bottled a fragrance based on the Bible’s descriptions of armageddon – including animal horns, flesh burned with fire and a grievous sore<p>I have smelled the end of the world. And it smells like bile.</p><p>In the bright, white atrium of London’s <a href="http://www.carrollfletcher.com/">Carroll/Fletcher gallery</a>, I recently sniffed armageddon off the end of a cardboard strip. The perfume, called Apocalypse, is by art partners <a href="http://thomson-craighead.net/">Jon Thomson and Alison Craighead</a> and forms part of their new show, <a href="http://www.carrollfletcher.com/exhibitions/52/overview/">Party Booby Trap</a>, which opened this week.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/shortcuts/2016/apr/17/thompson-craighead-bible-amageddon-apocalypse-carroll-fletcher-art">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Can Marks & Spencer do an Alexa Chung with its menswear?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/apr/19/marks-spencer-menswear-kestin-hare-alexa-chung</link>
      <description><p>Teaming up with new British designer Kestin Hare suggests the national treasure is taking on younger competition </p><p>Marks &amp; Spencer is a national treasure. But as all national treasures, from Andy Murray to Adele, know, being cool has no place in one’s armoury of talents. Its new menswear collection, a collaboration with the young Scot Kestin Hare, however, tells a different story. It brushes against the coat-tails of hip and urban, and suggests a high-street brand that is gutsy enough to try and compete with the likes of Topman and Asos. Is that a wise move?<br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/apr/19/marks-spencer-menswear-kestin-hare-alexa-chung">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/fashion">Fashion</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/mens-fashion">Men's fashion</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/business/marksspencer">Marks & Spencer</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/alexa-chung">Alexa Chung</category>

    <item>
      <title>Issey Miyake: 45 years at the forefront of fashion</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/apr/10/issey-miyake-45-years-at-the-forefront-of-fashion</link>
      <description><p>At 77, Issey Miyake is still at the cutting edge of design. Tamsin Blanchard joins him in Tokyo</p><p><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/fashion-blog/2012/apr/24/issey-miyake-wins-design-prize">Issey Miyake</a> is quite excited about his paper suit. “It doesn’t crease!” he tells me as he smiles and scrunches up a bit of his sleeve with his fingers. It springs back to perfectly smooth.</p><p>The suit itself looks very straightforward: a smart blue single-breasted jacket with matching trousers, no low crotch on the trousers, no asymmetry; the sleeves are both where you expect sleeves to be; there’s not even a random pleat. But this is <a href="http://mds.isseymiyake.com/mds/en/collection/">typical Issey Miyake</a>. In more than 45 years of designing clothes, he has never stopped innovating. He has an obsession with making clothes that are light, practical and washable, and that don’t crease.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/apr/10/issey-miyake-45-years-at-the-forefront-of-fashion">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>How men are mixing it up: the 'winterfication' of the summer wardrobe</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/apr/11/how-men-are-mixing-it-up-the-winterfication-of-the-summer-wardrobe</link>
      <description><p>Men are ignoring the season’s change and mixing winter and summer looks: think Beckham in a beanie in springtime, or Pharrell in loafers and shorts </p><p>Traditionally, menswear has strict seasonal boundaries: jumpers and dark hues for autumn winter, short sleeves and mankles for the summer months. But it’s a rulebook that doesn’t allow for the reality of how men wear clothes: namely that for most men, a couple of perrenials should last all year long. In this spirit, there’s been an increasing winterfication of the summer wardrobe in menswear.</p><p>“I think men are quite random about their wardrobe,” says psychologist Ros Taylor. “It’s like, they bought a hat in winter and felt they cut a dash with it, so why change a winning formula for a season change? As women, we coordinate, and buy magazines to inform us of the latest shoe combos. Men tend to wear what’s in their wardrobe.”</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/apr/11/how-men-are-mixing-it-up-the-winterfication-of-the-summer-wardrobe">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/apr/07/my-agents-told-me-to-stop-eating-the-reality-of-body-image-in-modelling</link>
      <description><p>Two models have come forward and exposed the pressure put on models by agents and designers, but there’s hope</p><p>Two models have spoken out about the pressures they faced to stay skinny, shining a light on the continued body image issues faced by the fashion industry. Erin Heatherton, a former Victoria’s Secret model, has revealed that she was pressurised to lose weight by the fashion house.     <item>
      <title>Whisker tango foxtrot: post-hipster beards and what they say about you</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/apr/07/whisker-foxtrot-tango-post-hipster-beards-and-what-they-say-about-you</link>
      <description><p>From the Superbeard to the Upside Down, men are trying out different grooming styles to stand out from the tattooed crowd</p><p>As anyone with eyes will tell you, beards have become a mainstay of everyday life. If the hipster subculture birthed a defining look, it’s now just part of the furniture. In 2016, Men are more confident about trying out different styles to stand out from the tattooed crowd. Following Letterman’s <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/shortcuts/2015/oct/14/the-p46-the-loser-and-other-beard-types-2015-david-letterman">achievement beard</a> (which he praised as a “<a href="http://www.whitefishreview.org/archives/2015/12/david-letterman-interview/">real creepy look</a>”) , the new beard styles are saying more than “I think I could catfish people into thinking I’m Brad Pitt with this.” So what do they say about you?</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/apr/07/whisker-foxtrot-tango-post-hipster-beards-and-what-they-say-about-you">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Pleats to please: six ways to wear the skirt of choice for 2016</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/apr/05/pleats-skirt-2016-beyonce-alexa-chung-gucci-strictly-spring-wardrobe</link>
      <description><p>Beyoncé and Alexa Chung have put a new spin on it, Gucci brought it to the catwalk, and Strictly added sparkles to take it up a notch. Do you need any more reasons to bring the pleated skirt to the top of your spring wardrobe wish list?</p><p>Take note, iron-averse style watchers: pleated skirts are the only ones that pass fashion muster right now – they’re everywhere from the catwalk to the red carpet to your iPlayer catch-up session. Like <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/mar/23/denim-hair-what-does-it-mean">denim hair</a>, big logos or <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/mar/21/beginners-guide-to-facial-contouring-kim-kardashian">contouring</a>, pleats’ popularity is partly down to the fact that they’re really photogenic. They might not be desk-job-friendly (those wrinkles from sitting down do tend to spoil a pleat’s line) but when snapped moving – as on a Vogue editor on the way to a fashion show – or wafting through a waltz, they have a pleasing three-dimensional quality that an A-line mini or pencil skirt just can’t claim. In this brave new world of skirts, the pleat semantics are a minefield. Here’s our guide to six pleats and what they mean in 2016.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/apr/05/pleats-skirt-2016-beyonce-alexa-chung-gucci-strictly-spring-wardrobe">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Camo chameleon: why the luxe army look is having a moment</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/apr/06/camo-chameleon-why-the-luxe-army-look-is-having-a-moment</link>
      <description><p>From Drake to the ‘hipster hunter’, the masculine military look is on the march once again</p><p>Menswear is currently having a love affair with the sartorial style of the blue-collar worker, from the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/gallery/2016/mar/03/most-wanted-five-objects-of-desire-for-spring-in-pictures">DHL delivery man</a> to the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/jan/26/fisherman-fashion-menswear-workwear-trend">fisherman</a> to the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2014/nov/14/lumbersexual-beard-plaid-male-fashion">lumbersexual</a> to the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/mar/08/easy-riders-anoraks-patchworked-jeans-post-chic-paris-fashion-instagrammed-catwalk-kanye-west">waltzer boys</a>. Taken as an extension of the utilitarian wear movement, it makes sense: worker wear is functional in a way that doesn’t scare the horses, is inventive enough to power of the imaginations of designers and has a masculine associative appeal. Now menswear is turning to the army for inspiration, taking old favourites and giving them a modernist reboot.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/apr/06/camo-chameleon-why-the-luxe-army-look-is-having-a-moment">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Burkinis are nasty, but then fashion is seldom liberating | Catherine Bennett</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/apr/03/burkini-islam-fashion-marks-and-spencer</link>
      <description><p>As ‘modest wear’ hits the high street, the debate raging around it has more than a hint of hypocrisy</p><p>After an increasingly desperate few years, which the combined efforts of Emma Thompson, Doreen Lawrence and Alexa Chung have so far done little to relieve, Marks and Spencer has finally produced a garment that people want to talk about.</p><p>Yet more unusually, the object of interest, <a href="http://www.marksandspencer.com/floral-contrast-burkini/p/p22431888" title="">a blue burkini</a> – a kind of whole-body swimming pyjama – is still, at the time of writing, available online, and looks as if it might be just the ticket for anyone planning a trip to broiling, jellyfish-infested waters. Though the suit’s purpose is not, you gather, physical protection. Rather, M&amp;S stresses: “This burkini suit covers the whole body with the exception of the face, hands and feet, without compromising on style.”</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/apr/03/burkini-islam-fashion-marks-and-spencer">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Justin Bieber's dreadlocks: what he should learn about locked hair</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/apr/05/justin-bieber-dreadlocks-cultural-appropriation-black-pride</link>
      <description><p>Caught in the crosshairs of cultural appropriation, Bieber could use an education on the hairstyle that has roots in Hinduism, Rastafarianism and black resistance</p><p>Anytime Justin Bieber posts a photo to Instagram, tens of thousands of teens across America go wild. But when the pop star uploaded a series of pics ahead of the iHeart Radio Awards Sunday night, he created a different sort of reaction: a backlash.<strong> </strong></p><p>The photo revealed Bieber’s signature blond locks in what appeared to be the early stages of knotty dreadlocks. Fans were quick to <a href="https://twitter.com/KINGS0L0M0N/status/716836314100940800?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw">call him out</a> for cultural appropriation – something the pop star has been accused of in the <a href="http://time.com/4011171/cornrows-and-cultural-appropriation-the-truth-about-racial-identity-theft/">past</a>. And so here we are again – and the reaction is no surprise.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/apr/05/justin-bieber-dreadlocks-cultural-appropriation-black-pride">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>From Pringle to new Gucci: Ronnie Corbett, unlikely style icon</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/apr/04/ronnie-corbett-mens-fashion-style-icon-pringle-gucci-golf-wear-statement-glasses</link>
      <description><p>The comedian Ronnie Corbett, who died last week, was also a style icon, a ‘classless arisotocrat’ who embraced golf-wear, colours and statement glasses</p><p>He was neither tall, nor dark, nor handsome. He was, in fact, none of the things we expect of a “style icon” – and yet, somehow, <a draggable="true" href="http://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2016/mar/31/ronnie-corbett-dies-aged-85">Ronnie Corbett</a>, with his charm, talent, and charisma, became one of the most enduringly influential figures in British fashion. </p><p>His look was one part showbiz pizazz; a kind of Euro jet set glamour, which emerged dazzling out of the post-war gloom, tempered with a classically suave and dignified Britishness that is also jolly, eccentric and effortlessly smooth. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/apr/04/ronnie-corbett-mens-fashion-style-icon-pringle-gucci-golf-wear-statement-glasses">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Why Rihanna’s obsessed with Princess Diana</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/shortcuts/2016/apr/04/rihanna-t-shirt-princess-diana-fashion</link>
      <description><p>The pop queen has been spotted wearing a T-shirt emblazoned with Diana’s image – but it’s not the first time she’s expressed admiration for the Princess of Wales</p><p>Like flies to carrion, you can be sure wherever <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/feb/19/rihanna-delays-world-tour-anti-postponing-eight-shows-and-cancelling-two-more">Rihanna</a> goes the paps will follow. So it’s safe to assume the 28-year-old singer puts thought into what she’s wearing. Take her <a href="http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-3520983/Rihanna-pays-tribute-Princess-Diana-statement-steps-thigh-high-jean-boots.html">Princess Diana T-shirt</a>, worn in New York on Saturday. Just a hunch, but given she’s mid-world-tour (and, in a natty bit of self-promo, was also pictured wearing the denim waders she designed with <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2014/mar/22/manolo-blahnik-this-much-i-know">Manolo Blahnik</a> for her new collaboration), she’s probably trying to tell us something. But what?</p><p>In fact, it feeds into obtuse comparisons between Diana and the singer that were first mooted in an essay by the US scholar Camille Paglia in 2013 under the hyperbolic headline: <a href="http://www.thesundaytimes.co.uk/sto/public/article1214678.ece">Why Rihanna is the new Diana</a>. The piece kickstarted a long-running connection between the two women that delighted Rihanna: “Never thought these many people would even know my name; now it’s next to Princess Diana’s on the front of a newspaper!” she <a href="https://www.instagram.com/p/V1A6vrhMx-/">wrote on Instagram</a>.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/shortcuts/2016/apr/04/rihanna-t-shirt-princess-diana-fashion">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>I too have ginger hair. Abusing us is not acceptable prejudice | Nicholas Milton</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/10/ginger-hair-edward-watson-gingerism</link>
      <description>Redheads such as Edward Watson, the Royal Ballet dancer, are still often a target for unthinking taunts. Surely it’s time to consign gingerism to history<p>Ginger nut. Duracell battery. Carrot top. These hurtful taunts were a regular part of my life growing up with a mop of red hair in a tough inner-city comprehensive during the 1970s. And like a lot of other young people at the time who suffered because they looked different, I was singled out.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/stage/2016/may/10/royal-ballet-dancer-edward-watson-references-ginger-hair">Royal Ballet dancer fed up with critic's references to his ginger hair</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/10/ginger-hair-edward-watson-gingerism">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>The joy of socks - smelly ones, that is | Peter Ormerod</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/05/joy-of-smelly-socks-odourless</link>
      <description>The discovery of odourless socks is no mean feat for feet – but their gentrification messes with their whole socks appeal<p>We don’t care about you any more, wheel. Get outta here, lightbulb. Penicillin, do one. Because surely no advance in the history of human civilisation can come close to the discovery of <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/money/2016/may/04/devon-farmer-steve-whitley-claims-no-smell-angora-goat-mohair-socks" title="">socks that don’t smell and never need washing</a>. And I don’t mean this in a good way, either.</p><p>To paraphrase Nietzsche’s ruminations upon <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/God_is_dead" title="">the death of God</a>: we have seen the lightning but are yet to experience the thunder. For what is a sock if it is denuded of its olid destiny? What is a sock that never knows the inside of a washing machine, from which, mysteriously, it may never emerge? It is not a sock, in any recognisable sense of the word. We haven’t thought this through at all, have we?</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/05/joy-of-smelly-socks-odourless">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Am I going to regret my tattoo? You asked Google – here’s the answer | Sarah Marsh</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/04/am-i-going-to-regret-my-tattoo-google-answer</link>
      <description><p>Every day millions of internet users ask Google life’s most difficult questions, big and small. This week our readers answer one of the commonest queries</p><p>Like a dog or a cat, a tattoo is for life, not just for Christmas. When one goes wrong, it can go really wrong: we’ve all heard horror stories about mementos of a (now ex) girlfriend or boyfriend or tales of “spontaneous” (read: drunken) inkings.</p><p>But even if a tattoo is well thought through – as is often the case – can you ever be sure you won’t regret it? Maybe not today, maybe not tomorrow, but soon, and for the rest of your life?</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/04/am-i-going-to-regret-my-tattoo-google-answer">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>East Africa's ban on second-hand clothes won't save its own industry</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sustainable-business/2016/may/04/east-africa-kenya-ban-second-hand-clothing-imports-west</link>
      <description><p>If the proposed ban on used clothing imports is to succeed, governments must also tackle cheap imports from Asia and offer more support to local industry</p><p>Across the African continent second-hand clothes from developed countries are a mainstay of many informal traders, dominating local market stalls. <a href="http://comtrade.un.org/data/" rel="nofollow">East Africa alone imported $151m</a> of second-hand clothing last year, <a href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-30227025" rel="nofollow">most of which</a> was collected by charities and recyclers in Europe and North America.</p><p>In February, however, the East African Community (EAC), an intergovernmental organisation, <a href="http://www.theeastafrican.co.ke/news/EAC-heads-of-state-to-ban-used-clothes-and-shoes-imports-/-/2558/3094476/-/6jmhba/-/index.html" rel="nofollow">proposed a ban </a>on imported used clothes and shoes. The aim is to encourage local production and development within member countries: Burundi, Kenya, Rwanda, Tanzania and Uganda.<br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sustainable-business/2016/may/04/east-africa-kenya-ban-second-hand-clothing-imports-west">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/sustainable-business/sustainable-business">Guardian sustainable business</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/world/africa">Africa</category>

    <item>
      <title>Curious silence of Philip Green’s celebrity friends | Catherine Bennett</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/01/curious-silence-philip-green-celebrity-friends-bhs-kate-moss</link>
      <description><p>Kate Moss never says much in public, but why are the other chums of the beleaguered businessman so quiet?</p><p>Dunbar’s Number suggests that 150 is around the maximum that it is possible, for the average person, <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/2011/apr/25/few-people-dunbars-number">to have as friends</a>. For some reason, the businessman formerly known as Sir Philip Green has always seemed to be on a mission to disprove it. Phil’s Number, as we might call it, appears to be more like <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/books/2013/may/03/what-makes-great-gatsby">Jay Gatsby’s</a>: limitless. As with his acquisition of shops and yachts, there really is no end, Green has repeatedly demonstrated, to the number of brand-new friends available to a determined person with a sufficiently attractive and compelling personality.</p><p>Photographs of the businessman, perhaps by design, tend to show him surrounded by friends, as impressive in quality as in quantity, and plainly thrilled, from their body language, to be in his company: there is a lot of hugging. In and around a Topshop show, for example, we might find Green <a href="http://www.dailymail.co.uk/femail/article-3242141/Cressida-Bonas-lovely-lace-hobnobs-Anna-Wintour-Alexa-Chung-Suki-Waterhouse-Topshop-Unique-s-fashion-week-row.html">pressed against</a> Cressida Bonas, aged 26, the actress and former girlfriend of Prince Harry, prior to nestling alongside an old friend, Anna Wintour.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/01/curious-silence-philip-green-celebrity-friends-bhs-kate-moss">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Lil’ Kim shouldn’t be blamed for her new, whiter, look | Patience Zalanga</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/apr/27/lil-kim-whiter-look-misogynoir-colourism-anti-blackness</link>
      <description>Misogynoir, colourism and anti-blackness invade our lives every day. When I saw how Lil’ Kim had changed, I could only empathise<p>Amid all the black girl love emanating from <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/apr/25/beyonce-lemonade-jay-z-infidelity-emotional-project-depths" title="">Beyoncé’s brilliant video album Lemonade</a>, <a href="http://uk.complex.com/tag/black-twitter" title="">Black Twitter</a> blew up on Sunday in response to rapper <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/musicblog/2014/aug/05/lil-kim-takes-the-crown-off-nicki-minajs-flawless-remix" title="">Lil’ Kim</a> revealing a new look <a href="https://www.instagram.com/p/BEmWuB2vsVu/?taken-by=lilkimthequeenbee&amp;hl=en" title="">on Instagram</a>. After what looks like extensive cosmetic surgery to her facial features, lighter skin, and a straight blonde weave, she barely resembles the only woman to ever outrap Biggie on a track. The notorious K.I.M. looks white. There were mixed reactions from black social media users; some people made jokes and memes, some were simply mystified, and many reacted with pity. White social media was largely silent. I found myself oddly defensive of Lil’ Kim’s decision to alter her appearance. While not exactly endorsing her look, I could certainly understand it.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/apr/25/beyonce-lemonade-jay-z-infidelity-emotional-project-depths">Beyoncé's Lemonade is about much more than Jay Z and infidelity | Ijeoma Oluo</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/apr/27/lil-kim-whiter-look-misogynoir-colourism-anti-blackness">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Mrs Cameron’s Diary: Boho pyjamas for Obamas: #totesapprope | As seen by Catherine Bennett</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/apr/22/mrs-camerons-diary-boho-pyjamas-for-obamas-visit-totesapprope</link>
      <description>Govey’s Brexit glasses are almost *a thing* fashwise so Rosie’s given me top Coachella tips<p>Well the way everyone <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/apr/19/brexit-could-spark-democratic-liberation-of-continent-says-gove" title="">went on about Govey</a> anyone would think he was some sort of genius, even Rosie is like, God Sam I know he is like your total frenemy but fashwise those Brexit glasses are actually almost a *thing*? I’m like *sarcasm voice*, well thank you Rosie for your loyalty to your actual employer, she’s like *fashion adviser voice* awesome, btw Sam, tightswise do you think yes for <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/apr/21/obama-arrives-in-london-with-eu-referendum-high-on-the-agenda" title="">the Obama visit</a> or more sort of not? I’m like, what would you advise, she’s like, whatevs Sam you choose, they are your legs not mine, I’m like, thank you, she’s like, you’re welcome, I mean tbh Sam I am not the biggest fan of that dress anyway but I have not just turned 45, God, I just can’t even.</p><p>I said to Mummy, honestly, how embarrassing was Govey? Mummy’s like, of course he has behaved appallingly but his speech was priceless, “<a href="http://www.theguardian.com/politics/video/2016/apr/19/remain-conjuring-up-boogeymen-to-win-says-gove-video" title="">operating to a script written by George RR Martin</a>”, we were in fits, I’m like, what about Dave’s joke, did you hear him say “I’m lovin’ it” lol. She’s like, sorry, how actually IS that amusing? I’m like, I literally have no clue, but Nancy said it was hilair, bear in mind she wrote it, plus did you see her Queen tribute, “<a href="http://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2016/apr/21/charles-turns-to-shakespeare-to-pay-tribute-to-the-queen" title="">she has been a rock of strength</a>”, such luck her Easter homework was How I Feel About the Queen, all Dave had to do was read it out, while she planned the Obama visit. Mummy’s like, so what are you wearing? I’m like, Rosie thinks maybe a fringed suede jacket over denim cut-offs, with a messy rock-chick *do*?</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/apr/22/mrs-camerons-diary-boho-pyjamas-for-obamas-visit-totesapprope">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Why is Kim Kardashian famous? You asked Google – here’s the answer | Eleanor Morgan</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/apr/20/why-is-kim-kardashian-famous</link>
      <description>Every day millions of internet users ask Google life’s most difficult questions, big and small. Our writers answer some of the commonest queries<p>How do you begin to dissect fame like that of <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/kim-kardashian">Kim Kardashian</a>? Where do you make the first cut in such omnipresence? Because it’s not just about her, the flesh and bones woman, any more. We exist within her vast show, literally and figuratively. Even if you don’t actively choose to follow her movements, she’s there. Inescapable.</p><p>We should start with the unavoidable: the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kim_Kardashian">sex tape</a>. In the mid-00s Kardashian wasn’t famous like her friends <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2007/aug/25/usa.edpilkington">Nicole Richie</a> and <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/paris-hilton">Paris Hilton</a>, for whom she was a stylist. Richie and Hilton were catapulted into the public eye with their feckless and fantastic reality show <a href="http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0362153/">The Simple Life</a>, blasting a tsunami of velour <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/jul/02/the-day-i-threw-out-my-juicy-couture-tracksuit">Juicy Couture</a> and Von Dutch trucker caps into society. They giggled and pouted on every red carpet and magazine cover going. But this kind of fame eluded Kardashian, despite her <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/news/2003/oct/06/guardianobituaries.usa">notorious parents</a> and her social life. Until, that is, her <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/filmblog/2008/apr/15/delaneyonmonroe">sex tape</a> – recorded in 2003 with her then-boyfriend Ray “Ray J” Norwood – was “leaked” into the public domain.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/apr/20/why-is-kim-kardashian-famous">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Hairy armpits, spots, burps, wee – these are the signs of true love | Nell Frizzell</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/apr/19/hairy-armpits-spots-burps-wee-hotel-new-zealand-banned-lycra-shorts-cycling</link>
      <description><p>Hearing that a hotel in New Zealand had banned Lycra shorts is quite funny when you’ve been letting it all hang out on a cycling tour with your partner</p><p>Until your partner has seen you in the sort of padded cycling shorts that make you look like you’re wearing an industrial-strength nappy over the unshorn legs of <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/books/2005/dec/04/cslewis.film" title="">Mr Tumnus</a>, I’m afraid you’re still just dating. It’s not a relationship until you stop shaving your armpits. You’re not somebody’s partner until you’ve shared a poorly ventilated bathroom.</p><p>All this I have learned only recently, as I undertook a sweaty, hairy, padded, hilly and at times freezing bike ride across Ireland with my boyfriend. It was here, under the sun and occasional hail that I finally let it all hang out. Bobbing down beside a hedge at a canal’s edge to go for an al-fresco pee somewhere outside Mullingar, I felt the last of my single lady mystique gently stream down across my left foot as I stared resolutely into the eyes of a watching sheep. As I squeezed a blackhead the approximate size of a broad bean, until that moment trapped under the rubberised hem of my cycling shorts, I felt a release not just of sebum but also of romantic expectation. While standing behind a tent in my cotton M&amp;S briefs, wet wiping away two days of accumulated grime, I started to hum the Commodores: she’s mighty mighty, just lettin’ it all hang out.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/apr/19/hairy-armpits-spots-burps-wee-hotel-new-zealand-banned-lycra-shorts-cycling">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Smart v casual: the ultimate menswear style swap</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/mar/06/vintage-streetwear-menswear-style-swap-henry-lloyd-hughes-elgar-johnson</link>
      <description><p>What happens when the vintage-loving star of Indian Summers, Henry Lloyd-Hughes, switches wardrobes with Elgar Johnson, a fashion director obsessed with sportswear?<strong> <br></strong></p><p>When people meet me in the flesh, they often seem disappointed that I don’t resemble Mark Donovan, the character I played in <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/the-inbetweeners">The Inbetweeners</a>, a bit more closely. “Where is the French crop, where is the sportswear?” they think. Instead they find someone with a lifelong enthusiasm for dressing snappily – for <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/tvandradioblog/2015/feb/16/how-to-do-vintage-when-youre-a-man">men’s tailoring, militaria and exotic vintage</a>. But sports casual not so much.<br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/mar/06/vintage-streetwear-menswear-style-swap-henry-lloyd-hughes-elgar-johnson">Continue reading...</a></description>
