    <item>
      <title>Back on track: the return of the zip-up tracksuit top</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/mar/08/back-on-track-the-return-of-the-zip-up-tracksuit-top</link>
      <description><p>Get ready to channel your inner Britpop boy and revisit your adolescent Adidas addiction – we’re on the verge of a retro sportswear comeback</p><p>The last time I wore a tracksuit top – vintage navy blue with the classic zip-up funnel-neck finish – was circa the mid-90s. Flashback: I’m in a pub in my small home town, leaning (probably a bit drunkenly) against a jukebox, with floppy hair, possibly wearing some friendship bracelets. Enter three older, tougher-looking men who stop, survey me and simultaneously chorus above the pub din: “<a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/musicblog/2014/apr/23/parklife-how-does-blurs-album-sound-20-years-on">Parklife</a>.”</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/mar/08/back-on-track-the-return-of-the-zip-up-tracksuit-top">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>The big reveal: deconstructing the slip dress</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/mar/07/the-big-reveal-deconstructing-the-slip-dress</link>
      <description><p>It’s underwear as outerwear, a flimsy thing that blurs the boundaries between public and private, grunge and sex. And it’s back</p><p>Fashion may be quixotic, but there are some things you don’t argue with: <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/may/17/miuccia-prada-i-hate-the-idea-of-being-a-collector">Mrs Prada</a>’s genius, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/karl-lagerfeld">Karl</a>’s Edwardian collar preference and the stone cold rightness of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nova_(UK_magazine)">Nova magazine</a>. In a prescient editorial printed in January 1969 with the headline, “What are you trying to hide?” the mag declared that the only response to worrying that your underwear would be visible beneath your clothes was to turn a wardrobe vice into a virtue. “Show that you mean it,” it declared. “Don’t count on your underclothes not showing, choose them so if they do, it doesn’t matter.” Accompanied by a model shot and clothes credited to Woolworths – an arch styling move if ever there were one – it documented a pivotal moment in the fashion history of underwear as outerwear.</p><p>Forty-five years later and the concept of the blurred line between public and private fashion – what ought to be concealed or revealed – is still being played out on the catwalk. For spring 2016, the debate began in September at the Givenchy show – a visiting dignitary at New York fashion week for one season only – where designer <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/riccardo-tisci">Riccardo Tisci</a> riffed on a slip dress theme with chemises, wispy lace and silk slips. At Calvin Klein, creamy ankle-length slip dresses with misbehaving slovenly-cum-sexy straps were worn with minimal trainers and recalled the 90s. It was an echo of the brand’s heyday, a moment of nostalgia for those whose love affair with fashion began when a doe-like <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/kate-moss">Kate Moss</a> defined the brand. In London, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/business/burberrygroup">Burberry</a> continued the theme, showing silky flowing slip dresses with utilitarian rucksacks and contrasting chunky sandals. Was Christopher Bailey submitting to his inner grunge rocker?</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/mar/07/the-big-reveal-deconstructing-the-slip-dress">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Marc Jacobs:  ‘I have the word Shameless tattooed on my chest'</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/mar/04/marc-jacobs-i-have-the-word-shameless-tattooed-on-my-chest</link>
      <description><p>The distinguished designer’s return to New York has been triumphant. Here he talks about sobriety, social media and how clothes help articulate our feelings<br></p><p>“You can ask me anything. I’m an open book. What do you want to know?”</p><p>That, right there, is who <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/marc-jacobs">Marc Jacobs</a> is. Maybe he doesn’t mean it quite literally – what smart, self-respecting 52-year-old is going to share his deepest secrets with a journalist he barely knows? – but the sentiment is heartfelt, no doubt about that. <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Xv744Ckqp5U">I Want Your Love</a>, Chic’s 1979 disco classic, is playing in his office, seven floors above Spring Street in New York’s SoHo. Jacobs lights a cigarette and leans back in his chair. “I have the word ‘Shameless’ tattooed on my chest. I want to be as honest as I possibly can,” he says. “I sleep better at night.”</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/mar/04/marc-jacobs-i-have-the-word-shameless-tattooed-on-my-chest">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>How should you dress at 50? Topshop's Kate Phelan tells you how</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/mar/05/kate-phelan-creative-director-topshop-high-street</link>
      <description><p>The creative director of Topshop discusses how to shop the high street as a grownup</p><p>The pursuit of individual and personal style becomes so much more important as you get older. When I look at my clothes at home, I don’t think my style has changed very much since my early 30s. That was when I settled on something. And if I could be 38 again, I don’t think I would dress any differently than I do now, at 50.</p><p>That said, some elements of the way I dress have been constant since I was a teenager, when I became obsessed with <a href="http://tmagazine.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/06/14/bruces-bellport/">a Bruce Weber Vogue shoot</a> based on <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2010/aug/18/edward-weston-photography">Edward Weston</a> and his women. I remember taking the magazine into Exeter to get my hair cut like the picture, then buying a fisherman’s jumper in a sailing shop. I bought a grey pencil skirt, dug out my school shoes and ankle socks, got my dad’s overcoat and got the look. I still dress like those pictures in a way.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/mar/05/kate-phelan-creative-director-topshop-high-street">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Why Botticelli's Venus is still fashion's favourite muse</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/mar/03/why-botticellis-venus-is-still-fashions-favourite-muse</link>
      <description><p>Erotic, youthful, ethereal: the Botticelli beauty who, 500 years on, continues to inspire Lady Gaga, Andy Warhol and Dolce &amp; Gabbana<br></p><p>How long is a good innings as an iconic beauty, these days? Thirty years, like <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2009/nov/12/question-time-cindy-crawford">Cindy Crawford</a>? Sixty-five, like <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/sophia-loren">Sophia Loren</a>?</p><p>How about 530 years? That’s how long Botticelli’s women have been adored, desired and emulated. They have been <a href="https://cuttingedge.bobdylan.com/">muses to Bob Dylan</a> and <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AZ6mOC4uSX4">James Bond</a>, <a href="http://www.warhol.org/ArtCollections.aspx?id=1593">Andy Warhol</a> and <a href="http://www.zimbio.com/pictures/VkWSFxseouN/Lady+Gaga+Wearing+Botticelli+Inspired+Dolce/ED1M5XB4uhL">Lady Gaga</a>. <a href="http://www.uffizi.org/artworks/the-birth-of-venus-by-sandro-botticelli/">Botticelli’s Venus</a>, rising from her seashell, is a poster girl not just for the Uffizi, but in teenage bedrooms all over the world. (She even appears on an<a href="http://www.coindatabase.com/pic/w500/img/591pix_EuroCoins/10c_ita_2008.jpg"> Italian 10 cent euro coin</a>.) Flora from <a href="http://www.metmuseum.org/collection/the-collection-online/search/155851">the same painting inspired Elsa Schiaparelli in 1938</a>, while the figure of <a href="http://portlandgnosis.com/botticellis-primavera/">Flora as seen in Botticelli’s Primavera</a> was brought to life on <a href="http://www.vogue.com/fashion-shows/pre-fall-2015/valentino/slideshow/collection#16">the Valentino catwalk last year</a>.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/mar/03/why-botticellis-venus-is-still-fashions-favourite-muse">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/fashion">Fashion</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/lifeandstyle">Life and style</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/artanddesign">Art and design</category>

    <item>
      <title>Secrets of a professional Instagrammer</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/mar/02/instagram-professional-instagrammer-blogger-filter</link>
      <description><p>There are people on Instagram who get paid to go on holiday, employ professional photographers and receive endless freebies. Here one blogger tells us how she makes a living </p><p>Is it terrible to admit that I get so many free gifts, I’m starting to feel trapped? That every day, as the parcels and “Sorry we missed you” slips pile up on my doorstep, my stress levels rise?</p><p>As a blogger, I know that inside every package will be a note: “Please post a picture of this gift including our hashtag.” But I’m not going to post a shot of every crap shoe that arrives; I’ve got a website to run. So you’re stuck: return the gifts and spend hours in the post office and a fortune on postage. Don’t return them – and fail to plug that rubbish product – and you’ll get a bad rep.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/mar/02/instagram-professional-instagrammer-blogger-filter">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/fashion">Fashion</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/lifeandstyle">Life and style</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/instagram">Instagram</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/media/blogging">Blogging</category>
      <pubDate>Wed, 02 Mar 2016 13:01:06 GMT</pubDate>
      <guid>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/mar/02/instagram-professional-instagrammer-blogger-filter</guid>
      <media:content width="140" url="https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/89c0bea8e2c3d3b395800ee0dc83db0705ee1941/0_335_2089_1257/master/2089.jpg?w=140&q=55&auto=format&usm=12&fit=max&s=6b258f1ee48c791a3826972f8438f8f9">
        <media:credit scheme="urn:ebu">Illustration: Antonio Soares</media:credit>
      </media:content>
      <media:content width="460" url="https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/89c0bea8e2c3d3b395800ee0dc83db0705ee1941/0_335_2089_1257/master/2089.jpg?w=460&q=55&auto=format&usm=12&fit=max&s=e93a32b57aeb599b549405f0000533a8">
        <media:credit scheme="urn:ebu">Illustration: Antonio Soares</media:credit>
      </media:content>
      <dc:creator>The Secret Instagrammer, as told to Hannah Marriott</dc:creator>

    <item>
      <title>Plate-a-porter: when designers have their cake and eat it, too</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/mar/07/plate-a-porter-when-designers-have-their-cake-and-eat-it-too</link>
      <description><p>From a Twix bar to fish finger sandwiches, it’s time to find out what fashion’s lunch hour really looks like</p><p>Posting pictures of your lunch may be the ultimate social media stereotype, but it is one for which the usually cliche-averse fashion industry has fallen hard. Blame Instagram and the endless filtered photos of the food (plateies?) you’re about to tuck into. But right now anyone who reckons they’re anyone is talking about food, or posting pictures of eggs benedict and chips, even if the amount of carbs actually ingested is negligible.</p><p>In designers’ frenetic studios, food is much more than fodder for Instagram. Whether it’s a Twix bar on the run at <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/christian-dior">Dior</a> or a team lunch at <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2013/jun/25/acne-10-things-fashion-brand">Acne</a>, in its mundanity, the reality of what designers eat is way more revealing than the inspiration behind their S/S 16 collection.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/mar/07/plate-a-porter-when-designers-have-their-cake-and-eat-it-too">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/fashion">Fashion</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/lifeandstyle">Life and style</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/food-and-drink">Food & drink</category>
      <pubDate>Mon, 07 Mar 2016 06:01:55 GMT</pubDate>
      <guid>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/mar/07/plate-a-porter-when-designers-have-their-cake-and-eat-it-too</guid>
      <media:content width="140" url="https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/a79d8de6ca3804c6fc438c139f0c68180a1d6bb8/0_27_4966_2978/master/4966.jpg?w=140&q=55&auto=format&usm=12&fit=max&s=0d7185d582601ef49662c99668df80c3">
        <media:credit scheme="urn:ebu">Photograph: David Newby for the Guardian</media:credit>
      </media:content>
      <media:content width="460" url="https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/a79d8de6ca3804c6fc438c139f0c68180a1d6bb8/0_27_4966_2978/master/4966.jpg?w=460&q=55&auto=format&usm=12&fit=max&s=47c4a2ab7a7d43a9687d2fe12ad8206a">

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/apr/27/stella-mccartney-team-gb-olympic-kit-is-confidentially-patriotic</link>
      <description><p>The designer’s Olympic kit blends a safe heritage print meets performance kit</p><p>All herald Team GB. With the 2016 Olympics three months away, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/stella-mccartney">designer Stella McCartney</a> has fired the starting pistol, unveiling a new kit for <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/sport/team-gb">Team GB</a> and <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/sport/paralympicsgb">ParalympicsGB</a> which features a new heraldic coat of arms as its logo.</p><p>“The coat of arms is all around us in Britain. It’s so much a part of us that we barely even notice it, but it is so distinctively British,” said McCartney shortly after presiding over the launch wearing six-inch high heels, shoulder-robing a red coat over a cream blouse and black silk jogging bottoms. She was flanked on stage in central London by Tom Daley, who sported the new coat of arms on his tiny navy trunks, and Jessica Ennis with the image emblazoned on a two piece. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/apr/27/stella-mccartney-team-gb-olympic-kit-is-confidentially-patriotic">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>Pictures taken by British fashion photographer Josh Olins will hang in National Portrait Gallery as part of exhibition to mark magazine’s centenary</p><p>The Duchess of Cambridge is to appear on the front cover of the British edition of Vogue to mark the magazine’s centenary. </p><p>Several more pictures of the duchess will appear inside the magazine, and two of the photographs will go on public display in London on Sunday 1 May.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2016/apr/30/duchess-of-cambridge-appears-as-vogue-cover-star">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>Francisco Costa and Italo Zucchelli are to leave the US brand, to make way for ‘one creative vision’, possibly under Raf Simons</p><p>Calvin Klein has announced that Francisco Costa and Italo Zucchelli will be leaving the company.     <item>
      <title>Anthony Vaccarello named as creative director of Saint Laurent</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/apr/04/versus-anthony-vaccarello-move-versace-saint-laurent-fashion</link>
      <description><p>The Belgian-Italian, widely tipped to join the French house, has been confirmed as the new designer</p><p>Anthony Vaccarello has been named as the creative director of Saint Laurent, confirming what had been suspected with the fashion industry. He was widely expected to replace Hedi Slimane, who left <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/apr/01/hedi-slimane-has-announced-his-exit-from-saint-laurent">the house on Friday</a>. </p><p>In a statement, Francesca Bellettini, president and CEO of Saint Laurent, praised Vaccarello’s “modern, pure aesthetic … Anthony Vaccarello impeccably balances elements of provocative femininity and sharp masculinity in his silhouettes.” </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/apr/04/versus-anthony-vaccarello-move-versace-saint-laurent-fashion">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Beyoncé stamps her unmistakable brand on sportswear fashion</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/apr/01/beyonce-stamps-her-unmistakable-brand-on-sportswear-fashion</link>
      <description><p>Singer’s new Ivy Park label is a fusion of empowerment and enjoyment, just as she is</p><p>It is a stone-cold fact about the modern world that where there are emotional buttons to be pressed, there is a lucrative business opportunity. The festive season, for instance, is now officially ushered in by a <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/media/2015/nov/19/jingles-bells-its-the-twelve-ads-of-christmas">fight to the death between retailers</a> over who can make the general public cry the most with their Christmas ad.</p><p>So it says something about how tightly wound we are about women’s bodies and fitness that even campaigns for running leggings are conceived with that I’ve-got-something-in-my-eye feeling in mind. <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZY0cdXr_1MA">A commercial for the activewear label Under Armour</a>, entitled I Will What I Want, shows American ballerina <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/stage/2015/jun/30/misty-copeland-success-ballet-right-direction">Misty Copeland</a> in a dance studio and on stage, soundtracked by the rejection letters she received at the beginning of her career; it has clocked up 10m views on YouTube. The Adidas <a href="http://mygirls.adidas.co.uk">All In For #mygirls campaign</a>, the <a href="http://www.nike.com/us/en_us/c/women/better-for-it">Nike Better for It</a> spots and Always’ award-winning <a href="http://always.com/en-us/about-us/our-epic-battle-like-a-girl">#LikeAGirl campaign</a> have all hit the same emotional sweetspot of physical health and female empowerment. Fourth-wave feminism is on a workout high, while still uneasy about how much female self-esteem is bound up with our bodies.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/apr/01/beyonce-stamps-her-unmistakable-brand-on-sportswear-fashion">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/fashion">Fashion</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/music/beyonce">Beyoncé</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/fitness">Fitness</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/womens-sportswear">Women's sportswear</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/music/music">Music</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/lifeandstyle">Life and style</category>
      <pubDate>Fri, 01 Apr 2016 14:19:27 GMT</pubDate>
      <guid>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/apr/01/beyonce-stamps-her-unmistakable-brand-on-sportswear-fashion</guid>

    <item>
      <title>French fashion mogul Pierre Bergé hits out at 'Islamic' clothing</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/mar/30/fashion-mogul-pierre-berge-hits-out-at-islamic-clothing</link>
      <description><p>The businessman, a former partner of Yves Saint Laurent, accuses fashion houses of taking part in the ‘enslavement of women’</p><p>Former fashion mogul Pierre Bergé has lashed out at designers who create Islamic clothing and headscarves, accusing them of taking part in the “enslavement of women”.<br></p><p>The French businessman was for many years the life and business partner of designer Yves Saint Laurent, who died in 2008. Together they founded YSL.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/mar/30/fashion-mogul-pierre-berge-hits-out-at-islamic-clothing">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Peacock revolution back with label that dressed Mick Jagger and David Bowie</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/mar/13/peacock-revolution-david-bowie-mick-jagger-mr-fish</link>
      <description>Revival of Mr Fish and new exhibition recall dandies of the 60s<p>Mr Fish, the 60s fashion label that helped usher in a “peacock revolution” in men’s fashion, is to be revived, evoking fond memories of a dandy revolution that inspired the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/aug/04/david-bowie-his-style-story-1972-1973" title="">young David Bowie</a>.</p><p>Although it ceased trading almost 40 years ago, plans are being made to bring out a new line of shirts and kipper ties, using the famous name. The move comes as a number of menswear designers and fashion houses, including Gucci and <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/jan/10/jw-anderson-mixes-mundane-and-strange-in-fashion-show-streamed-on-grindr" title="">JW Anderson</a>, are referencing the label’s style.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/mar/13/peacock-revolution-david-bowie-mick-jagger-mr-fish">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Saint Laurent in Paris: the return of the 80s party girl</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/mar/08/saint-laurent-in-paris-the-return-of-the-80s-party-girl</link>
      <description><p>There’s the echo of a Roxy Music video in Hedi Slimane’s latest, and possibly last, collection for fashion house</p><p>Since 2012, when designer <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/hedi-slimane">Hedi Slimane</a> began his reboot of the Saint Laurent brand, the label has been closely linked with music. Whether that be the young indie bands which populated the front row of his shows to the chagrin of uptight fashion editors banished to the rows behind them, or the designs themselves which are frequently dosed with gig culture – Glastonbury wellies and Courtney Love tiaras were a feature of his last show in Paris. Advocates of the brand are often those who <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/fashion-blog/2016/feb/11/justin-bieber-glitter-and-velvet-saint-laurent-makes-its-la-debut">play music for a living</a>, from Justin Bieber to Keith Richards.</p><p>So it was significant that at the Saint Laurent show in Paris on Monday evening – the second part of the brand’s fall collection which began in blockbuster gig fashion in LA last month – that there was no catwalk music at all. Instead, the soundtrack was simply the voice of Benedicte de Ginestous announcing the arrival of each of the outfits. “Numero un ... number one,” she declared in a tone at once overly dramatic but also compelling. The significance of this device was not lost on the audience seated on personalised chairs in marble-heavy salons – de Ginestous announced the numbers of each look for Yves Saint Laurent’s couture shows between 1977 and 2002.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/mar/08/saint-laurent-in-paris-the-return-of-the-80s-party-girl">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Stella McCartney show: designer's clothes reflect how real women live</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/mar/07/paris-fashion-week-stella-mccartney-show-designer-clothes-real-women</link>
      <description><p>With her label in rude health, Paris fashion week show adopts a greatest hits approach – but if that sounds dull, it wasn’t</p><p>The disconnect between the invitations to Stella McCartney’s shows and the tone of the show itself has long been acknowledged by insiders at Paris fashion week. This season’s – a digital display with the word “invites” flashing across the screen – is pure silliness. </p><p>Monday’s event, on the other hand, was a serious business. While the show notes talked about “sensual with a sense of humour and a tomboy side” the collection worked on that classic commercial adage: if it ain’t broke, don’t fix it. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/mar/07/paris-fashion-week-stella-mccartney-show-designer-clothes-real-women">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Chanel in Paris: Lagerfeld revisits Coco</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/mar/08/chanel-in-paris-lagerfeld-revisits-coco-fashion-week</link>
      <description><p>Airport lounge chic and Scottish estate references were on display at this self-referential show</p><p>The concept of the front row is understood even by those with just a whisper of an interest in fashion. While music venues have their moshpits and politics has its front bench, fashion has the Frow. A catwalk front row is a microcosm of all the narcissistic peacocking that exists in any industry. But here on the Frow, fashion’s top table, everything is laid bare for all to see. It appears that Karl Lagerfield is a designer who finds this never-ending fussing over seats an absolute delight. Why else would he do away with the row formatting at the Chanel show and make every single seat – all 3,500 of them – a front row? Certainly not for democratic reasons (that seems unlikely for a man at the helm of a billion-euro label selling bags with four-figure price tags) – it’s more likely for the insider fun of it.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/mar/08/chanel-in-paris-lagerfeld-revisits-coco-fashion-week">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Dior's Paris catwalk upstaged by Blenheim Palace coup</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/mar/04/diors-paris-catwalk-upstaged-blenheim-palace-coup</link>
      <description><p>Label confirms it will exhibit next cruise collection at the Oxfordshire country house – 58 years after its last show there</p><p>It is a symptom of the current state of flux in the fashion industry that Dior’s autumn/winter womenswear show – the traditional biannual showpiece of the house, staged in a lavish mirrored venue in the Louvre according to the long-established calendar of Paris fashion week – was upstaged by the announcement of another Dior show. </p><p>The house will exhibit its cruise collection in Blenheim Palace on 31 May, two days before <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/feb/03/westminster-abbey-gets-a-gucci-makeover-stylewatch">Gucci stages an equally blockbusting show in London’s Westminster Abbey</a>. The news puts the historic buildings of England centre stage in the cruise catwalk schedule, which is rapidly becoming the most glamorous and high-profile season of the fashion year. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/mar/04/diors-paris-catwalk-upstaged-blenheim-palace-coup">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Milan fashion week: Armani looks to next year's red carpet</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/mar/01/milan-fashion-week-armani-looks-to-next-years-red-carpet</link>
      <description><p>Armani kept things classically polished, mixing a largely black and white collection of velvet dresses with relaxed officewear and glam athleisure</p><p>It seemed apt that Giorgio Armani, such a stalwart of the red carpet, should present his autumn/winter collection at Milan fashion week the Monday morning after the Oscars. The dresses worn for Sunday night’s ceremony –<a draggable="true" href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/gallery/2016/feb/28/oscars-red-carpet-fashion-2016-in-pictures"> including Cate Blanchett’s aqua-coloured Armani Privé gown</a> – have been hung back in the wardrobe, but awards-season dressing requires careful forward planning. Smart red-carpet players are already shopping for the next one.</p><p>Prospective red-carpet customers had to wait with this collection. The first thing of note was that Armani was catering to the vast majority of the women who buy his clothes: professionals, some of whom grew up in the 80s when the designer revolutionised workwear by adapting the men’s suit to womenswear. More than half of this show had outfits with trousers and a concession to the loosening-up of dress codes was implicit. Suits were in the minority here. Instead, most outfits were contrasting jacket and trousers – with many variations on the combination of black velvet trousers and pink tweed jacket. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/mar/01/milan-fashion-week-armani-looks-to-next-years-red-carpet">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Gigi Hadid stars at the Milan Versace show – in pictures</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/gallery/2016/feb/27/gigi-hadid-stars-at-the-milan-versace-show-in-pictures</link>
      <description><p>Donatella Versace describes her brand’s autumn/winter 2016 collection – modelled by Gigi Hadid among others in Milan – as daywear.     <item>
      <title>Italian PM Matteo Renzi to open Milan fashion week</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/feb/03/italian-pm-matteo-renzi-to-open-milan-fashion-week</link>
      <description><p>Italian premier to open biggest event in Italy’s fashion calendar despite reputation for lack of sartorial sense </p><p>Matteo Renzi has been mocked for his personal fashion foibles in the past, but the Italian prime minister will nevertheless brave the tough crowd of <a href="http://milanfashionweeklive.com/">Milan fashion week</a> later this month, becoming the first premier to open the event.</p><p>While Renzi is not expected to take a spin down the runway, the move is seen as an important show of support for the beleaguered industry, which has been hit by a slowdown in the Middle East and Russia and a drop-off in the Chinese market.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/feb/03/italian-pm-matteo-renzi-to-open-milan-fashion-week">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Dolce & Gabbana fashion range celebrates same-sex families</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/jan/29/dolce-gabbana-fashion-range-celebrates-same-sex-families</link>
      <description><p>Italian design duo appear to be trying to atone for remarks made last year criticising gay couples who have children</p><p>The Italian fashion designers Domenico Dolce and Stefano Gabbana appear to be trying to make amends for derogatory remarks they made last year about same-sex couples who have children with the release of a line of handbags and T-shirts celebrating gay and diverse families.</p><p>Gabbana’s <a href="https://www.instagram.com/p/BBFkpLslWq7/?taken-by=stefanogabbana">Instagram account</a> carried photographs of the new line, including a black handbag depicting two fathers and three children. Another photograph showed models wearing T-shirts with similar images, including of families with two mothers. The label used the hashtag #dgfamily. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/jan/29/dolce-gabbana-fashion-range-celebrates-same-sex-families">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Georgina Howell obituary</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/jan/28/georgina-howell</link>
      <description>Fashion journalist and biographer of Gertrude Bell, the trailblazing ‘daughter of the desert’ <br /><p>The elegant, perceptive journalism of Georgina Howell, who has died aged 73, entertained and informed readers of British and American magazines for 40 years, until she retired to Brittany in 2000 to write Daughter of the Desert, a biography of Gertrude Bell, the explorer, linguist and archaeologist who was the British government’s oriental secretary in Iraq in the 1920s.</p><p>Bell, whose life has since been made into a film, directed by Werner Herzog and starring Nicole Kidman, was Georgina’s heroine: an early feminist, the first woman to gain a first in modern history at Oxford, the first to achieve senior rank in British military intelligence and the first to win respect and to be treated as an equal by the establishment in Britain and rulers in the Middle East. The biography, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/books/2006/sep/03/biography.features" title="">published in 2006</a> and later retitled Queen of the Desert, was shortlisted for the Samuel Johnson prize. Georgina also edited Bell’s writings in A Woman in Arabia (2015), for Penguin Classics.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/jan/28/georgina-howell">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>André Courrèges obituary</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/jan/08/andre-courreges</link>
      <description>French fashion designer who popularised an ethereal, space-age look in the 1960s<p>A radical future was in fashion for a while in the 1960s, its girls gleaming ethereal in silver and white. The lead designer of this brave – and brief – new world was André Courrèges, who has died aged 92.</p><p>He was not an absolute beginner when he launched the look, although its success depended on his rapport with young people. He had been born in Pau, in the French Basque country (and kept the accent); studied as a civil engineer keen on architecture and textiles; and served as a pilot in the French air force during the second world war, recalling especially the sky-blue flannelette of the pyjamas issued to US forces who landed in France in 1944 – such good cloth.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/jan/08/andre-courreges">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Topman rocks on with catwalk show of flamboyant menswear</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/jan/08/topman-design-rocks-on-with-catwalk-show-of-flamboyant-menswear</link>
      <description><p>Diverse influences – from athevening to Marc Bolan to the 90s – could be seen in opening show of London Collections: Men</p><p>The show that opened <a href="http://www.londoncollections.co.uk/">London Collections: Men</a> – the menswear showcase and first fashion week of 2016 – undeniably set an agenda for the year ahead. The honour fell on Friday to Topman Design, the catwalk label from the high street store, with its autumn/winter show. The trends on display? Velvet, blouses for men, floral prints and colours inspired by autumn leaves and oxidised metals.</p><p>A front row including TV presenter Dermot O’Leary, singer Nick Jonas and actor Douglas Booth watched beanie-wearing models showcase a collection that was flamboyant, glamorous and ornate. Suits were slouchily cut in panne velvet, delicate devoré blouses had retro floral motifs, and decorative tailoring was <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/dec/14/harry-styles-ikea-chic-nudie-cohn-suit-stylewatch">worthy of One Direction’s Harry Styles</a>.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/jan/08/topman-design-rocks-on-with-catwalk-show-of-flamboyant-menswear">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Coach brings New York street style to London Collections – stylewatch</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/jan/09/coach-london-collections-menswear-catwalk-stylewatch</link>
      <description><p>Creative director Stuart Vevers says his new collection is inspired by Bruce Springsteen and early hip hop</p><p>Bruce Springsteen and Grandmaster Flash might not sound like natural bedfellows but Stuart Vevers managed to make a rock-hip hop mash-up look totally feasible on the <a href="http://uk.coach.com/">Coach</a> catwalk, done out with girders to look a bit like a building site. See loads of plaid, combat boots, bucket hats straight out of a Jamal Shabaz street style picture, and the excellently named Gotham tote bag. </p><p>‘It’s a New York brand so I’m looking at things from New York,’ said Vevers. ‘There are parallels between Bruce’s poetic rebellion and the early hip hop scene.’ Certainly in the hands of Vevers. Add XXXXL puffas, biker jackets and skinny straight-legged trousers and here’s an autumn 2016 look that is both born to run and a rapper’s delight. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/jan/09/coach-london-collections-menswear-catwalk-stylewatch">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Can Steve Rowe save M&S fashion?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/jan/07/can-steve-rowe-save-ms-fashion</link>
      <description><p>When Marks &amp; Spencer chief executive Marc Bolland steps down in April, following a noticeable drop in sales, his successor Steve Rowe will face a formidable challenge. Can M&amp;S’s current executive director of general merchandise turn things round?</p><p>Steve Rowe’s fashion credentials are strong. He began his career as a 15-year-old Saturday boy in the men’s knitwear department of M&amp;S in Croydon, and after leaving school worked at Topshop for four years before rejoining the company. This gives him a connection that Marc Bolland, who joined M&amp;S from Morrison and Heineken, did not have.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/jan/07/can-steve-rowe-save-ms-fashion">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Dior & the rise of the in-house design team</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/dec/10/dior-the-rise-of-the-in-house-design-team</link>
      <description><p>Since Raf Simons left Dior two months ago, speculation has been rife as to which big name would replace him. But the fashion house has reportedly announced that its new collections will be overseen by Simon’s design team</p><p><a draggable="true" href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/oct/22/raf-simons-to-leave-as-creative-director-at-dior">Raf Simons left Dior</a> in October. High time, surely, for a bells-and-whistles unveiling of a new star designer, ready to put his or her stamp on 2016’s collections. Conventional industry wisdom goes that to stage a show without a designer figurehead is a waste of considerable expense; on the other hand, a house of the status of Dior could never suffer the ignominy of not giving up their prime spot at Paris fashion week.</p><p>But according to <a href="http://wwd.com/fashion-news/designer-luxury/dior-studio-to-design-next-two-runway-collections-10294146/ ">WWD</a>, Dior has handed responsibility for the next two collections – haute couture, to be shown in January, and ready-to-wear, which presents at Paris Fashion Week in early March – to the design team who worked under Simons.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/dec/10/dior-the-rise-of-the-in-house-design-team">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Mariuccia Mandelli obituary</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/dec/13/mariuccia-mandelli</link>
      <description>Designer and head of the Italian fashion house Krizia, she created one of the first prototypes for hot pants<p>The godmother of Italian fashion, Mariuccia Mandelli, who has died aged 90, ran her ready-to-wear house Krizia for 60 years, helping to establish Mil an as an international industry capital and to export its hard tailoring, soft fabric and cerebral simplicity all over the world.</p><p>Her family intended her to be a primary school head (she had a definite “you-have-let-me-down” teacher’s manner); but her metier was dressing her dolls in imitation of shop window mannequins in her native Bergamo. She dutifully completed her teacher training course and worked in schools during her 20s, and then shocked her family when she sold the Lambretta scooter they had bought her and headed for nearby Milan on the proceeds.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/dec/13/mariuccia-mandelli">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>Europe’s largest retailer of luxury footwear acquired by Cinven, from US private equity group Sycamore Partners</p><p>Cinven, the private equity group, has bought Kurt Geiger, the largest retailer of luxury footwear in Europe, in a deal worth £245m.</p><p>Kurt Geiger, founded on London’s Bond Street in 1963, makes £30m-plus in profits annually on sales of around £260m.     <item>
      <title>Zara owner dismisses China slump fears as it reports 20% profit rise</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/dec/10/zara-inditex-dismisses-china-slump-fears-profit-rise</link>
      <description><p>Inditex records profits of €2bn in the first three quarters with group ‘very optimistic’ about China prospects despite downturn</p><p> Inditex, the owner of clothing retailer Zara, has said it is optimistic about its prospects in China despite the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/business/2015/oct/19/chinese-economic-growth-slows-to-69-in-third-quarter">slowing economy</a>, claiming mid-market brands were not feeling the pinch.</p><p>It came as the group, whose founder, Armancio Ortega, briefly overtook Bill Gates as the world’s wealthiest man this year, reported an overall sales rise of 16% to €14.7bn (£10.6bn) in the first three quarters of this year, with profits up 20% to €2.02bn.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/dec/10/zara-inditex-dismisses-china-slump-fears-profit-rise">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>The Glaswegian designer’s company becomes the latest on the London fashion week schedule to close down, less than a year after announcing key investment</p><p>Jonathan Saunders, the London fashion week designer, has announced that he is to close his label in the new year.     <item>
      <title>Stripes and zigzags: fashion brand Missoni's links to modern art</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/may/01/missoni-stripes-zigzags-modern-art-fashion-textile-museum-london</link>
      <description><p>Exhibition at Fashion and Textile Museum in London takes an eclectic trip through the Italian label’s six-decade history</p><p>For 60 years, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2014/sep/19/missoni-milan-fashion-week-family-affair">the Italian brand Missoni</a> has owned zigzags and stripes in fashion. The <a href="http://www.ftmlondon.org/ftm-exhibitions/missoni-art-colour/">Missoni Art Colour</a> show at the Fashion and Textile Museum in London does not disappoint on that front. Stripes are visible from the moment visitors walk through the door, on specially created lights that hang over the reception desk. <br></p><p>The rest of the exhibition, which originally opened in the Maga museum in Gallarate, Italy, last year, takes a less obvious trip through the brand’s history. As the title suggests, it’s about the connections between the company’s designs and <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/global/shortcuts/2015/oct/27/modern-art-is-rubbish-why-mistaking-artworks-for-trash-proves-their-worth">modern and contemporary art</a>. Divided into four galleries, the first contains no clothes at all. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/may/01/missoni-stripes-zigzags-modern-art-fashion-textile-museum-london">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Anna Wintour apologises for 'migrant chic' comments</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/apr/15/anna-wintour-under-fire-for-migrant-chic-comments</link>
      <description><p>Editor-in-chief of American Vogue used phrase to describe a Kanye West fashion show in New York</p><p><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/anna-wintour">Anna Wintour</a>, the editor-in-chief of American Vogue, has apologised for using the phrase “migrant chic” to describe a Kanye West fashion show.</p><p>During an appearance on the US TV talkshow Late Night with Seth Meyers, Wintour discussed pictures of her sitting alone in a VIP area at West’s event at Madison Square Garden, in New York where West was debuting his new album, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/feb/14/kanye-west-the-life-of-pablo-review-you-can-see-why-his-immodesty-rubs-people-up-the-wrong-way">The Life of Pablo</a>, and his Adidas Yeezy season 3 fashion line.<br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/apr/15/anna-wintour-under-fire-for-migrant-chic-comments">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2016/apr/13/underwear-goes-on-show-at-the-victoria-and-albert-museum</link>
      <description><p>V&amp;A’s Undressed: A Brief History of Underwear to include clothes worn by Kate Moss and Queen Victoria’s mother as well as rubber corset and men’s pants</p><p>Boxers, briefs, corsets, thermals, slips and bras – the contents of the nation’s smalls drawer will be spilled at <a href="http://www.vam.ac.uk/content/exhibitions/exhibition-undressed-a-brief-history-of-underwear/">Undressed: A Brief History of Underwear</a>, the biggest exhibition of underwear ever to go on display, which opens on 16 April at the Victoria and Albert Museum in London.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2016/mar/27/ten-iconic-underwear-moments-vanda-exhibition">Our top 10 iconic underwear moments</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2016/apr/13/underwear-goes-on-show-at-the-victoria-and-albert-museum">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Rainbow children: how the dip-dye trend has gone from shocking to mainstream</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/apr/03/peak-dip-dye-kim-kardashian-hipster-hairstyle</link>
      <description><p>Once the preserve of hipsters, multi-tone hairstyles are all the rage with everyone from Katy Perry to Zayn Malik</p><p><strong> <br></strong></p><p>Ten years is a long time for any trend to stay relevant, not least a hairstyle. But this year it will be a full decade since the “dip-dye” caught on with a certain type of fashion-conscious woman – think models such as Charlotte Free or the singer M.I.A. However, now that <a href="http://www.glamourmagazine.co.uk/news/beauty/2016/03/17/kim-kardashian-new-ombre-dip-dye-hair-pictures-news">Kim Kardashian has adopted the two-tone </a>look, it seems set to become one of the defining hairstyles of the age.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/apr/03/peak-dip-dye-kim-kardashian-hipster-hairstyle">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/mar/31/dead-ostrich-demo-flagship-store-ruffles-hermes-feathers</link>
      <description><p>Half-naked activist with mock dead bird demonstrates against fashion brand’s use of ostrich leather after Peta exposé</p><p>Activists have held a demonstration outside Hermès’ flagship store in central London to protest against the fashion brand’s use of ostrich leather to make handbags.<br></p><p>Jackie Joyce, 29, led the protest, during which she stood topless with a mock dead ostrich draped across her chest. She was joined by fellow activists Anna Buraya and Charly Keats holding handbag-shaped placards reading “Hermès: Bin ostrich skin”.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/mar/31/dead-ostrich-demo-flagship-store-ruffles-hermes-feathers">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/costume-and-culture/2016/mar/23/australian-wins-global-cosplay-competition-with-necromancer-outfit</link>

    <item>
      <title>How I get ready: Scott Mills, DJ and television presenter</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/mar/05/scott-mills-dj-radio-1-presenter-interview</link>
      <description><p>I can’t do a gig without new socks</p><p>When I DJ at student gigs, I start getting ready in the car. My tour manager picks me up and drives me wherever I need to be. They can be quite long journeys so he plays mellow music like Magic FM. Half an hour before we arrive he switches to Radio 1; because it is usually a Friday or Saturday night, they will be playing pumping dance music. That’s when I know it’s time to get ready.</p><p>I bring a man bag with me in which I have my clothes, hair wax, hair spray, aftershave and a mirror. I will change out of my jogging bottoms into a fresh pair of jeans, a nice shirt and a new pair of socks (I can’t do a gig without new socks). When I arrive, I brush my teeth and I am ready to go.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/mar/05/scott-mills-dj-radio-1-presenter-interview">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>How I get ready: Gabby Logan</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/feb/06/gabby-logan-interview-how-i-get-ready</link>
      <description><p>If I have 20 shows every days for 20 days, I have to be on it. It’s not as if when I get to Azerbaijan or Kiev I can just nip out to the nearest Zara</p><p>I exercise five days a&nbsp;week and I&nbsp;love&nbsp;it, so I’ll always make sure I&nbsp;get some in before a night out. It&nbsp;could be anything from circuits with my trainer or a bike ride, to&nbsp;yoga. It doesn’t matter, I&nbsp;always&nbsp;feel better for it. It gives my&nbsp;skin a glow and everything feels&nbsp;fresher.</p><p>If I’ve got a big week ahead, where I&nbsp;have to wear certain outfits for shows, red carpet events or dinners, I will plan everything on the Sunday. I have it all ready on the hanging rail in my dressing room so I’m not dithering and wasting time. It helps to be organised. The same applies when I go to big events such as the Olympics or world championships. If I have 20 shows every day for 20 days, I have to be on it. It’s not as if, when I get to Azerbaijan or Kiev, I can just nip out to the nearest Zara.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/feb/06/gabby-logan-interview-how-i-get-ready">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Lisa Bonet and Zoe Kravitz for Calvin Klein – stylewatch</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/jan/14/lisa-bonet-and-zoe-kravitz-for-calvin-klein-stylewatch</link>
      <description><p>Cheekbones, tattoos and two generations of fashion influence unite for the US brand’s latest campaign</p><p>If you’re feeling cynical about the glossification of motherhood, look away now. Featuring Lisa Bonet and her daughter Zoe Kravitz, Calvin Klein’s latest campaign makes the parental bond look as haute and aspirational as a Loewe puzzle handbag.</p><p>It’s clever casting – and not just for the matching cheekbones. Many thirty- and fortysomething fashion fans swooned over Bonet’s oversized blazers and pork pie hats when she played the Cosby Show’s <a href="http://denisehuxtables.tumblr.com/">Denise Huxtable</a> in the 1980s; many twentysomethings are currently in awe of Kravitz. But the best thing about this windswept vision is its ageless view of slightly rebellious, tattooed fashion. Very cool indeed.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/jan/14/lisa-bonet-and-zoe-kravitz-for-calvin-klein-stylewatch">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Michella Obama's State of the Union dress – stylewatch</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/jan/13/michella-obamas-state-of-the-union-dress-stylewatch</link>
      <description><p>What colour was the Narciso Rodriguez outfit? Did it reference the yellow she wore at the 2009 inauguration? Is it the “great goodbye dress”? So many questions</p><p>The meaning of <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/us-news/michelleobama">Michelle Obama</a>’s upper arms is a topic to which we will clearly need to return at length before this presidency is out, but for now let’s talk about the dress. The colour was the prime talking point of the State of the Union address, before designer Narciso Rodriguez confirmed that it is officially “marigold”. (The exact same colour was mustard when J Lo wore it to the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/golden-globes">Golden Globes</a> two days earlier, but go <a href="http://www.etonline.com/awards/goldenglobes/179790_et_picks_the_best_and_worst_dressed_at_the_2016_golden_globes/">figure</a>) The sunniness of the tone was a deliberately upbeat note, chosen as the Obamas begin the final, legacy-minded stretch of their White House tenure. Compare and contrast with <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2015/jan/20/no-tan-suit-state-of-the-union-obama-white-house">last year</a>’s serious, dark-toned skirt suit, which chimed with her husband’s 2015 speech focussing on income inequality.<br></p><p>The dress evoked elements of the first lady’s greatest fashion hits. The inauguration of 2009 is a key reference here. First, the intriguing colour recalled the dress and coat she wore that day, a a paler yellow which sparked a similar naming <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/jan/20/michelle-obama-isabel-toledo-sasha-malia">frenzy</a>. (For the record, some called it citrine, but here at the Guardian we backed lemongrass.) For Obama’s arrival last night, her marigold dress was teamed with a purple coat, a daring colour combination which also harked back to that inauguration, when the first lady wore olive green gloves with her pale yellow coat, and Malia and Sasha wore bright, jewel-toned scarves in contrasting colours. Bright colours for optimism, and surprising combinations for daring: these are central to the Michelle Obama fashion message.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/jan/13/michella-obamas-state-of-the-union-dress-stylewatch">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/fashion">Fashion</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/michelleobama">Michelle Obama</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/lifeandstyle">Life and style</category>
      <pubDate>Wed, 13 Jan 2016 14:59:52 GMT</pubDate>
      <guid>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/jan/13/michella-obamas-state-of-the-union-dress-stylewatch</guid>

        <media:credit scheme="urn:ebu">Photograph: Bao Dandan/Xinhua Press/Corbis</media:credit>

      <media:content width="460" url="https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/0de0ebba353b4c379fc5094f2c990c0624c5c185/0_486_3632_2181/master/3632.jpg?w=460&q=55&auto=format&usm=12&fit=max&s=7dbd600c92b0a28ee309cee47a836535">

    <item>
      <title>Patrick Cox: 'Janet Jackson nicknamed me Party Pat'</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/jan/10/patrick-cox-janet-jackson-nicknamed-me-party-pat</link>
      <description><p>The most famous shoe designer of the 1990s is back, presenting his new brand, Lathbridge, at London Collections Men. He talks about finding stardom through loafers and how to judge a man by his footwear</p><p><strong>You once said that the huge success of the Wannabe loafer in the 1990s was as much about “the zeitgeist, the time, the place, [and] Britpop” as the shoe itself. What happened?<br></strong>When I arrived in England from Canada in the 80s, no one was running around in sneakers – it was a Doc Martens moment, or maybe people were wearing brogues if they were posh. But then dance culture exploded – everyone wanted to go out dancing – and Wannabes worked. They also came to represent a certain way of living, the beginnings of an aspirational lifestyle. Until then, people hadn’t had their noses pressed up against the glass of rich people’s lives as they do today. But that was changing. Wannabe felt like an honest name; to say: “I wish I had £250 for a pair of shoes, but actually I have £80.” Also Madonna called her fans “wannabes” and I was a huge fan at the time.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/jan/10/patrick-cox-janet-jackson-nicknamed-me-party-pat">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>A lesson in space chic: Tim Peake's boilersuit – stylewatch</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/dec/15/tim-peake-boilersuit-space-chic-british-astronaut</link>
      <description><p>Tim Peake might be making history as the first British astronaut to go to space, but let’s not overlook that boilersuit – a little bit Louis Vuitton and <em>very</em> of the moment</p><p>Forget the Christmas onesie – it’s Tim Peake for the fashion all-in-one win this month. The British astronaut may have had little to do with his choice of boilersuit but his chirpy wave says that he knows he’s nailed it on the wardrobe front. Well, that’s the way Stylewatch is interpreting this landmark moment in UK space history anyway. In the spirit of seasonal goodwill, allow us to impose our sartorial agenda on the situation. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/dec/15/tim-peake-boilersuit-space-chic-british-astronaut">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Harry Styles graduates from Ikea chic to Nudie suit – stylewatch</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/dec/14/harry-styles-ikea-chic-nudie-cohn-suit-stylewatch</link>
      <description><p>The One Direction star’s X Factor outfit has drawn yet more comparisons to soft furnishings. Surely the more pertinent reference here is Nudie Cohn, the man who made cowboys love rhinestones</p><p>It’s been a big week for rhinestones: first <a href="https://www.instagram.com/dollyparton/">Dolly Parton joined Instagram</a>, now Harry Styles has taken the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2004/feb/28/popandrock.gramparsons">Nudie Cohn</a> aesthetic to primetime TV, wearing a highly decorative ensemble that would not have looked out of place in <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/gramparsons">Gram Parsons</a>’ wardrobe. </p><p>Styles never seems to be more than five metres away from a piece of elaborate clothing these days, having become so enamoured with <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/feb/25/milan-fashion-week-guccis-smart-revamp-ensures-brains-restore-fawn">new-era Gucci under Alessandro Michele</a> that he is permanently swathed in the brand’s fancy fabric. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/dec/14/harry-styles-ikea-chic-nudie-cohn-suit-stylewatch">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/fashion">Fashion</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/lifeandstyle">Life and style</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/music/harry-styles">Harry Styles</category>

    <item>
      <title>Tom Hardy down-dresses Leonardo DiCaprio – stylewatch</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/dec/07/tom-hardy-down-dresses-leonardo-dicaprio-stylewatch</link>
      <description><p>A lesson in casual accessorising for the alpha male – it’s not often you see a sweatband on the red carpet</p><p>In the age of the hoodie-clad Silicon Valley billionaire, it is not the man in the suit but the man who dares to wear a crumpled T-shirt next to him who is making the power move with his wardrobe.</p><p>Tom Hardy illustrated this point beautifully on Sunday night with <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/dec/02/creasing-up-is-ironing-a-thing-of-the-past">creased</a> jeans, grey trainers and a top from <a href="http://www.rugmanart.com/">Rug Man Art</a>. The T-shirt was illustrated with the face of a man who looked spookily like Hardy himself, genetically spliced with <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/nov/17/billy-gibbons-zz-top-solo-album-perfectamundo-interview">Billy Gibbons</a>. The <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/sep/08/mark-zuckerberg-takes-a-tip-from-the-steve-jobs-school-of-getting-dressed-stylewatch">Mark Zuckerberg prize for dressing-down</a>, however, was clinched with a sweat band worn high on his left arm; its locker-room connotations bravely at odds with the red carpet. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/dec/07/tom-hardy-down-dresses-leonardo-dicaprio-stylewatch">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>JW Anderson on the Star Wars effect on fashion</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/nov/19/jw-anderson-star-wars-effect-fashion</link>
      <description><p>London’s most avant-garde designer on which Star Wars characters are the best-dressed and why the films will be a perennial fashion reference</p><p>There aren’t many fashion designers with whom a conversation about Star Wars would veer from <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Live_%26_Kicking">Live &amp; Kicking</a> to a declaration that “boredom is the new electric”, but Jonathan Anderson has never been one for convention.</p><p>As creative director of his own label, JW Anderson, and <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/sep/03/jw-anderson-loewe-interview">of Spanish luxury brand Loewe</a>, Anderson is one of the most influential forces in contemporary fashion. He is famed for producing designs that may look unsettlingly avant garde at first – think men in blouses and women cloaked in androgynous tunics – but are later widely adopted by the industry. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/nov/19/jw-anderson-star-wars-effect-fashion">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Diddy and Kate Moss: the original fashion/hip-hop couple – stylewatch</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/nov/11/diddy-and-kate-moss-the-original-fashionhip-hop-couple-stylewatch</link>
      <description><p>OK, so they weren’t a couple, but they did do a great shoot for US Vogue in 1999, and now Diddy has reused the shoot for his new mixtape, MMM</p><p>“As I got older, I decided I’m going to make fashion,” explained Diddy, AKA Sean Combs, to the bemused crowd at the launch party for his new mixtape, MMM, before releasing the cover: a shot of himself with Kate Moss from 1999.</p><p>Part of a series shot by Annie Leibovitz, this portrait first appeared in US Vogue in October 1999 in a feature called Puff Takes Paris, in which Puff did indeed take Paris, alongside Jean Paul Gaultier, Karl Lagerfeld, Oscar de la Renta, Alek Wek and John Galliano. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/nov/11/diddy-and-kate-moss-the-original-fashionhip-hop-couple-stylewatch">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Mario Testino: ‘My mother is still a big dresser – she’s 92’</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2015/nov/07/mario-testino-my-mother-is-a-big-dresser-she-is-92</link>
      <description><p>The fashion photographer on growing up in Peru, capturing Princess Diana – and disliking pictures of himself</p><p><strong>I come from a fashion background </strong>rather than photography. My mother is a big dresser and still is – even though she’s 92. And there is a tradition of women dressing well in Peru – parents’ day at school was like a fashion show, so I was used to seeing all these ladies dressed up.</p><p><strong>Dressing is the most basic form of expression</strong> for everybody and anybody. I don’t think it is superficial. Growing up in a conservative society I would try to prove people wrong by wearing flowery suits and stripy terrycloth pants. I’ve always had a positive, colourful energy. I remember liking school because we had three uniforms. To me that was the height of glamour.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2015/nov/07/mario-testino-my-mother-is-a-big-dresser-she-is-92">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Garance Doré  on what makes the French so chic: 'Elegance is refusal'</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/oct/25/garance-dore-french-chic-elegance-refusal</link>
      <description><p>The fashion icon and daughter of immigrants grew up in Corsica and made it to the top of the fashion world. One thing is certain: she’s not going back to France</p><p>Fretting about how to dress when interviewing someone is usually the least of my worries, but today my task is to get fashion legend Garance Doré to talk. And as a fellow French woman, I feel like I have to look my best.</p><p>Doré was described by the New York Times as the “guardian of all style”. She rose to fame thanks to her <a href="http://www.garancedore.fr/en/category/style/street-style/">street style photography</a> and candid blog musings and is now gearing up for the release of her first book, <a href="http://www.garancedore.fr/en/2015/10/20/love-x-style-x-life/">Love Style Life</a>.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/oct/25/garance-dore-french-chic-elegance-refusal">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>How I get ready: Ashley Walters</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/nov/07/how-i-get-ready-ashley-walters</link>
      <description><p>‘I am not in that place yet where I’ve found my own style’</p><p>I don’t go out that much because I&nbsp;have seven kids. So, when I do, it’s a huge event. I have a friend, Mark Haddon, who is a stylist and a brand PR, so a week before I’ve got somewhere to go, we sit among thousands of items of clothing and he will pick something out for me. I’ve never been fashion savvy; I’ve&nbsp;always been&nbsp;dressed and I am not in that place yet where I’ve found my own&nbsp;style.</p><p>When it comes to suits, I’ve got&nbsp;bespoke stuff like Dolce &amp; Gabbana, but mainly they are M&amp;S. When I met my wife, Danielle, she was working for M&amp;S as manager of the suits section. I started buying their suits because I got 25%&nbsp;discount through her, but I&nbsp;really like the fit and they do some&nbsp;good stuff.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/nov/07/how-i-get-ready-ashley-walters">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Mary Portas: 'Things are better for women on the high street today than when we started'</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/oct/28/mary-portas-things-are-better-for-women-on-the-high-street-today-than-when-we-started</link>
      <description><p>Have fashion brands finally stopped ignoring women over 40 and started catering to them as a matter of course? The Queen of Shops argues that the high street is finally embracing ageless style</p><p>It was just a year ago that a major survey claimed that women aged 50-plus felt ignored by the high street, despite the fact that <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/fashion-blog/2014/nov/20/new-research-claims-the-high-street-makes-women-over-50-feel-ignored">90% of British retailers had seen most growth from the over-50s sector</a>. </p><p>Eleven months later and things do seem to have moved on – whether it’s <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/shortcuts/2015/jan/07/joan-didion-and-celine-why-old-age-is-having-a-fashion-moment">Joan Didion becoming the face of Céline</a> or the smattering of brands launching specifically with over-50s – or at least over-40s – in mind. All of which throws up a rather more nuanced question: while older women rage at being overlooked by the high street, do we really want to be specifically marketed to?</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/oct/28/mary-portas-things-are-better-for-women-on-the-high-street-today-than-when-we-started">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Contouring and eyeliner: new cover art for Adele's 25 is revealed</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/oct/22/contouring-and-eyeliner-new-cover-art-for-adeles-25-is-revealed</link>
      <description><p>Adele has revealed the cover for her forthcoming album, 25, and once again has opted for a black and white close crop</p><p>For the cover of her new album, 25, out on 20 November, Adele has done a complete u-turn and gone for a black-and-white close-crop shot (see <a draggable="true" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/21_(Adele_album)">21</a>) that focuses on her face (see <a draggable="true" href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2008/jan/25/popandrock.shopping6">19</a>). An early adopter of the failproof feline flick and contouring combination (see 19 and 21), both are back although – wait – her hair looks a little shorter. According to Man About Town magazine, it was shot by Alasdair McLellan. Given her decision to stay firmly out of the spotlight, she’s a sight for sore eyes so we’ll take what we can get.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/oct/22/contouring-and-eyeliner-new-cover-art-for-adeles-25-is-revealed">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/beauty">Beauty</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/music/adele">Adele</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/music/music">Music</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/fashion">Fashion</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/lifeandstyle">Life and style</category>
      <pubDate>Thu, 22 Oct 2015 16:37:29 GMT</pubDate>

    <item>
      <title>How I get ready: David Gandy</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/oct/03/how-i-get-ready-david-gandy</link>
      <description><p>‘Some people think it is cool to turn up to a big event in a T-shirt but I think that is a little disrespectful’<br></p><p>I know so many people who, when they get ready for an event, spend two days working with their stylist, calling in outfits and having their hair, makeup and everything else done. That makes me laugh. I go the opposite way. The last event I went to, I had 25 minutes to get ready before I was out of the door.</p><p>I don’t do a lot of grooming, though I have to use hair products. I’ve got very thick curly hair and without them I end up looking like an extra from <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2014/jul/15/how-we-made-baby-love-the-supremes" title="">the Supremes</a>. I just had my hair cut off because I was getting fed&nbsp;up with the amount of time it was taking.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/oct/03/how-i-get-ready-david-gandy">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/sep/22/david-beckham-on-his-new-short-movie-im-not-launching-an-acting-career</link>
      <description><p>On Monday night, we hung out with Becks in a bar in London for the premiere of a short film he made for Belstaff. He plays a Clint-Eastwood-style man ‘of few words but many squints’. Here’s what else we learned</p><p>In person, the tattoos on Beckham’s arms are so plentiful, they seem less like bodily adornments and more like under-sleeves to his outfit. Which was otherwise very simple: dark grey T-shirt, black jeans, lush and towering quiff of hair. It worked. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/sep/22/david-beckham-on-his-new-short-movie-im-not-launching-an-acting-career">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Like a storybook character come to life: why the Queen is a style icon</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/shortcuts/2015/sep/09/like-a-storybook-character-come-to-life-why-the-queen-is-a-style-icon</link>
      <description><p>From eggy yellow dresses to pointless handbags, there’s more to dressing like a monarch than meets the eye. Ours avoids chic and makes sure she doesn’t clash with grass. Though she did once sport a polka-dot turban</p><p>Her governess, Marion Crawford, once said of the young queen that “Lilibet never cared a fig” for clothes. And insofar as we can deduce anything about a public but unknowable person, this still feels true. In <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/live/2015/sep/09/queen-elizabeth-ii-longest-reigning-british-monarch-live-updates">63 years</a> of appearances as a monarch, personal vanity has never seemed to take up much bandwidth; what the Queen cares about, instead, is the art and science of being Queen. But she understands perfectly how clothes pay a key role in this. As she once put it: “I have to be seen to be believed.”</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/shortcuts/2015/sep/09/like-a-storybook-character-come-to-life-why-the-queen-is-a-style-icon">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Mark Zuckerberg takes a tip from the Steve Jobs school of getting dressed – stylewatch</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/sep/08/mark-zuckerberg-takes-a-tip-from-the-steve-jobs-school-of-getting-dressed-stylewatch</link>
      <description><p>The Facebook founder claims to be apathetic about fashion but this Vanity Fair cover, photographed by Annie Leibovitz, is a masterclass in personal branding</p><p>Is Mark Zuckerberg seeking to become the Steve Jobs of grey T-shirts? That is to say, just as <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2015/sep/06/steve-jobs-movie-review-michael-fassbender-telluride">black polonecks</a> were a key part of Jobs’s brand, so grey marl has become visual shorthand for the Facebook CEO.</p><p>Zuckerberg has always claimed that his dedication to grey is simply an <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2014/nov/10/obama-zuckerberg-us-president-facebook-founder">Obama-like strategy for minimising daily decisions</a> (“<a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2014/nov/11/five-things-you-need-to-know-about-mark-zuckerbergs-grey-t-shirts">I feel like I’m not doing my job if I spend any of my energy on things that are silly or frivolous</a>,” he has said). </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/sep/08/mark-zuckerberg-takes-a-tip-from-the-steve-jobs-school-of-getting-dressed-stylewatch">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>How I get ready: Craig Revel Horwood</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/sep/05/craig-revel-horwood-how-i-get-ready</link>
      <description><p>‘Give yourself a boost by looking in the mirror and telling yourself you look great’</p><p>If it is an opening night red carpet that starts at 7pm, I will be in the shower at 5pm, followed by a shave and my ironing. I never choose what to wear until the last minute. I pick the suit first, then iron the shirt and then I can decide what tie to wear with it. Everyone says it is easy for men to get ready, but there are so many components – cufflinks, buttonholes, making sure your socks and belt and shoes all match. Women can slip on a black dress and pair of heels, and they’re done.</p><p>Once I am changed, I re-read the invite, make sure my taxi is going to the right place (I’ve got that wrong before) and pare down my man bag to phone, keys, credit card and cash folded up to fit in my inside jacket pocket. I don’t put on my jacket until the last minute, to avoid&nbsp;sweating.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/sep/05/craig-revel-horwood-how-i-get-ready">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Daisy Lowe: I’ve been single for a long time, so I’m not as sexual</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/aug/22/daisy-lowe-ive-been-single-for-a-long-time-so-im-not-as-sexual-as-id-like-to-be</link>
      <description><p>The 26-year-old model talks about childhood, ambitions, body image – and her mum’s famous friends</p><p><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/culture/marianne-faithfull" title=""><strong>Marianne Faithfull</strong></a><strong> came to my 11th birthday</strong> party. I was like: “Who’s that woman?” My mum [fashion designer Pearl Lowe] said I’d understand one day.</p><p><strong>The maternal side of my family</strong> has always been creative. My great-grandmother was in one of the first girl bands, in the 1920s. Their outfits were mental: velvet bloomers with big ribbons and headpieces. They were brilliant.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/aug/22/daisy-lowe-ive-been-single-for-a-long-time-so-im-not-as-sexual-as-id-like-to-be">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Carine Roitfeld on how to nail French style</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/jul/30/carine-roitfeld-on-how-to-nail-french-style</link>
      <description><p>The former editor of French Vogue on why she hates trainers, obsesses over underwear and thinks diamonds are the trend of the season</p><p><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/carine-roitfeld ">Carine Roitfeld</a> is the founder of CR Fashion book, former editor of French Vogue, has collaborated with Tom Ford and is the latest addition to the <a href="http://mytheresa.com/">mytheresa.com</a> Women gang that includes <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/apr/15/brooke-shields-the-80s-ck-star-on-her-modelling-comeback">Brooke Shields</a> and Alexa Chung. As such, she knows a thing or two about insouciant, sexy French style: it’s all pencil skirts, heels and a whole lot of eyeliner. Here, she talks about her wardrobe staples, how diamonds make her feel and what she would never wear.</p><p><strong>When I like something I repeat buy it. </strong>I know I am going to wear the pieces a lot. So, high heels – I have a lot of black stilettos, different heel heights – skirts, some tight sweaters and tights, because I love tights. It’s almost like a uniform. My favourite colour is definitely black and I love to mix it with khaki.<br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/jul/30/carine-roitfeld-on-how-to-nail-french-style">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Jane Birkin handbags Hermès – but can she get her name back?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/shortcuts/2015/jul/29/jane-birkin-handbags-hermes-but-can-she-get-her-name-back</link>
      <description><p>The 1960s chanteuse wants to ‘debaptise’ the Birkin Croco bag, while an increasing number of celebrities are trademarking their names, lest fashion houses beat them to it</p><p>Like all truly desirable designer handbags, the Hermès Birkin comes not only with a dust bag and a certificate of authenticity but with a creation myth.</p><p>In 1981, the legend goes, Jane Birkin was on a flight from Paris to London when the contents of her handbag spilled over the aisle. The man sitting next to her commented that she could do with a tote with pockets. He happened to be the CEO of Hermès – such things can occur in first class – and the pair <a href="http://fashion.telegraph.co.uk/article/TMG9126955/How-Janes-Birkin-bag-idea-took-off.html">started brainstorming ideas on the back of a sick bag</a>.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/shortcuts/2015/jul/29/jane-birkin-handbags-hermes-but-can-she-get-her-name-back">Continue reading...</a></description>
