    <item>
      <title>Helen Mirren at 70: fashion gifts from a grande dame</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/jul/22/helen-mirren-70-fashion-gifts-grande-dame</link>
      <description><p>Her 70th birthday is just around the corner, but the celebrated actor shows no signs of slowing down, shutting up or becoming invisible. We salute her fearless approach to fashion</p><p>How brilliant is Helen Mirren? Allow me to count the ways. Take the fact she thinks sexism and ageism in Hollywood is “fucking outrageous” and will say so often to whoever is listening. And the fact that, at 70 years old this Saturday, she isn’t planning to retire any time soon, having gone successfully from stage to screen and back again in a career spanning almost 50 years. Later this year, she’ll be appearing as 1940s gossip columnist Hedda Hopper in the film Trumbo and intelligence officer Colonel Katherine Powell in the military thriller Eye in the Sky. The winner of one Tony, four Baftas, four Emmys and an Oscar, the feisty, London-born actress is a trailblazing force to be reckoned with and has no intention of slowing down, shutting up or becoming invisible. Dare to mess with Mirren and <a draggable="true" href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2013/may/06/helen-mirren-queen-drummers">risk an expletive-ridden audience with the Queen</a>. She has also been a long-time style crush of mine, and theses are the fashion gifts she has bestowed upon us.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/jul/22/helen-mirren-70-fashion-gifts-grande-dame">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Brigitte Bardot: 'I couldn't wear Lagerfeld while feeding my goats'</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/jul/10/brigitte-bardot-i-couldnt-wear-lagerfeld-while-feeding-my-goats</link>
      <description><p>This week, the Fendi couture show in Paris caused an uproar for its heavy use of fur. Former model and animal rights activist Brigitte Bardot explains why it’s a battle we’re still fighting</p><p>Karl Lagerfeld’s fur-heavy fashion house, Fendi, presented its first haute couture show in Paris on Wednesday evening. Under the banner Haute Fourrure, the house used animal pelts and skins in ever more extravagant ways. Unsurprisingly, animal rights activists gathered outside, the majority of whom came from the <a href="http://www.fondationbrigittebardot.fr/">Brigitte Bardot Foundation</a> . Here the actor explains why she fees so strongly about the fur trade and why she wrote an open letter to Lagerfeld’s pet cat.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/jul/10/brigitte-bardot-i-couldnt-wear-lagerfeld-while-feeding-my-goats">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Caitlyn Jenner in New York – stylewatch</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/jun/29/caitlyn-jenner-new-york-stylewatch</link>
      <description><p data-dropid="0">In her first public appearance since transitioning, Caitlyn Jenner goes for a tried-and-tested kind of glamour</p><p><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/jun/02/caitlyn-jenner-vanity-fair-cover-kim-kardashian-unites-acceptance-transgender-issues">Caitlyn Jenner’s Vanity Fair</a> cover was all va-va-voom glamour but for her first public performance since transitioning. Jenner went for an outfit that was would have been very familiar to viewers of Keeping Up with the Kardashians. Like her stepdaughters, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/kim-kardashian ">Kim</a>, Kourtney and Khloe, Jenner is a fan of low-key but high-maintenance style, a formula of simple clothes and “done” hair and makeup, not quite <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/mar/21/beginners-guide-to-facial-contouring-kim-kardashian">contoured</a> like Kim et al but pretty close. At a bar for gay pride celebrations in New York this weekend, Jenner wore all white: a V-neck T-shirt, belt and broderie anglaise pencil skirt. Nails are manicured, hair is blowdried and skin is glowing. It’s fashionable but discreet, far from look-at-me stuff, even if everyone at the bar where she was would have been doing just that. The takeaway? Jenner is a consummate professional, honed by nearly 10 years being on a reality TV show. This is a Kardashian-Jenner patented look. Expect more when her own series, I am Cait, airs on US TV next month. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/jun/29/caitlyn-jenner-new-york-stylewatch">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Katie Grand at the Fondazione Prada – stylewatch</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/jun/22/katie-grand-fondazione-prada-stylewatch</link>
      <description><p>The stylist and editor-in-chief of Love magazine tips her hat in Milan</p><p>A <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/jun/21/milan-mens-fashion-week ">Prada</a> party is always sure to attract the great and the good. So it came to pass with Sunday night’s cocktail reception at the brand’s new <a href="http://www.fondazioneprada.org/?lang=en">Fondazione</a>, an exhibition space in Milan. Top prize goes to the gallery staff, kitted out in very on-brand, school-style uniforms of grey shirt and black trousers. Katie Grand, the editor-in-chief of Love magazine and <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2013/jul/17/katie-grand-miuccia-prada-fashion">sometime collaborator with Mrs Prada</a>, arguably outshone the rest of the attendees in her layers of black and navy. Some might talk about the platforms, the full skirt with the smidge of turquoise poking out or the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/marc-jacobs">Marc Jacobs</a> T-shirt. But it is actually the hat, hair and beaded necklace that takes this outfit head and shoulders above the rest. This is because it takes a little from Lisa Bonet’s hat wardrobe in <a href="http://www.classictvbeauties.com/lisa_bonet_80s.jpg">A Different World</a>, adds Molly Ringwald’s in <a href="http:// https://s-media-cache-ak0.pinimg.com/736x/07/dc/48/07dc48404b1a041df46a3fc86732ca81.jpg ">Pretty in Pink</a> and streamlines the whole thing by painting it black. The result? Pretty grand. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/jun/22/katie-grand-fondazione-prada-stylewatch">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Princess Anne's 35-year-old Ascot outfit – stylewatch</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/jun/17/princess-annes-35-year-old-ascot-outfit-stylewatch</link>
      <description><p>The Princess Royal’s thrift chic cements her position as the royal family’s true style icon </p><p>The tabloids are frothing with excitement this morning because Princess Anne has re-worn a 35-year-old outfit to Ascot. Obviously, her thrift should be applauded, although the most important thing about this frock coat, in fashion terms, is that it could be from <a href="http://www.style.com/slideshows/fashion-shows/fall-2015-ready-to-wear/loewe/collection/22">Loewe this season</a>. </p><p>As all French Vogue editors know, mustard is the chicest colour and outerwear is everything. As for the high-necked blouse and skinny belt? Styling genius – and <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/feb/25/milan-fashion-week-guccis-smart-revamp-ensures-brains-restore-fawn">totally new-era Gucci, under Alessandro Michele</a>.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/jun/17/princess-annes-35-year-old-ascot-outfit-stylewatch">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Tina Knowles gets regal – stylewatch</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/jun/16/tina-knowles-ebony-cover-beyonce-solange</link>
      <description><p>From now on, let’s refer to the mother of Beyoncé and Solange as Her Majesty<br></p><p>Can we all please bow down to this Ebony magazine cover? From the luxuriant hair to the defiant pose to the silken red dress, there is nothing not regal about this photograph. Tina Knowles has been enjoying a purple patch, style-wise, of late – her wedding was <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/apr/30/getting-married-over-40-fashion-for-the-meringue-averse-bride-wedding-dress">a masterclass in grown-up glamour</a> – so it’s fitting to see her anointed “Queen T”, while wearing a crown. Long may she reign.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/jun/16/tina-knowles-ebony-cover-beyonce-solange">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>The Peaky Blinders shirt – stylewatch</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/fashion-blog/2016/apr/27/the-peaky-blinders-shirt-stylewatch</link>
      <description><p>With its neat-pleats, this is the male version of the Princess Di pie-crust collar</p><p>Although Peaky Blinders (which returns for its third series on 5 May) is set in the 1920s, sartorially speaking, BBC2’s gangland epic could not feel more current if it tried. There is Thomas Selby’s (<a draggable="true" href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/cillian-murphy">Cillian Murphy</a>) three-piece, herringbone suit – very east London hipster having a skinny flat white in an artisan coffee shop – while his haircut (a modernised short back and sides, a TV byword for “psychotic tendencies”, hello <a draggable="true" href="http://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/mr-robot">Mr Robot</a>) feels achingly contemporary. </p><p>But, in the context of 2016 – with Beyonce’s Lemonade, which is peppered with nods to Victoriana; <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/apr/13/the-alexa-effect-behind-the-scenes-at-the-launch-of-archivebyalexa">Alexa Chung’s range for M&amp;S</a>; and the recent death of lace-fan Prince – all eyes are on his bib shirt. With the recent passing of certified lace fan Prince, Beyonce’s Lemonade, which is peppered with nods to Victoriana and Alexa Chung’s range for M&amp;S, the shirt is nothing less than the male version of Princess Diana’s pie-crust collar. Worn without a tie but with the top button done up, it’s smart alternative to the shirt-and-tie, the neat-pleat effect providing an ornate counterpoint to the stiffness of the colour. A smart and stylish look, with a soupcon of Patrick Bateman-like menace.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/fashion-blog/2016/apr/27/the-peaky-blinders-shirt-stylewatch">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/fashion">Fashion</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/mens-fashion">Men's fashion</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/film/cillian-murphy">Cillian Murphy</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/peaky-blinders">Peaky Blinders</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/tv-and-radio">Television & radio</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/lifeandstyle">Life and style</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/culture/culture">Culture</category>
      <pubDate>Wed, 27 Apr 2016 13:02:06 GMT</pubDate>
      <guid>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/fashion-blog/2016/apr/27/the-peaky-blinders-shirt-stylewatch</guid>
      <media:content width="140" url="https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/d8d5cfdcda41e4d4409e6d5d14e09d6e858ca987/0_126_1770_1062/1770.jpg?w=140&q=55&auto=format&usm=12&fit=max&s=ee011fc550b48144508f28ce5c9e25fd">

    <item>
      <title>Erdem Moralioğlu: ‘I’ve always been fascinated by the way women look’</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/apr/16/erdem-moralioglu</link>
      <description><p>The fashion designer, aged 38, on being an immigrant, body size and his own ‘incredibly boring’ wardrobe</p><p><strong>I’ve always been fascinated by the way women look. </strong>As a young boy, I drew pictures of women – never men. I had a teacher in first grade who would wear long skirts and I could sometimes catch a glimpse of her slips poking out of the bottom of them. I was intrigued by the way women walked, how they sat, the secrets they might have. I’m sure you could have a Freudian field day with that.</p><p><strong>My parents met in Geneva. </strong>My dad was Turkish, my mother was from Birmingham and they ended up settling in Montreal, so I grew up visiting grandmothers in foreign countries. I remember thinking they couldn’t be further apart culturally, except they both drank tea: one from a mug and one from a glass with sugar cubes on the side. Tea was a universal grandmother thing.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/apr/16/erdem-moralioglu">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Stylewatch: Kimmy Schmidt's jumper</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/apr/14/stylewatch-kimmy-schmidts-jumper</link>
      <description><p>Part Orla Kiely preppy, part Gucci, Season two is all about the spicy mustard top.</p><p>Kimmy Schmidt, if you think about it, has a lot in common with Buddy the Elf. Judging by the trailer for the second series of Unbreakable…, the commonalities are about to increase: Kimmy appears to get a job as an elf in a year-round Christmas store. But now is not the time to think about how millennial fictional characters are perfect for each other. Now is the time to think about jumpers. Kimmy demonstrated her power with a cheery knit in the first series of this <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/mar/09/how-dress-spring-kimmy-schmidt ">Tina Fey-penned sitcom </a>and they appear to be just as strong this time around. The yellow knit here is a nose-runningly spicy mustard yellow, and the herringbone pattern is part Orla Kiely preppy, part new <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/gucci">Gucci</a> retro. If her penchant for wearing a handbag cross body is yet to be ironed out by Titus et al, Kimmy is leading in knits. That much is unbreakable. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/apr/14/stylewatch-kimmy-schmidts-jumper">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Buy of the Day: Whistles x Move Your Frame tracksuit</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/apr/11/buy-of-the-day-whistles-x-move-your-frame-tracksuit</link>
      <description><p>Whistles have launched their second sportswear collaboration with Frame: leisurewear you can also wear to the shops</p><p>Available from <a href="http://www.whistles.com/">Whistles</a></p><p>If <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/apr/01/beyonce-stamps-her-unmistakable-brand-on-sportswear-fashion">Beyoncé</a> has effectively reworked workout gear with Ivy Park, the second Whistles x <a href="https://moveyourframe.com">Move Your Frame</a> collaboration is a quieter – but no less desirable – take on clothes that function just as well in the yoga studio as they do outside it. Working directly with the exercise studio, the collection includes leggings, jumpsuits and do-anything-in clothes. Case in point: this grey marl tracksuit, which has a bit of normcore chic about it, some zeitgeisty cool (<a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/mar/25/take-the-money-and-run-the-rise-of-the-1000-tracksuit">see Vetements and Chloe tracksuits</a>) and a lot of “I’ve had my green juice, 12 hours sleep, done my sun salutations. What’s next?” We like that look even if, in reality, all we’ve actually done is got up at 12 and proceeded to watch back-to-back episodes of <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/gallery/2016/jan/28/the-good-wife-seven-years-of-power-dressing-gallery">The Good Wife</a>. Whichever camp you fall into, you’re #winning wearing this.</p><p><em><a href="http://www.whistles.com/women/whistles-x-frame/luxe-jogger-22464.html?dwvar_luxe-jogger-22464_color=Grey%20Marl#start=1">Luxe jogger £115</a>, luxe hoodie £125.</em></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/apr/11/buy-of-the-day-whistles-x-move-your-frame-tracksuit">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Q&A: Heidi Klum, model – ‘When did I last cry? Three days ago, when my makeup artist poked me in the eye’</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/apr/02/heidi-klum-q-and-a-interview</link>
      <description><p>The book that changed my life? The German-to-English dictionary </p><p>Born in Germany, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2015/aug/18/heidi-klum-donald-trump-video">Heidi Klum</a>, 42, has been a model since the age of 19. She is the Emmy award-winning host of <a href="http://www.bravotv.com/project-runway">Project Runway</a>, a judge on <a href="http://www.nbc.com/americas-got-talent">America’s Got Talent</a> while her business empire includes the lingerie range <a href="https://www.heidiklumintimates.com/">Heidi Klum Intimates</a>. She is divorced from <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2010/sep/16/seal-interview-pop">the singer Seal</a>, has four children, dates the art dealer <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vito_Schnabel">Vito Schnabel</a> and lives in Los Angeles.</p><p><strong>When were you happiest?</strong><br>The first time I saw each of my four children’s faces.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/apr/02/heidi-klum-q-and-a-interview">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Do the write thing: why fashion has a fetish for stationery</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/sep/07/stationery-fashion-fetish-style-morley</link>
      <description><p>Fashion has embraced technology but it still loves a pencil. And a posh notebook, a sharpie and embossed notecards. Inspired by Tom Ford and her school filofax, Jess Cartner-Morley on her stationery obsession</p><p>It began, as character-defining crushes so often do, on French exchange. I was 13, immersed in Frenchness for the first time, and it was fabulous. First because each morning for breakfast we were given a bowl of hot chocolate and a stack of creamy, scallop-edged biscuits to dip into it. But also because of the stationery. I fell madly, deeply in love with the school exercise books, which were A5-sized, sewn-spined, the pages chequered with a faint quadrille. So elegant, so precise, so chic. WHSmith’s spiral-bound lined notebooks were dead to me from that day onward, and a lifelong love affair was born.</p><p>Stationery is more emotional than fashion, notebooks and diaries more intimate than your knicker drawer. I can measure out my life in paper, from those flimsy notebooks to the ludicrously expensive Smythson ones I use now. My teenage diaries are even now redolent with the pointless intensity of childhood secrets. The Filofax and Mont Blanc fountain pen I had as a sixth former are unthrowable still, despite or perhaps because of the painfully earnest copied-out quotes and in-jokes scrawled in the margins. I have a treasured folder filled with notepaper from every swanky hotel I have ever stayed in: the <a href="https://www.roccofortehotels.com/hotels-and-resorts/hotel-savoy/">Savoy</a> in Florence, with its tiny terracotta duomo motif; <a href="http://www.claridges.co.uk/">Claridge’s</a>, where we stayed on my husband’s 40th. And I have the giveaway organisational safety harnesses of every overwrought modern professional. (Current obsession: the <a href="https://www.leuchtturm1917.com/notebooks-diaries/accessories/pen-loops/">Leuchtturm 1917 pencil loops</a>, fixed in the back of every notebook and diary to save precious seconds on endlessly updating my to-do lists.)</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/sep/07/stationery-fashion-fetish-style-morley">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/stationery">Stationery</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/fashion">Fashion</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/lifeandstyle">Life and style</category>
      <pubDate>Mon, 07 Sep 2015 06:01:09 GMT</pubDate>

    <item>
      <title>In the frame: how I learned to love glasses</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/sep/05/glasses-fashion-wiseman</link>
      <description><p>After a childhood seen through grubby fingerprints, Eva Wiseman mastered contact lenses and never looked back. Now – with specs all over the red carpet and the catwalk – she’s wearing glasses by choice</p><p>It was 1990 and I couldn’t choose which colour frames to have, so I had them all. All the colours. A pair of very large, very round, very rainbowed spectacles, through which nine-year-old me saw a world that, perhaps inevitably, was mainly laughing and pointing. Shame on my mother for giving me the power to decide my own fate, but shame on me for letting them stain the way I’d feel about glasses for the rest of my life. Until now.</p><p>My favourite bit of fashion is when something you’ve overlooked for years suddenly sidles into view, all fresh and gleaming and covetable. This season, just as I was beginning seriously to contemplate laser eye surgery, it’s spectacles. The Gucci catwalks were particularly fabulous – androgynous, eccentric, romantic – and almost half of the looks were accessorised with glasses. Big round ones, sassy cat’s eye ones, clunky fat ones. MaxMara’s models were similarly bespectacled, while Prada and Chanel’s new eyewear campaigns (<a href="http://stylenews.peoplestylewatch.com/2015/04/07/kristen-stewart-in-ads-for-chanel-eyewear/">Kristen Stewart as an androgynous photographer</a>, her hair like a fallen Elvis) make glasses look impossibly sexy.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/sep/05/glasses-fashion-wiseman">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>JW Anderson: ‘The minute your brand can be predicted, you’ve got a problem’</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/sep/03/jw-anderson-loewe-interview</link>
      <description><p>Loewe designer and head of his own label, Anderson has bold ambitions and a fierce competitive instinct forged during his youth in 1990s Northern Ireland. Here he talks alter egos, gender fluidity and Instagram</p><p>Because I am a little early, and in true Paris fashion week tradition the morning’s schedule is already running a little late, I spend the first half hour of my visit to <a href="http://www.loewe.com/eu_en/?countrynl=GB&amp;gclid=CPaf1emKxsYCFSTmwgodtBwDHw">Loewe</a>’s Parisian headquarters in the basement kitchen. This being Paris fashion week, however, this is a little better than it sounds: long, scrubbed, pale wood benches and a table piled with bowls of kumquats and slivers of lemon cake on a white platter. Fuchsia peonies in a glass urn are so artfully overblown that, when no one is looking, I stroke a petal to check they are real. (They are.) A charming French PR chats to me about how much she loves living in Dalston. A pair of male models, in dressing gowns and with alligator clips flattening their hair ready for the artless dirty-hair-don’t-­care look they will sport at the collection presentation later, spend 10 painstaking minutes trying to figure out the espresso machine; eventually, generous in triumph, they pass tiny paper cups of coffee around the room.</p><p><br>From the ground floor, the building blooms into grandeur: a double sweeping staircase, parquet floor, polished curlicue railings. Loewe occupies the lowest four floors of the building; someone confides, as we walk upstairs, that the sixth floor houses <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/catherinedeneuve">Catherine Deneuve</a>’s apartment. On the first floor, <a href="http://www.lvmh.com/">LVMH</a> executives in elegant black suits are drinking more espressos, up here borne aloft by waiters with silver trays. We climb another level, past photographer’s assistants gaffer-taping lighting cabling to the floor and makeup artists powdering more boys, to the office of <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/gallery/2014/sep/26/jonathan-jw-anderson-debut-loewe-paris-fashion-week">Jonathan Anderson</a>, the 30-year-old designer from The Loup, County Derry, on whose talent LVMH is gambling the Loewe brand, the man at whose whim the parquet has been painted wenge-dark and the models’ hair creased flat.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/sep/03/jw-anderson-loewe-interview">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/lifeandstyle">Life and style</category>

    <item>
      <title>Men in blouses, boys in brocade: the return of rock star androgyny</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/sep/04/androgyny-menswear-rock-gucci</link>
      <description><p>This season’s menswear designers are inspired by icons who challenged preconceptions of masculinity – think Bolan in a boa or Kurt Cobain in a dress</p><p><strong> <br></strong>Forty-six years ago, in July 1969, the<strong> </strong>Rolling Stones took to the stage for <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/global/from-the-archive-blog/2011/jul/07/from-the-archive-rolling-stones-brian-jones-1969">a concert in Hyde Park</a>. It was two days after the death of guitarist Brian Jones and thousands of young fans flocked to see them. The gig was dedicated to Jones, and Mick Jagger read from <a href="http://www.poetryfoundation.org/poem/174379">Andonais</a>, a poem Shelley wrote about the loss of his friend John Keats. What did Jagger, arguably then the figurehead of youth culture, wear for this poignant moment? <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/news/2014/jul/06/mick-jagger-brian-jones-hyde-park-observer-archive">A white, frilled dress</a> with a pie crust collar covered with bows.</p><p>Ever since <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/elvispresley">Elvis</a> wore eyeliner, men in rock have enjoyed a bit of dressing up and challenging the cultural idea of masculinity. Some of the most iconic men in pop – <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/davidbowie">David Bowie</a>, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/musicblog/2012/apr/10/marc-bolan-t-rex-interview">Marc Bolan</a>, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/jimi-hendrix">Jimi Hendrix</a> – ruled rock’s airwaves done up to the nines in frilled blouses, glitter makeup, brocade, high heels and feather boas. They even had their own designers – Bowie worked with <a href="http://dandyinaspic.blogspot.co.uk/2011/07/mr-fish.html">Michael Fish</a>, creator of what became known n as “the man dress” and the designer of Jagger’s 1969 number. The subversiveness of all this only added to their allure, their air of transgression and all-round swagger.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/sep/04/androgyny-menswear-rock-gucci">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>The fashion checklist: pastels, blue steel, capes and sci-fi</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/sep/07/fashion-trends-autumn-winter-2015</link>
      <description><p>Black is back and so is rich velvet. But will you be inspired by Star Wars, Margot Tenebaum or Zoolander this season? Here are 10 microtrends to set the tone for autumn/winter 2015</p><p><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/movie/91078/royal.tenenbaums"><strong>Margot Tenenbaum</strong></a><strong> <br></strong>The certain muse of <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/fashion-blog/2015/jan/21/-sp-gucci-names-accessories-chief-alessandro-michele-as-creative-director">Alessandro Michele</a>’s Gucci collection. Furry dressing gowns, clips, gloves and all.</p><p><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/movie/90417/zoolander"><strong>Zoolander</strong></a> <br>The<a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/mar/10/zoolander-returns-ben-stiller-and-luke-wilson-bring-blue-steel-to-paris-fashion-week"> Valentino womenswear show</a> featured a walk-off from <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/benstiller">Ben Stiller</a> and <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/owenwilson">Owen Wilson</a>, reminding us that we have just five months to work on our own Blue Steel.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/sep/07/fashion-trends-autumn-winter-2015">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>London calling: Gareth Pugh on why there's no place like home</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/sep/06/gareth-pugh-london-return-show</link>
      <description><p>The British designer brought his show back to London this season after five years in Paris. Here he writes about his love for the capital, from his Peckham art squat days to hustling like Del Boy</p><p>My first fashion show ran on Mars bars and sleep deprivation. Ten years ago, I was selected last minute to take part in <a href="http://www.fashioneast.co.uk/about.asp">Fashion East</a> which meant I had four weeks to create a collection from nothing: I had no fabric, no team, no idea of what I wanted to do. I never imagined I’d be creating my first show under those constraints, but of course I couldn’t say no. In the end it was an amazing experience, making it through the chaos and producing something I could be proud of.</p><p>At the time, my studio was a disused gym in a squat in Peckham, part of the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2009/apr/12/artists-collectives-squats">!WOWOW! collective</a>. It was a huge building incorporating an old tile warehouse, a nightclub, a theatre, an evangelical baptist church and my studio in the gym, which I’ve been told used to belong to <a href="http://www.gladiatorszone.co.uk/gladiators/male/wolf/">Wolf from Gladiators</a>. The only place warm enough to sleep was the sunbed. The whole enterprise was scrappy and optimistic; feral and lawless. I still work with people I met in those early days, such as Matthew Stone, who does my music, and Katie Shillingford, who styles my shows. They are people I can be open and honest with, without fear of judgment. We know each other too well to have to be polite.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/sep/06/gareth-pugh-london-return-show">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Final cuts: my obsession with film star hair</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/sep/06/hair-obsession-fashion-chilvers</link>
      <description><p>From Renton’s buzzcut in Trainspotting to Robert Pattinson’s giant bouffe in Twilight, one hair fetishist untangles this season’s looks for men</p><p>Sometimes if I’m having a bad day, I Google Image <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/river-phoenix">River Phoenix</a> and study his hair. It’s like therapy and momentarily sends my brain somewhere better. This obsession is partly to do with the film My Own Private Idaho and its beautiful portrayal of youthful confusion and unrequited love. But it is also because Phoenix’s hair was at its absolute peak of amazing. Big and beautifully dishevelled, in many ways it was the embodiment of his character. Essentially, hair mis-en-scene.</p><p>Over the years, it is not just River’s up-top tangle that has reeled me in. Hair obsessing stretches from my own, which grows fast and outward, often resembling a giant mushroom. But also to (very) specific catwalks (the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/gallery/2011/jun/28/paris-mens-fashion-week">Raf Simons wet-look partings from spring/summer 2012</a> are an all-time high), via a roster of celebrities. This briefly manifested itself as a Tumblr starring the likes of actors <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/culture/ben-whishaw">Ben Whishaw</a>, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/jake-gyllenhaal">Jake Gyllenhaal</a> and <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/andrew-garfield">Andrew Garfield</a>, the artist <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/basquiat">Jean-Michel Basquiat</a> and <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/strokes">the Strokes</a> singer <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2014/oct/09/30-minutes-with-julian-casablancas-voidz-strokes-interview">Julian Casablancas</a>. I even barraged my late boyfriend (himself a man of much hair prowess) to file relevant images in a specifically labelled HAIR folder on my computer desktop.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/sep/06/hair-obsession-fashion-chilvers">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Fashion Insta-heroes: six snapshots to sum up the new season</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/gallery/2015/sep/02/fashion-insta-heroes-six-snapshots-autumn-winter-2015</link>
      <description><p>From Dior Homme’s floral badges to Chanel slingbacks, six of our favourite accessories to inspire you this season </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/gallery/2015/sep/02/fashion-insta-heroes-six-snapshots-autumn-winter-2015">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/fashion">Fashion</category>

    <item>
      <title>Horti-couture: how fashion fell for florals</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/sep/02/flowers-plants-fashion-accessories</link>
      <description><p>Florals have a language all their own. From LBD-esque dark orchids to statement peonies, here’s our guide to harnessing your flower power</p><p>There are small but crucial differences between fashion and the real world. Here’s one: in fashion, flowers for the kitchen table are not something that you buy on impulse from the stall by the station as an it’s-Friday treat. They are as much of a style statement – and as trend-driven – as your handbag, or your shoes, or the car you drive, or the restaurant you book for your birthday party. They must be carefully considered and finely calibrated to enhance your personal brand.</p><p>The coolest trend in flowers over the past few years hasn’t, confusingly, involved flowers at all. Greenery is what greets you when you walk into <a href="https://www.celine.com/en/celine-stores/europe/united-kingdom/london/mount-street">Céline’s Mount Street store</a>. The vogue for palm leaves can be traced back to Céline’s ad campaign for autumn/winter 2011; their cult status was confirmed in 2012 when House of Hackney launched its now-classic <a href="http://www.houseofhackney.com/collections/palmeral.html">Palmeral print</a>. A cheeseplant or succulent on your mid-century sideboard is pure minimalist cool, the lack of pretty petals chiming nicely with your on-trend androgynous wardrobe.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/sep/02/flowers-plants-fashion-accessories">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <pubDate>Wed, 02 Sep 2015 12:13:09 GMT</pubDate>

        <media:credit scheme="urn:ebu">Photograph: /Teri Pengilley for The Guardian</media:credit>
        <media:description>A cheeseplant or a succulent on your mid-century sideboard is pure minimalist cool Photograph: Teri Pengilley for The Guardian</media:description>
      </media:content>
      <media:content width="460" url="https://i.guim.co.uk/img/static/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2015/7/10/1436546632746/cheeseplant-and-print-009.jpg?w=460&q=55&auto=format&usm=12&fit=max&s=1780331f591c4b28d52a0793b22951d4">

    <item>
      <title>Fashion duos: 'I believe that I have the better taste. I think she would say the same'</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/sep/02/fashion-partners-duos-public-school-loquet-hayford</link>
      <description><p>In fashion, can two heads be better than one? Four duos talk frankly about how they make business, friendship and family work without wanting to kill each other </p><p>Public School are Maxwell Osborne and Dao-Yi Chow. Both native New Yorkers, they met in 2003 when Chow, a former journalist, was marketing director of Sean John and Osborne was an intern. They launched their own label in 2007; since then their minimal, mainly monochrome streetwear with a high fashion twist has been a retail hit and won them several fashion industry awards, including <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/fashion-blog/2015/jan/09/public-school-nyc-wins-international-woolmark-prize">the first International Woolmark prize for menswear</a> this year. The pair are based in New York’s garment district and as well as running <a href="http://publicschoolnyc.com/">Public School</a>, they were recently appointed <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/apr/29/is-menswear-the-new-route-to-the-top-jobs-in-fashion">creative directors of DKNY</a>.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/sep/02/fashion-partners-duos-public-school-loquet-hayford">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>From bedroom to catwalk: new star Amie Robertson earns her stripes</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/feb/20/aime-robertson-marc-jacobs-london-fashion-week</link>
      <description>Marc Jacobs protege leads rush of fresh talent as annual shows kick off<p>The news that fashion has anointed a new designer as a star can be signposted in various ways. For Amie Robertson, who debuted her label <a href="http://www.avrobertson.com/about.html" title="">AV Robertson</a> at <a href="http://www.londonfashionweek.co.uk" title="">London Fashion Week</a> on Saturday morning, the evidence came in the form of front-row guest Marc Jacobs, who had flown in from New York, and a coterie of superstar models including <a href="http://www.vogue.co.uk/news/2016/02/01/edie-campbell-british-vogue-cover-march-2016" title=""><em>Vogue</em>’s March cover star, Edie Campbell</a>, celebrity offspring Georgia Jagger, and Lineisy Montero, currently in the Chanel campaign.</p><p>For a fledgling label, still designed from a bedroom in Robertson’s parents’ house in Manchester, these signals were enough to make the assembled guests at the Tate Britain show sit up and take notice. The show notes crediting Katie Grand also ensured that they paid attention. Grand, who is editor-in-chief of <em>Love</em> magazine, has styled for Prada and works with Jacobs. Her endorsement of an unknown like Robertson is a Big Deal. It turns out that the Central Saint Martins fashion illustration BA graduate met Grand when she completed a year’s internship in 2014 at Marc Jacobs in New York.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/feb/20/aime-robertson-marc-jacobs-london-fashion-week">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Fashion to go: from the London catwalk shows straight into the shops</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/feb/19/london-fashion-week-catwalk-shows-insta-gratification</link>
      <description><p>Top designers follow Burberry’s lead and make ‘Insta-gratification’ the hottest new trend as London fashion week opens</p><p>Beetroot juice on tap, cropped frayed jeans in the front row and frilled blouses on the catwalk at J. JS Lee’s opening show. So far, so familiar for London fashion week, which began on Friday morning with a Soho car park as its headquarters.</p><p>But the newest trend at London fashion week is one coming from within the industry in what might be called “Insta-gratification” – the ability to buy the clothes seen on the runway immediately. The biannual event is due to be transformed from September, when Burberry will show a “see-now, buy-now” collection, doing away with the up to six month wait between the show and the clothes appearing in the shops. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/feb/19/london-fashion-week-catwalk-shows-insta-gratification">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Karl Lagerfeld takes Chanel on a nature trail in Paris</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/jan/26/karl-lagerfeld-takes-chanel-nature-trail-paris</link>
      <description><p>Designer’s chic spring collection was presented on an eco-themed runway complete with blue sky and trees in full leaf </p><p>At Chanel, the show starts long before the clothes appear. Karl Lagerfeld’s overture began a few days ahead of this collection with the show tickets: simple slabs of eco-friendly plywood looking nothing like haute couture’s traditional beribboned and gold-embossed invitations. </p><p>Once inside the Grand Palais on the day of the show, guests found themselves transported from the leaden skies and frenetic streets of Paris to a blissed-out, spa-like stage set, with a painted blue sky lit by floodlights and a backdrop of trees in full leaf. A minimalist pavilion in slatted wood sat in the centre of a lawn edged by paths picked out in yet more pale wood. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/jan/26/karl-lagerfeld-takes-chanel-nature-trail-paris">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/chanel">Chanel</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/karl-lagerfeld">Karl Lagerfeld</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/fashion-weeks">Fashion weeks</category>

    <item>
      <title>Rags and riches: John Galliano’s Martin Margiela collection</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/jan/27/rags-and-riches-john-gallianos-martin-margiela-collection</link>
      <description><p>At this Paris catwalk show, the philosophy of Maison Margiela was clear: to unpick fashion rather than use it to brandish wealth</p><p>In the light of Oxfam’s recent report that <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/jan/18/richest-62-billionaires-wealthy-half-world-population-combined">62 individuals own as much of the world’s wealth as the poorer half</a> of the global population, the Paris haute couture collections hawking six-figure cocktail dresses embellished with gold leaf or mink trim make a twisted kind of economic sense.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/jan/27/capes-tights-style-lessons-couture-2016-paris">From the joy of capes to the great tights uprising: seven style lessons from couture</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/jan/27/rags-and-riches-john-gallianos-martin-margiela-collection">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Directorless Dior proves it does not do turmoil in classic haute couture show</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/jan/25/designerless-christian-dior-raf-simons-turmoil-haute-couture-paris</link>
      <description><p>Three months after Raf Simons’ departure, show at Musée Rodin evokes Dior’s eternal muse: the spontaneous, relaxed Parisienne</p><p>The house of Christian Dior is in turmoil. The unexpected departure of <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/oct/22/raf-simons-to-leave-as-creative-director-at-dior">Raf Simons</a> three months ago has left it without a designer, the design studio plunged against its will into an interregnum period, stirring up unhappy memories of the anxious year that followed <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/jul/08/john-galliano-margiela-show-silk-men-rustic-haute-couture">John Galliano’s scandalous exit</a> in 2011. </p><p>Responsibility for this haute couture collection, and for the ready-to-wear collection that will be presented in a month’s time, rest for now on the shoulders of the design team – a thankless task, as the audience out front gossip endlessly about which star designer is about to sign a contract.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/jan/25/designerless-christian-dior-raf-simons-turmoil-haute-couture-paris">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Donatella Versace opens Paris fashion week with sporty couture</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/jan/24/donatella-versace-haute-couture-at-paris-fashion-week</link>
      <description><p>A collection which taps into ‘ath-evening’ and shows a designer tapped into reality and current trends </p><p>On Sunday night Donatella Versace, a pocket-rocket of a designer from Milan, opened the haute couture shows in Paris with a collection that was both modern and rooted in reality. Well, at least as much rooted in reality as it is possible to be when talking about evening dresses costing more than £10,000.</p><p>Her collection was named “Athletic Couture” and featured dresses with ergonomic lines which traced the models’ curves, harness straps and white ski pants and matching zip tops highlighted with orange go-faster stripes all of which could loosely be termed sporty. Before the show the designer said: “I was thinking about women at their most focused and dynamic … women who push themselves to the limit.”</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/jan/24/donatella-versace-haute-couture-at-paris-fashion-week">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Armani Privé: lilac blooms on Giorgio's couture catwalk</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/jan/27/armani-prive-lilac-blooms-on-giorgios-couture-catwalk</link>
      <description><p>Mauve, violet and lavender set the tone for Armani Privé’s Paris collection, with standout moments from two Oscar dress contenders</p><p>Even the 12th richest man in the global fashion industry dresses up for Paris haute couture. As the models emerged on to the mirrored Armani Privé catwalk, the man himself could be seen half-hidden behind the curtains dressed in a black suit, crisp white shirt and black tie, giving the final nod to each model as they stepped out. It was a much more formal look than the navy T-shirt which is <a draggable="true" href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/fashion-blog/2014/jul/10/giorgio-armani-80-eight-facts-fashion-designer">Giorgio Armani’s trademark look</a> on show day in Milan.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/jan/27/armani-prive-lilac-blooms-on-giorgios-couture-catwalk">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Milan fashion week: back to basics for Gucci's Alessandro Michele</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/jan/18/milan-fashion-week-back-to-basics-for-guccis-alessandro-michele</link>
      <description><p>The Italian giant’s new creative director set the agenda in 2015 – does he do it again with a (slightly) pared-back new collection?</p><p>This time last year, even the most devoted fashion insider might have responded with a blank stare at any mention of the name Alessandro Michele – but what a difference a year makes. <br></p><p>Michele is now the creative director at Gucci. He dresses Harry Styles and Alexa Chung, produces feted advertising campaigns with peacocks as accessories, and won best international designer at the British fashion awards last year. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/jan/18/milan-fashion-week-back-to-basics-for-guccis-alessandro-michele">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Maison Margiela menswear is a chip off the eastern bloc</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/jan/22/maison-margiela-menswear-paris-is-chip-off-eastern-bloc</link>
      <description><p>The label’s men’s catwalk in Paris showed the influence of new eastern European designers but without the excitement</p><p>To some, the menswear catwalks are the poor relations to their female equivalents – a trouser-heavy prologue to the haute couture shows that begin in Paris on Sunday. But those people have not been paying attention. Right now, menswear in the French capital is having a burst of creative energy.</p><p>Both on and off the catwalk, a look is emerging from the Paris autumn/winter 2016 menswear shows. It isn’t a trend as such, more a long-term shift in the way men who care about clothes are dressing, which blurs the lines between smart and casual. It is a haphazard, almost accidental way of dressing – padded coats over smart trousers, giant trapper hats worn with tailored pieces, tracksuit bottoms worn too high at the waist with long wool overcoats and a beanie hat. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/jan/22/maison-margiela-menswear-paris-is-chip-off-eastern-bloc">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Burberry nods to Bowie in menswear show – and reclaims camel-checked past</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/jan/11/burberry-nods-bowie-menswear-show-reclaims-camel-checked-past</link>
      <description><p>Singer’s enduring influence on fashion world clear to see as British brand brings London Collections Men to a close</p><ul><li><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/jan/11/he-had-an-instinct-for-elegance-david-bowies-fashion-legacy">‘He had an instinct for elegance’: David Bowie’s fashion legacy</a></li></ul><p>How strange it was that the final day of Britain’s twice-yearly celebration of men’s fashion, London Collections Men, fell on the morning that we learned of <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/jan/11/david-bowie-dies-at-the-age-of-69">David Bowie’s death</a>.</p><p>Monday’s hot ticket, the Burberry show, was full of flamboyant dressers who idolised the musician, such as fashion editors who danced to Ziggy Stardust at the Blitz Club as teenagers and stylists whose first experiments with crimson hair dye and silver nail varnish were inspired by him.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/jan/11/burberry-nods-bowie-menswear-show-reclaims-camel-checked-past">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Edgy, sporty and with a hint of soul: why luxury ‘ladwear’ is king of the catwalk</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/jan/09/ladwear-king-of-the-catwalk-london-collections-men</link>
      <description>The hyper-casual look featuring haute couture hoodies, now embraced by many rappers, is going mainstream<p>A louche khaki chenille tracksuit paired with elbow-length “oven mittens” summed up the prevailing mood in menswear on Saturday. It was both business as usual for haute streetwear designer Astrid Andersen and proof that “ladwear” is usurping tailoring and eccentricity in the race for dominance of British men’s fashion.</p><p>For the past few seasons, there has been a growing divide between two clear camps: peacock and hyper-casual. One is effeminate, an imaginative take on the Brummellian dandy; think last autumn’s leopard print at Topman Design or printed shirts at Burberry. The other is streetwear and its various sub-styles – tracksuits, longline sweaters and textured hoodies. It’s a look Danish designer Andersen has made her trademark for the past four seasons. But only now is it coming out on top, as the weekend’s <a href="http://www.londoncollections.co.uk/" title="">London Collections Men event </a>has demonstrated.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/jan/09/ladwear-king-of-the-catwalk-london-collections-men">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/mens-fashion">Men's fashion</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/mens-sportswear">Men's sportswear</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/fashion">Fashion</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/lifeandstyle">Life and style</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/business/jd-sports">JD Sports Fashion</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/business/retail">Retail industry</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/business/business">Business</category>
      <pubDate>Sat, 09 Jan 2016 22:10:35 GMT</pubDate>

    <item>
      <title>From the backbenches to the front row – our Westminster sketchwriter goes to men’s fashion week</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/jan/12/from-the-backbenches-to-the-front-row-what-would-our-sketchwriter-john-crace-make-of-mens-fashion-week</link>
      <description><p>He was told off for looking at the models not the clothes, and got dirty looks for opening the freebies. What did he think of the string thongs at London Collections Men?<br></p><p>“It’s all about the new Gucci, isn’t it?” Since I don’t have a clue what the old Gucci is, I decide to keep my mouth shut. <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/fashion-blog/gallery/2015/jan/13/-sp-david-gandy-watch-london-collections-men">Top male model David Gandy</a> does not have the luxury of silence. As an ambassador – Our Man in Dolce &amp; Gabbana – for the clunkily named London Collections Men, the bloke’s equivalent of London fashion week, he’s obliged to answer any question that comes along. A foreign TV crew stick a microphone in front of him and ask his considered opinion on the effects of weather on men’s fashion shopping patterns. David mumbles something along the lines that all weather patterns can be good for shopping and the TV crew leave happy.</p><p>Then the concrete basement darkens and Gandy takes his seat alongside some other eye candy bussed in for the benefit of the fashion writers strategically placed on the front row opposite them. I’m later told that <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/jul/20/nick-jonas-review-islington-academy-jonas-brothers-dreamboy-aims-to-please-as-solo-act">Nick Jonas</a> and <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2012/apr/09/chloe-green-shoe-collection">Chloe Green</a> were there, although I’m not sure which was which. Or who they are. But this is the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/jan/08/topman-design-rocks-on-with-catwalk-show-of-flamboyant-menswear">Topman</a> show, the LCM big-buck opener, so they must be important.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/jan/12/from-the-backbenches-to-the-front-row-what-would-our-sketchwriter-john-crace-make-of-mens-fashion-week">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>Designer’s gender-fluid approach in evidence in autumn/winter collection, shown as part of London Collections: Men</p><p>He’s the first to win both womenswear and menswear designer of the year at the British fashion awards, and has a reputation for the unexpected. </p><p>JW Anderson’s autumn/winter 2016 collection, shown on Sunday morning as part of London Collections: Men, did not disappoint on that score, with a live-streaming of the show on gay dating app Grindr.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/jan/10/jw-anderson-mixes-mundane-and-strange-in-fashion-show-streamed-on-grindr">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Star Wars or slacker? Six key trends from London Collections Men 2016</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/fashion-blog/2016/jan/12/star-wars-or-slacker-six-key-trends-from-london-collections-men-2016</link>
      <description>Overlong sleeves, desert warrior outfits and looking like Bruce Springsteen are all in store for fashionable men next season<p>Forget trading-floor rules such as the cuff of your shirt hitting an inch beyond your wristbone. Next season is far more slacker than that. Pulling your sleeves over your hands like <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/shortcuts/2015/nov/09/kurt-cobain-cardigan-nirvana-auction">Kurt Cobain</a> in Seattle is a tic to cultivate. Wrists are to be covered at all times. See the sweaters at <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/jan/08/topman-design-rocks-on-with-catwalk-show-of-flamboyant-menswear">Topman</a> and Agi &amp; Sam, and pyjama tops at JW Anderson.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/fashion-blog/2016/jan/12/star-wars-or-slacker-six-key-trends-from-london-collections-men-2016">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>The geek v the extrovert: Milan's fashion face-off</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/sep/29/geek-v-extrovert-milan-fashion-week-ss216-catwalks</link>
      <description><p>Sensible shoes, specs and skirt suits competed with nightclub styling, 80s glitz and show-off frocks in Milan. But which look was better?</p><p>News just in from Milan fashion week: the pouting sexpot who has ruled the Italian catwalks since the middle ages – it has felt that long, anyway – has been usurped by a girl in glasses with hair tucked behind her ears. One in sensible shoes who looks like she might be wearing a vest under her frock.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/sep/29/geek-v-extrovert-milan-fashion-week-ss216-catwalks">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Louis Vuitton's Nicolas Ghesquière brings digital punk to Paris catwalk</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/oct/07/louis-vuitton-nicolas-ghesquiere-digital-punk-paris-fashion-week-catwalk</link>
      <description><p>Show at Frank Gehry-designed gallery, featuring models resembling wild creatures from Mad Max, sees fashion house marry high art with big commerce</p><p>To witness the pinnacle of fashion today – in terms of both commercial might and creative endeavour – it doesn’t get much better than the Louis Vuitton show that has taken place in Paris.</p><p>According to the fashion house’s creative director, Nicolas Ghesquière, this collection was about “the frontier of the digital world” – a theme that enabled him to dress models in <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/may/07/louis-vuitton-turns-catwalk-into-a-spaceship-as-fashion-goes-intergalactic">shimmering space-age creations</a> while flagging up the brand’s heritage as a purveyor of very posh luggage. “It’s another way of travelling at the end of the day,” he said, “this digital travelling that we are all experiencing.”</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/oct/07/louis-vuitton-nicolas-ghesquiere-digital-punk-paris-fashion-week-catwalk">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Thoroughly modern Stella McCartney muses over real women</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/oct/05/thoroughly-modern-stella-mccartney-muses-over-real-women-paris-fashion-week</link>
      <description><p>The idea of the artist and their muse influenced the designer’s Paris fashion week show, but her interpretation was firmly rooted in real life</p><p>How to turn highbrow inspiration into no-brainer, instantly desirable clothes? Put it in the hands of Stella McCartney. The British designer, who showed her spring/summer 2016 collection in Paris on Monday morning, , described her collection as being influenced by the idea of an artist and their muse. But forget interpretations of Picasso’s portraits of <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/culture/2003/may/24/art">Dora Maar</a>, or <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2004/aug/21/art.fashion">Rossetti’s of Lizzie Siddal</a>, McCartney is a designer that lives very much in the real world and her clothes were about modern life – appealing with or without the art references. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/oct/05/thoroughly-modern-stella-mccartney-muses-over-real-women-paris-fashion-week">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Westwood Gold Label collection inspired by sinking Venice, apparently</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/oct/04/vivienne-westwood-collection-inspired-by-sinking-venice</link>
      <description>Designer put the city centre stage at Paris fashion week in her Mirror The World show<p>There aren’t many designers who can find inspiration in a campaign to save Venice from the effects of climate change but Vivienne Westwood is unique.</p><p>The show for her Gold Label collection, at Paris fashion week on Saturday, was called Mirror The World, and saw the designer put the city – slowly sinking into its surrounding lagoon – centre stage on the Paris catwalk. A pre-show <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?t=9&amp;v=n4XQagtzi2c" title="">film on her blog</a> saw Westwood speak of Venice as an “emporium of culture”, citing painters Titian and Bellini, and the city’s carnival, as inspiration.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/oct/04/vivienne-westwood-collection-inspired-by-sinking-venice">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <pubDate>Sat, 03 Oct 2015 23:58:00 GMT</pubDate>
      <guid>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/oct/04/vivienne-westwood-collection-inspired-by-sinking-venice</guid>
      <media:content width="140" url="https://i.guim.co.uk/img/static/sys-images/Travel/Late_offers/pictures/2015/10/4/1443916604823/British-designer-Vivienne-009.jpg?w=140&q=55&auto=format&usm=12&fit=max&s=42bc2f3335fd2f76a8b9aadcfe4b7561">
        <media:credit scheme="urn:ebu">Photograph: Benoit Tessier/REUTERS</media:credit>
        <media:description>Vivienne Westwood with her husband, Andreas Kronthaler, at the end of her spring/summer 2016 show in Paris. Photograph: Benoit Tessier/REUTERS</media:description>
      </media:content>

    <item>
      <title>Paris fashion week: Céline’s art collaboration is a natural fit</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/oct/04/paris-fashion-week-celines-art-collaboration-is-a-natural-fit</link>
      <description><p>Influential label eschews fashion circus and commissions Danish artist Thomas Poulsen, aka FOS, to create a catwalk space for its strong spring/summer show</p><p>With selfies, Snapchat previews and screaming crowds craning for a view of Kendall Jenner’s bottom, fashion shows in 2015 can feel like wannabe stadium rock concerts. What catwalk events do not often feel like are prologues to the Frieze art fair. Unless, of course the brand is question is the hugely influential Céline.</p><p>For her spring/summer show on Sunday, the label’s creative director, Phoebe Philo, commissioned the Danish artist Thomas Poulsen, who works under the name FOS, to create the catwalk space. Guests carrying invitations with dollops of poured resin puddled over them walked into a venue divided by large sheets of ripstop nylon in orange, blue and yellow hanging from the ceiling rigging. The soundtrack, which came without a melody, had been conceived by Philo and FOS and “reflected a mechanical energy, sound and rhythm to create an immersive feeling”, said the brand. With Céline clothes also the de facto uniform of the female gallerists, the arty credentials were stacked tall.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/oct/04/paris-fashion-week-celines-art-collaboration-is-a-natural-fit">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>The face (and hairstyle) that’s turning heads on the Paris catwalk</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/oct/04/afro-returns-to-catwalk-paris-fashion</link>
      <description>Lineisy Montero is not the only black face on the catwalk but it is her hairstyle which sets her apart in contrast to the longer tresses of other models<p>Paris fashion week is in full swing, with one face emerging to define the spring/summer of 2016. Lineisy Montero, the 19-year-old model from the Dominican Republic, has walked in all the most significant shows this season, from Balmain to Balenciaga. She is being hailed as an example that the catwalk, which is traditionally dominated by thin, blonde white models, is finally embracing diversity.</p><p>Montero has featured in more than 50 shows since mid-September, and is instantly recognisable for her short afro. While she can be seen as part of a wider rise of black faces on the catwalk – ranging from Binx Walton and Joan Smalls to Malaika Firth and Jourdan Dunn – it is this hairstyle, in contrast to the longer tresses of these other models, that sets her apart. In March, Montero’s debut on the Prada catwalk – her first runway show – saw a social media storm, and brought the afro, so associated with 1970s Black Panthers and civil rights activists such as Angela Davis, back into the fashion conversation. There are now several other models with afros, including Karly Loyce. Montero, however, remains the poster girl for natural afro hair in fashion, with her popularity this Paris fashion week a case in point.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/oct/04/afro-returns-to-catwalk-paris-fashion">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>What we learned from London Fashion Week</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/oct/04/what-we-learned-from-london-fashion-week</link>
      <description><p>From the revival of big sleeves and old cardies to dressing in parrot green and keeping it personal, here are the 10 lessons from this year’s shows</p><p>Oxfam is still the starting point for great fashion. We know designers use it to find inspiration for their collections. But during <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/london-fashion-week-autumn-winter-2015">London Fashion Week</a>, for one day only, stylist Emma Slade Edmondson reinterpreted what she saw on the fashion show live streams for <a href="http://www.charityfashionlive.com/">Charity Fashion Live</a>. She used the Oxfam shop in Dalston as her base and watched the live streams of the shows for that day, including Jasper Conran, Sibling London and Holly Fulton (right), and scoured the rails to find ways to recreate the looks. Photographer Rachel Manns shot the results on a mini catwalk in store.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/oct/04/what-we-learned-from-london-fashion-week">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Balmain goes back to 1980s with ruffles, jumpsuits – and an Instagram preview</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/oct/01/balmain-back-to-1980s-ruffles-jumpsuits-instagram-preview</link>
      <description><p>Designer’s spring/summer catwalk has nostalgic flavour of 80s Paris club wear, but its brand-building is bang up to date</p><p>You can debut your spring collection the old-fashioned way, in the gilt-and-frescoed salon of a grand hotel next to the Paris Opera with a select few hundred of the fashion establishment in attendance. </p><p>Or you can debut it on social media, giving <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/jun/30/kendall-jenner-instagram-photo-most-liked-history">Kendall Jenner</a> and Gigi Hadid dresses from the new collection to wear to a party the night before the show, and letting Jenner post a close-up photo of the two supermodels’ bottoms – one in open-weave cobweb knit dress, one in a semi-sheer jumpsuit – to her 37.7 million Instagram followers. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/oct/01/balmain-back-to-1980s-ruffles-jumpsuits-instagram-preview">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Galliano's rehabilitation continues with high-spirited glamour</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/sep/30/gallianos-rehabilitation-maison-margiela-glamour-van-noten</link>
      <description><p>Show for Maison Margiela recalled gleeful days of old while Dries van Noten’s gaudy elegance edged a real-life comfort zone</p><p>The 11am catwalk show in the Tuileries on Wednesday was, in theory, a display of next spring’s ready-to-wear womenswear collection for the Parisian house of Margiela. In reality, the entwined stories of John Galliano and Paris fashion long ago moved beyond such mere technicalities. </p><p>Ready-to-wear womenswear is, anyway, a term that could be only very loosely applied to skirts wrapped in clingfilm, jackets made from sofa stuffing, and fishnet bodystockings; especially when many of the models on the catwalk are men.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/sep/30/gallianos-rehabilitation-maison-margiela-glamour-van-noten">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Armani's Milan fashion week show is more about power than clothes</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/sep/28/armani-milan-fashion-week-spring-summer-women-2016</link>
      <description><p>The 81-year-old ‘godfather of fashion’ ignored the whims of the industry when presenting his spring/summer 2016 collection </p><p>Attending a Giorgio Armani show is not about spotting next season’s trends – it’s about seeing what power looks like.<br></p><p>The shows are held in the company’s <em tabindex="-1">teatro</em> in Milan, an architectural ode to elegance and restraint, all monolithic pillars and concrete walls. The catwalk is accessed through 12ft openings cut into the grey stone. As the collection is presented, the audience will occasionally burst into spontaneous applause.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/sep/28/armani-milan-fashion-week-spring-summer-women-2016">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/sep/27/dolce-gabbana-shares-the-amore-in-milan-with-jolly-50s-italy-collection</link>
      <description><p>Italian designers play to international customers with clothings and bags that celebrate picture-postcard view of Italy for label’s spring/summer collection</p><p>Here’s an announcement no scruffy fashion journalist wants to see at the beginning of a catwalk show: “The models in this show will be taking selfies with you. Be part of this special fashion moment.”</p><p>So read signs displayed at the presentation of Dolce &amp; Gabbana’s spring/summer 2016 presentation in Milan on Sunday. Thankfully, what transpired was not members of the crowd being forcibly snapped with the world’s most photogenic women, but the models taking photographs of themselves as they walked down the runway, a conceit that proved to be just one jolly part of a very jolly show. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/sep/27/dolce-gabbana-shares-the-amore-in-milan-with-jolly-50s-italy-collection">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>Fashion house pairs melancholic designs with striking accessories as design director Fabio Zambernardi runs the show</p><p>At most Milan fashion week shows, the philosophy behind a sheer skirt is the desire to show a bit of leg, but things are different at Prada. The sheer organza layers were “about the idea of a dress, or the memory of a dress as a memory of another time”, Fabio Zambernardi, Prada’s design director, said backstage. </p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/may/17/miuccia-prada-i-hate-the-idea-of-being-a-collector">Miuccia Prada: I hate the idea of being a collector. I really hate it</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/sep/24/prada-memories-milan-fashion-week-womens-spring-summer-2016">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Versace stops the traffic in Milan with a twist on camouflage</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/sep/25/versace-stops-the-traffic-in-milan-with-a-twist-on-camouflage</link>
      <description><p>Donatella Versace mixes camouflage with leopard-print swirls and mines military garb and shades of khaki for the label’s spring/summer collection</p><p>Donatella Versace may live a life dedicated to glamour and excess but she is still a creature of habit. Every season, she presents her fashion shows in the glossy, purpose-built theatre within Versace’s neoclassical palazzo on Via Gesú in Milan – until Friday night, that is, when the designer decamped to a cavernous, concrete space towards the outskirts of the city.</p><p>Speaking before the presentation, she explained: “To show [at Versace headquarters] feels very safe and I do not want always to be safe.” </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/sep/25/versace-stops-the-traffic-in-milan-with-a-twist-on-camouflage">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>New-look Gucci is talk of the town as Milan’s catwalk gets a makeover</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/sep/26/gucc-milan-fashion-week-new</link>
      <description><p>Italian fashion has a reputation for being somewhat staid and conservative, but this year it’s taking a walk on the wild side</p><p>The fashion industry thrives on the new, on, say, the awkwardly cut trouser that look a bit weird at first, until eventually the eye adjusts. Spotting trends early on is how many people earn their crust – from the retailers who invest in products months before they go on sale to the stylists who coax clients into that challenging Perspex tabard before anyone else. Perhaps this thirst for novelty is why some fashion buyers and editors seem to be stifling a yawn, from time to time, at most Milan fashion weeks.</p><p>Every fashion capital has its cliches. New York is best-known as a financial powerhouse; Paris is the home of fabled couture brands like Chanel and Dior; London is the wacky, creative little sister. Fashion is so essentially a part of Milan’s identity that upon landing at Linate airport, the first thing visitors see is a hangar sponsored by Emporio Armani. But leaving aside Prada, which has always been quirky and intellectual, Milan is often praised for its heritage and quality, while being accused of promoting a tired, <em>molto sexy</em> view of femininity, and of being a little staid.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/sep/26/gucc-milan-fashion-week-new">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Emporio Armani at Milan fashion week: 40 years of 'a determined form of grace'</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/sep/25/emporio-armani-at-milan-fashion-week-40-years-of-a-determined-form-of-grace</link>
      <description><p>Giorgio Armani continues to reveal his penchant for designs based on an ‘observation of everyday reality’</p><p>The show notes at the Emporio Armani catwalk show in Milan defined the look of this collection as “a subtle yet determined form of grace”. A phrase which applies not just to these clothes, but to the brand Giorgio Armani, 81, has spent the past 40 years building. </p><p>The first look of the show was a grey trouser suit. One, of course, with the precisely calibrated slouch that has made the Armani suit an icon of urbane sophistication since Richard Gere wore one in American Gigolo. This being the more youthful and relaxed – read, cheaper – of the two Armani catwalk shows in Milan fashion week, the suit was worn with a pink T-shirt with a smiley face emoticon. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/sep/25/emporio-armani-at-milan-fashion-week-40-years-of-a-determined-form-of-grace">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>London fashion week: Burberry and Christopher Kane look to the stars</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/sep/21/london-fashion-week-burberry-christopher-kane</link>
      <description><p>Christopher Bailey’s show took Burberry street while celebrities looked on, and Kane made light of a dark period in his life </p><p>When your catwalk show is prefaced by Benedict Cumberbatch kissing his hellos with Sienna Miller and Kate Moss before waving to Anna Wintour across the 32-piece orchestra warming up in the middle of the catwalk, and Cara Delevingne is holding hands with girlfriend St Vincent on the front row as Alison Moyet stands up to sing, it is fair to say your brand is riding pretty high in the status stakes.<br></p><p>At which point, it is perhaps possible to relax a little. In the 14 years he has been at Burberry, Christopher Bailey has elevated the brand out of all recognition, from dodgy checks to A-list chic. He has done so by aligning Burberry with high-taste reference points, from Lucian Freud and the St Ives painters to vintage books and the Bloomsbury group.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/sep/21/london-fashion-week-burberry-christopher-kane">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Meet the nodels: fashion beyond skinny models</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/sep/21/nodels-fashion-skinny-models-catwalk-people-clothes</link>
      <description><p>The new trend in catwalk casting proves that people matter more than clothes</p><p>Haters, form an orderly queue. I probably shouldn’t say this out loud, because it’s not as if you lot don’t have enough anti-fashion ammunition anyway, but I’m going to. This is the 15th year I’ve been going to fashion shows, and for much of that time I barely noticed how thin or how young the models were. I know, I know. I’m a bad person.</p><p>I watched shows and came out thinking and talking about the zip placement or the music or the front-row scene, and did you notice such-and-such must have had a falling out with so-and-so because they usually sit together, and only later discovered that the show had hit the headlines because one of the “girls” was generally felt to be shockingly skinny, or was 13 years old. Sometimes this felt like a deliberate missing of the point, because you wouldn’t find a footballer’s new haircut on the back page of a newspaper where the match report would be. But it turns out it was me who was missing the point. I was looking so hard at the clothes that I didn’t&nbsp;see the people in them.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/sep/21/nodels-fashion-skinny-models-catwalk-people-clothes">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Louis Vuitton in Paris: regenerating athleisure</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/mar/09/louis-vuitton-makes-sportswear-looks-like-a-winner-paris-fashion-week</link>
      <description><p>The mighty luxury house’s Paris show aimed to reflect ‘the way women dress’ - and, remarkably, succeeded</p><p>In fashion, the art of making a look your own, rather than the wholesale adoption of the latest trend, is what distinguishes someone with style. </p><p>On the final day of Paris fashion week, Louis Vuitton gave a masterclass in making a hugely familiar trend – sportswear - its very own.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/mar/09/louis-vuitton-makes-sportswear-looks-like-a-winner-paris-fashion-week">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/fashion">Fashion</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/lifeandstyle">Life and style</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/fashion-weeks">Fashion weeks</category>
