    <item>
      <title>Stylewatch: Willow Smith at Chanel's Paris show</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/mar/09/stylewatch-willow-smith-at-chanels-paris-show</link>
      <description><p>Chanel’s new ambassador looks like a superhero – and is just what the fashion label needs</p><p>In the context of the tweedy, mannered vibe of Chanel’s <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/mar/08/chanel-in-paris-lagerfeld-revisits-coco-fashion-week">Paris show</a>, singer Willow Smith’s appearance on the Frow was a stylistic U-turn. She was a vision of futuristic nowness: pierced septum, robed cape, electric-blue Egyptian eyeliner and a catsuit that, if civilian space programmes did fashion lines, would work nicely in Nasa’s collection for next season. She basically looked like a badass superhero. The announcement that the 15-year-old daughter of Will Smith would be the <a href="https://www.instagram.com/p/BCsmYzJPNjU/?hl=en">new ambassador</a> for the fashion house seemed like a cheeky, Largerfeld-like nod to the old maxim of “out with the old, in with the new, babes”.</p><p>It also made total sense. Like her brother <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/culture/2016/jan/05/jaden-smith-skirt-gender-stereotypes-louis-vuitton-ad">Jaden</a>, she has been nothing but fashion forward since she <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ymKLymvwD2U">whipped her hair </a>back and forth at the tender age of nine. Experimenting with pastel-pink and platinum hair colours and shades of eye shadows in aubergine, she has lived out a life under the spotlight like a refined aesthete. Instead of scandalising the web with her TMZ-ish exploits, she has done her teen metamorphosis thing with a subtle grace, expressing herself via her <a href="https://www.instagram.com/gweelos/">Instagram</a>: a thing of beauty that, frankly, should be in the running to win the Turner prize.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/mar/09/stylewatch-willow-smith-at-chanels-paris-show">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Eight key trends from Paris: silk scarves, studenty velvets and flashy pleats</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/mar/08/eight-trends-paris-silk-scarves-studenty-velvets-flashy-pleats-fashion-week-trench-coats</link>
      <description>Paris fashion week featured weird trench coats, crooked hems and quilted biker jackets. And there was an up-all-night party-girl vibe thrown in for good measure<p>There’s something a bit rakish, a bit Quentin Crisp about a silk scarf. Though Crisp may have not been in mind <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/mar/03/chloe-shows-us-a-post-girly-world">at Chloé</a>, where the inspiration was Anne-France Dautheville, an adventurer who travelled across Europe on a motorbike in the 70s. Carine Roitfeld, spotted front row in a black one accessorised with a leopard-print coat and huge sunglasses, was a different matter. She totally gets the Crisp reference we reckon.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/mar/08/eight-trends-paris-silk-scarves-studenty-velvets-flashy-pleats-fashion-week-trench-coats">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Easy Riders, anoraks and patchworked jeans – the rise of post-chic Paris fashion</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/mar/08/easy-riders-anoraks-patchworked-jeans-post-chic-paris-fashion-instagrammed-catwalk-kanye-west</link>
      <description><p>The most Instagrammed piece on the catwalk this week is a green Balenciaga anorak, while, in the front row, Kanye West is the new Catherine Deneuve. How did Paris get so hard-edged?</p><p>All you really need to know, to get your head around Paris fashion week, is this: the most lusted-after, Instagram-liked piece on the catwalk this week was an anorak. At Balenciaga, new designer Demna Gvasalia’s vision for the most ultra-chic, super-refined Paris label was distilled in an <a href="http://www.businessoffashion.com/fashion-week/2016aw/balenciaga/collection/look/9">oversized anorak in a garish green-and-blue colour combination</a> which was a long, long way from the pale greys of Avenue Montaigne or the matt black of the Boulevard Saint Germain. And the audience loved it.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/mar/08/eight-trends-paris-silk-scarves-studenty-velvets-flashy-pleats-fashion-week-trench-coats">Eight key trends from Paris: silk scarves, studenty velvets and flashy pleats</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/mar/08/easy-riders-anoraks-patchworked-jeans-post-chic-paris-fashion-instagrammed-catwalk-kanye-west">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>The flowering of men's underwear - fashion archive, July 1973</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/may/03/men-underwear-fashion-1973</link>
      <description><p><strong>24 July 1973</strong>: The counters of men’s underwear departments are a blaze of colours and patterns such as briefs, shorts, and see-through slips</p><p><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2016/apr/13/underwear-goes-on-show-at-the-victoria-and-albert-museum">Underwear goes on show at the Victoria and Albert Museum</a><br></p><p>There was a time when the things a man wore under his outer clothing were white, shapeless, and woolly. Their sole purpose was to keep him warm. They were unseen and therefore their appearance was subordinate to their practical application.<br></p><p>Things have changed. The formerly blanched counters of the underwear departments are a blaze of colours and patterns. Mundane nouns like combs and underpants have given way to briefs, shorts, and, yes, slips – French slips, mini-slips, and see-through slips. A slip is apparently not something nice ladies wear any more, it is a handful of nylon cut into the smallest bikini that a man’s anatomy will allow and stretched round his hips like a “G” string. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/may/03/men-underwear-fashion-1973">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Shop mannequins to be more lifelike - fashion archive, 17 April 1970</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/apr/21/mannequins-lifelike-shops-1970-archive</link>
      <description><p><strong>17 April 1970: </strong> A note in the factory says, ‘All mannequins to have painted nipples from now on’</p><p>One of the stories in “Dr Who” earlier this year ended with the scene of dozens of tailor’s dummies smashing their way through plate glass windows and shooting down the populace: the dummies had come to life.</p><p>It was a dramatic scene full of sinister possibilities and, in a curious way, prophetic of what is actually happening. For although (one hopes) it will be many, many years before dummies take the law into their own hands, they are becoming increasingly lifelike and, because of this, are exerting an influence on fashion as never before.<br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/apr/21/mannequins-lifelike-shops-1970-archive">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>The relaunch of Levi's 501 jeans: fashion archive, April 1986</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/apr/14/levi-jeans-501-relaunch-1986</link>
      <description><p><strong>10 April 1986</strong>: The advertising campaign for the five-pocket Levi Strauss denim jean has been a barnstorming success - and not only for Levi</p><p>Yeee-ha! Make way for the return of ripped-up, rough-tough, bad-guy gen-u-ine one hundred per cent original Levi’s! You’ve seen the commercials, you’ve hummed the tune, you’ve bought the record, you’ve run the retailers right out of stock of those cool, classic, red-tab 501s ...<br></p><p>The relaunch of the good old five-pocket Levi Strauss denim jean (Pedigree: San Franciso 1850, poor man’s workwear) has been such a barnstorming success that it’s even taken the parent company by surprise. Not to mention the nice lucrative spin-offs that have unexpectedly lined other people’s pockets, given a dead pop star a mammoth hit and turned a male model into a proto-celebrity.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/apr/14/levi-jeans-501-relaunch-1986">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>This summer has a lean and belted look: fashion archive, 4 April 1979</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/apr/07/lean-belt-look-women-fashion-archive-1979</link>
      <description><p><strong>4 April 1979: </strong>Sleek heads, slim sandals and silky fabrics that skim the hem are forecast for this season<br></p><p>Nothing riles a reader quite so effectively as the fashion editor who announces: “This season you can’t survive without a diamante breastplate/striped leg-warmers/hob-nailed boots.” So I’ll phrase it this way: This spring you are going to want an elegant frock. <br></p><p>I don’t mean one of those I - lost - my - innocence - in - a munitions - factory numbers in the harshest of bright colours. Their spots, stripes and garish prints will be jostling one another on the rails, padded shoulders to the fore. Starved of sunshine, warmth and colour after the drearily prolonged winter, you may be tempted to succumb to their superficial allure. My advice is to resist if you can, and to invest some time in tracking down something a little more subtle, a little ladylike, a little less throwaway.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/apr/07/lean-belt-look-women-fashion-archive-1979">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>A plain woman’s guide to nylon for her husband: fashion archive, 1958</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/mar/28/nylon-menswear-wives-husbands-feminism-1958-archive</link>
      <description><p><strong>28 March 1958: </strong>What wives need to know about the latest advances in men’s clothing</p><p>Looking round a small exhibition of nylon used for men’s wear (arranged by British Nylon Spinners, Ltd., at their Manchester office) I began to wonder why so few men of my acquaintance wear nylon shirts. These were the answers I provided for myself: (a) that someone told them, in nylon’s early days, that after much washing nylon takes on, irrevocably and irremovably, a dingy yellowish tinge; (b) that they associate nylon with the silkiness and, worse, the transparency of women’s lingerie; (c) that they want an immaculately smooth, if not starched, shirt front, and suspect nylon of being sloppy; (d) that they just do not like the idea of wet shirts dripping all over the bathroom.<br></p><p>Some of the objections are already outdated, others are on the way to being so. Nylon, as every woman knows, has now countless surface guises. It need by no means be either silky, shiny, or sloppy. It can be firm enough for a pique finish dress shirt. It can be as fluffy as angora wool, or it can have the warm, smooth touch of, say, winceyette or delaine. The shirtings which this wife would expect her husband to approve have the appearance of poplins, with pin stripes of blue, grey, red, or green. They are not shiny or silky, and they have a nice “body.” Shirtings line-checked in bright colours on cream look attractive for cold days.<br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/mar/28/nylon-menswear-wives-husbands-feminism-1958-archive">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Balenciaga dies: fashion archive, 20 March 1972</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/mar/17/balenciaga-cristobal-dies-archive-1972</link>
      <description><p><strong>The Observer, 20 March 1972: </strong>The Spanish fashion designer was accused of putting women in ‘sacks’</p><p>Cristobal Balenciaga, the Spanish fashion designer, who died in Spain last week at the age of 77, was recognised as the supreme master of style in dressing women.</p><p>Mr Hardy Amies in a recent interview said that it was Balenciaga who killed off English couture: when he introduced ‘his revolutionary soft-cut suits’ he made the English strictly tailored look outdated.<br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/mar/17/balenciaga-cristobal-dies-archive-1972">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>My clothes and I - the sixties schoolgirl: fashion archive 13 Mar 1960</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/mar/10/teenagers-style-clothes-body-image-1960-archive</link>
      <description><p><strong>The Observer, 13 March 1960: </strong>Painful shoes, shared fitting rooms and all the self-consciousness of the typical teenager</p><p>Nicolette is sixteen. She doesn’t much like being thought of as a schoolgirl but supposes, with characteristic directness, that she cannot be called anything else.</p><p>Her face is full with a pointed chin, a very snub nose, small slanting eyes and far fewer spots than she is conscious of. Sometimes it looks like a baby’s and sometimes almost middle-aged with care, but it is still basically and appealingly the face of a child. Her hair is brownish, springy and vaguely shoulder length with a ragged fringe over some of her forehead.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/mar/10/teenagers-style-clothes-body-image-1960-archive">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Poncho raincoat offer: fashion archive, 29 February 1976</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/mar/03/poncho-raincoats-observer-1976-archive</link>
      <description><p><strong>The Observer, 29 February 1976</strong>: Halfway between a cape and a raincoat, Observer readers can buy this spring fashion garment for the marvellous price of £13.85</p><p>One of the nicest shapes around this year is the poncho raincoat. Halfway between a cape and a raincoat, it has a lovely, swirly shape and being lightweight and loose can be worn over innumerable layers.<br></p><p>As our spring fashion offer we have just such a coat, exclusive to OBSERVER readers. Apart from the shirt-tail shape, it has a hood, large patch pockets, and double buttons at the side to give the sleeve shape. It is in 65 per cent polyester/35 per cent cotton, with a colour choice of stone or deep charcoal (almost black). The hood lining and trim are in a brushed fabric - a camel/brown/ orange/green check - which is 40 per cent acrylic/30 per cent wool/30 per cent other fibres. The coat should be dry cleaned.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/mar/03/poncho-raincoats-observer-1976-archive">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Music hall and mannequins: fashion turns in London, 27 February 1923</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/feb/27/catwalk-show-london-theatre-1923</link>
      <description><p><strong>27 February 1923: </strong>Designers bring a fashion parade to the stage at the London Palladium, with the occasional song and dance thrown in</p><p>Few women have the effrontery to walk into the most exclusive and expensive “maisons” of Hanover Square or Rue Royale with the knowledge that they cannot afford anything more than “ideas” from the models that are being displayed. A mannequin parade which forms a “turn” at a variety theatre is, therefore, likely to be popular. One may examine the dresses with care, take note of the latest “line,” the newest trimming and coming colour with the comfortable thought that one has paid for the seat and earned the right to copy, if one can, anything that is being shown.</p><p>The difficulty with the 1923 fashions at the Palladium in London is that it is such an ambitious affair that one is left merely bewildered. It is arranged in “revue” form, and a story - a poor travesty of Cinderella and Faust - is woven round the dresses. But the dresses are enough in themselves, and the occasional song and dance merely interrupt one’s pleasure and interest in them.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/feb/27/catwalk-show-london-theatre-1923">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Fisherman fashion – making waves in menswear</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/jan/26/fisherman-fashion-menswear-workwear-trend</link>
      <description><p>Hipster fashion is sunk so designers have trawled the workwear trend and come up with a new look – think Aran jumpers, wide-legged trousers and rolled-up beanies. But what do real fishermen make of it?</p><p>‘They’re having a laugh, aren’t they?” Nigel Legge is a fisherman based in Cadgwith, Cornwall. <a href="http://www.lobsterpots.co.uk/">He has a sideline in lobster pots</a>, most recently seen in <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/poldark">Poldark</a>, which he makes and sells from his shed behind the harbour. But, weather allowing, he is on his boat, Razorbill, from around 5am until 3pm, catching mackerel, lobsters, that sort of thing. In his smock and jersey, he’s also the walking embodiment of the most stealth menswear trend around: fishermen. “The thing is, when you’re out at sea you don’t care what you look like. Which is just as well. It’s no place for fashion.”</p><p>In menswear, the time has come for hip young men to take stock. What is cool? What is hip? <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2014/jun/22/end-of-the-hipster-flat-caps-and-beards">And if you’re cool and hip, ie a hipster, what does this mean for your wardrobe?</a> Not long ago, there was a look. In its most basic form, it was best described as utilitarian workwear (flannel shirts, slim-fitting jeans, expensive leather boots). But in recent years, “hipster” has become nebulous as an adjective and derided as a social group. Vice declared <a href="http://www.vice.com/read/hw-here-lies-the-hipster-999">2015 the year the hipster died</a>; the word prompts shudders on the Guardian fashion desk. Naturally, that sentiment has ruined hipster fashion. It’s now impossible to wear a checked shirt without looking like a caricature.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/jan/26/fisherman-fashion-menswear-workwear-trend">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Grace Coddington: the woman who made fashion art</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/jan/23/grace-coddington-the-woman-who-made-fashion-art</link>
      <description><p>Over 30 years she created some of US Vogue’s most exciting and influential photo spreads, but now Grace Coddington has stepped aside. Is this a turning point for the industry?</p><p>A camel, a biplane and a monster truck convene in the Californian desert. A trio of dalmatians flank Naomi Campbell in a white convertible. Nine models lounge in haute couture in an enchanted forest. A handsome spaceman washes up in his capsule on a hazy beach.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2015/sep/26/grace-coddington-interview">Q&amp;A: Grace Coddington</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/jan/23/grace-coddington-the-woman-who-made-fashion-art">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <media:content width="140" url="https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/53403039f792643a0d80543170eb7deeeb5de560/5_135_1492_895/master/1492.jpg?w=140&q=55&auto=format&usm=12&fit=max&s=e36275cfe7dda6cb4a2b08ba2e8583c5">

    <item>
      <title>Bust it up: the pleasure and pain of bra shopping as an older woman</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/jan/21/bust-it-up-the-pleasure-and-pain-of-bra-shopping-as-an-older-woman</link>
      <description><p>Thanks to gravity, hormones and weight, buying underwear as an older woman could be exasperating – but experience can teach you how to shop like a pro</p><p>My bra history goes like this: young, flat-chested and embarrassed, I would guess my size and grab the first bra I could find in M&amp;S, rather than actually seeking advice or trying anything on. Older, saggier and less concerned about what other people think, I’m more inclined to loiter in underwear departments, demanding attention and feeding my expensive lingerie habit. I’m wondering if there is a correlation? As confidence and earnings go up, nipples head in the opposite direction.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/jan/21/bust-it-up-the-pleasure-and-pain-of-bra-shopping-as-an-older-woman">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>David Bowie’s style legacy: ‘He stole ideas from everywhere’</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/jan/11/david-bowie-style-icon-fashion-legacy-aladdin-sane</link>
      <description><p>From Aladdin Sane’s jumpsuit to the Thin White Duke’s suits, Bowie’s distinctive outfits have influenced designers from Jean Paul Gaultier to Hedi Slimane</p><p>In 2012, I visited the V&amp;A’s costume preservation department to see the preparations for the museum’s record-breaking <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2013/feb/16/david-bowie-guide-retrospective-show">David Bowie retrospective</a> the following year. A curator carefully unwrapped the tissue paper around one garment and laid it out for me to see. It was an item as familiar to me as the school uniform I wore for my first five years of secondary school, and indeed, a picture of Bowie wearing it has been on my bedroom wall for most of that time: <a href="http://www.vogue.co.uk/spy/celebrity-photos/2013/03/06/david-bowie-style-file---fashion-history-in-pictures/gallery/951078">a knitted jumpsuit in a bright zig-zag pattern</a>, with one leg cut off at the upper thigh and one arm cut away to reveal bare shoulder. It was, of course, a <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2012/aug/18/david-bowie-victoria-albert-museum-costumes">stage outfit</a> he wore during his Ziggy Stardust/Aladdin Sane tours, and the biggest surprise about it for me, close up, was that it was knitted, with quite thick wool in the most richly patterned parts.</p><p>I remarked that it must have been ridiculously hot to wear during a frenetic live show, and the curators laughed and said that sweat damage was one of the main problems they were working on with the stage clothes. (The original jumpsuit, for instance, had long since rotted away, and the one shown at the V&amp;A had actually been recreated by its designer, <a href="http://www.vam.ac.uk/content/articles/f/fashion-in-motion-kansai-yamamoto/">Kansai Yamamoto</a>, for an exhibition in New York a few years earlier.)</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/jan/11/david-bowie-style-icon-fashion-legacy-aladdin-sane">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>'Warhol’s ghost in a public toilet': an art critic reviews this season's fashion campaigns</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/jan/07/warhols-ghost-in-a-public-toilet-an-art-critics-review-of-this-seasons-fashion-campaigns</link>
      <description><p>The spring/summer 2016 shoots are out and, not for the first time, resemble artistic tableaux fit for the Tate. Art critic Jonathan Jones reviews six</p><p>Looking in a fashion magazine these days is like wandering through a very chic art gallery full of intensely radical artworks. It is only when you notice the £2,000 bag that lies casually across a model’s waxed leg that you realise these are ads. On the other hand, posh art galleries with their willowy squadrons of couture-clad staff are also easy to mistake for fashion magazines. Does the Gagosian now sell shoes? These spring and summer campaign images for leading fashion houses reveal that it’s all getting even artier. Provocative settings, abstract angles and minimalist bodies are everywhere. But how do the new looks being sold to us in 2016 really stack up as art? Are these ads Turner prize winners or Turnip prize nonsense? I put down my copy of John Ruskin’s Modern Painters to take a look at the latest convolutions in the art of style.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/jan/07/warhols-ghost-in-a-public-toilet-an-art-critics-review-of-this-seasons-fashion-campaigns">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Athevening: how to wear jogging bottoms to the pub</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/jan/08/athevening-how-to-wear-jogging-bottoms-to-the-pub</link>
      <description><p>Athleisure is the gift that keeps on giving. Now, fashion has decided you can wear it at night as well. But don’t bother looking for it in Sports Direct – here’s how to get the look</p><p>Fashion loves nothing more than a buzzword. Actually, scratch that, it loves a buzzword of a buzzword even more. See the latest example: athevening. </p><p>Most of us might resort to the confused <a href="http://emojipedia.org/confused-face/">emoji</a> when presented with such a word. But fashion insiders will recognise it as the brand-new incarnation of <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/jan/01/athleisure-beyonce-topshop-style-trend-gym-ready-gear">athleisure</a>, that hybrid of gym and non-gym clothes that allows you to look like you work out even if getting up from the sofa between episodes of Making a Murderer is a stretch. Beyoncé’s into it; so is Alexander Wang, and it’s handy to justify staying in your tracksuit top all day. Athevening is, arguably, even more good/lazy. It’s basically wearing sporty, slouchy clothes for a night out. <br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/jan/08/athevening-how-to-wear-jogging-bottoms-to-the-pub">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/dec/08/hessian-napkins-popcorn-tinsel-instagrammable-christmas</link>
      <description><p>’Tis the season to crop, filter and scroll. From carolling your way to perfect cheekbones to getting likes on your sprout tree, here’s how to have an Instagram-worthy Christmas <strong><br></strong></p><p>If style apologists have learned anything in 2015 it is that if it didn’t happen on Instagram, then it didn’t happen at all. You will have failed.       <title>What does ‘the natural look’ mean in the Kardashian age?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/dec/07/natural-kardashian-models-celebrities-bouncy-waves-full-makeup</link>
      <description><p>Now that models and celebrities like to refer to bouncy waves and full makeup as ‘natural’, where does that leave the rest of us?</p><p>Awesome news just in for the busy festive season. The “natural look” is in. Result! Run a brush through your hair and dab a bit of concealer on any obvious pimples, and off we go.</p><p>Oh ... wait. The “natural look”, <a href="https://intothegloss.com/2015/02/kim-kardashian-makeup/">according to Kim Kardashian</a>, for casual days when she’s doing her own makeup, involves “old school, heavy foundation” and “a matte bronzer ... I always contour my nose, and I love to contour my cheeks.” That messy bob Gigi Hadid had for the American Music Awards? Turns out it was a wig, <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/11/28/fashion/gigi-hadid-fake-bob-how-to.html">which her hairstylist casually noted took two hours to put in place</a>, after which there was some additional styling to be done. (He recommended an $18 volumising power that “makes you look like you just casually pushed your hair back”.)</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/dec/07/natural-kardashian-models-celebrities-bouncy-waves-full-makeup">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>No style icon but an image-maker: why Margaret Thatcher was the wrong fit for the V&A</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/nov/03/no-style-icon-but-an-image-maker-why-margaret-thatcher-was-the-wrong-fit-for-the-va</link>
      <description><p>The museum has rejected the former prime minister’s wardrobe on the grounds that it does not qualify as ‘fashionable dress’. It may have lacked refinement and subtlety, but her clothing was a masterclass in projecting power</p><p><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/jonathanjonesblog/2015/nov/03/margaret-thatcher-power-suits-worthy-v-and-a-clothes-museum-bowie">And the opposite view: why the V&amp;A were wrong</a></p><p>In a newspaper article in January 1975, Margaret Thatcher described private property as “one of the main bulwarks of individual freedom”. So it seems appropriate that her handbags, suits and necklaces will be sold for cold, hard cash to the highest bidder, rather than being saved for the nation.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2015/nov/03/va-rejects-offer-to-showcase-margaret-thatchers-clothing">V&amp;A rejects offer to showcase Margaret Thatcher's clothing</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/nov/03/no-style-icon-but-an-image-maker-why-margaret-thatcher-was-the-wrong-fit-for-the-va">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Do your clothes pass the feminist test?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/nov/04/do-your-clothes-pass-the-feminist-test</link>
      <description><p>It’s never been more fashionable to wear the word ‘feminist’ on your clothing, but Caroline Criado-Perez argues that it takes much more than a slogan for your outfit to support women</p><p>As any fool knows, you are what you wear. And there’s no fool like a feminist fool, which is why as I write this I’m wearing a full-on feminist outfit. By which I mean that everything from my pants to my necklace is emblazoned with the word “feminist”; that’s just how right on I am. After all, clothes emblazoned with the word “feminist” have never been more on-trend, available everywhere from Amazon to Etsy. In reality, it takes more than a Sans Serif proclamation for your T-shirt to pass the feminist test. Here’s what really counts:</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/nov/04/do-your-clothes-pass-the-feminist-test">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Eyebro: Justin Trudeau, Canada's new prime minister, gives good brow (and here's how)</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/oct/22/eyebro-justin-trudeau-canadas-new-prime-minister-gives-good-brow-and-heres-how</link>
      <description><p>Want the well-sculpted brows of Canada’s new liberal leader? Read on</p><p>In the runup to the election in Canada, it didn’t take long for the focus to fall on the semiotics of the candidates’ <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/10/22/fashion/justin-trudeau-takes-an-image-and-wins-with-it.html">grooming</a> habits and, in particular, that of Justin Trudeau, who is now the country’s newly appointed prime minister. Yes, he does great hair – and we can expect the “Trudeau” to enter the lexicon soon – but he also gives great brows. Which, for a man, is often a bit of a taboo topic of grooming conversation. For shame, though.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/oct/22/eyebro-justin-trudeau-canadas-new-prime-minister-gives-good-brow-and-heres-how">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Margot Tenenbaum: this season's hottest fashion muse is actually a school guidance counsellor</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/oct/27/margot-tenenbaum-fashion-muse-autumn-winter-season-school-guidance-counsellor</link>
      <description><p>This autumn/winter the fashion industry has been united in its devotion to one muse – the excessively eyelinered Wes Anderson character Margot Tenenbaum. But what’s all the adoration like for the real woman who shares her name?</p><p>My name is Margot Tenenbaum but I’m not the Margot you’ve been reading about in glossy magazines this autumn/winter – the “coolest muse of the season”, according to <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/oct/09/what-wore-margot-tenenbaum-glam-geek-chic-jess-cartner-morley">fashion critics</a> and <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/aug/24/fantastic-mr-wes-anderson-how-tenenbaum-chic-took-over-the-catwalks">Gucci</a>, as played by Gwyneth Paltrow in the 2001 Wes Anderson movie The Royal Tenenbaums.<br></p><p>I don’t wear fur coats or smudge kohl around my eyes. In fact, I don’t wear make up at all at the moment. I’m more of a casual jeans and cardigan kind of girl. I work at a school in New York, as a guidance counsellor, so it’s perfectly acceptable for me to wear jeans with a sweater and a pair of black boots to work; my style is relaxed and comfortable.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/oct/27/margot-tenenbaum-fashion-muse-autumn-winter-season-school-guidance-counsellor">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>So fresh and so clean: a brief history of fashion and hip-hop</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/oct/27/fresh-dressed-fashion-hip-hop-kanye-west-louis-vuitton</link>
      <description><p>The documentary Fresh Dressed showcases the threads and racial politics that run between the music genre and style – and explains how the classic looks of the 80s live on with Kanye West wearing Louis Vuitton</p><p>To get an idea of how entrenched the word “fresh” is to <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/hip-hop">hip-hop</a>, look to the <a href="http://www.urbandictionary.com/define.php?term=fresh">Urban Dictionary</a>. Across 14 pages, definitions include “Young. Fly. Flashy … fashion sense that people ain’t never seen before.” The general gist emerges: to be fresh is to be stylish, and style has always been key to hip-hop.</p><p>This connection is the subject of a new documentary, <a href="http://freshdressedmovie.com">Fresh Dressed</a>, directed by Sacha Jenkins and out this week. Starting with Run DMC – the group’s fat laces, <a href="http://www.cazal-eyewear.com/index.php?lang=en">Cazal glasses</a>, gold chains and Kangol hats – and running up to current fashion killas <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/kanyewest">Kanye West</a> and <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/asap-rocky">A$AP Rocky</a>, it’s a crash course in an alliance of style, culture and music. Talking heads range from Kanye himself, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2004/apr/15/popandrock">Damon Dash</a>, Givenchy creative director <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2014/dec/09/julia-roberts-riccardo-tisci-givenchy-pretty-woman">Riccardo Tisci</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andr%C3%A9_Leon_Talley">American Vogue’s André Leon Talley</a>. Highlights include the story of <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2pac">Tupac Shakur</a> modelling for free as a gesture of support for black designer <a href="http://www.karlkani.com/">Karl Kani</a>, and that of <a href="http://www.dazeddigital.com/fashion/article/21390/1/dapper-dan-natural-born-hustler">Dapper Dan</a>, the cult designer who kitted out those on the 80s scene with tracksuits made from counterfeit <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/gucci">Gucci-</a> and <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/louis-vuitton">Louis Vuitton</a>-monogrammed fabric before these brands began to take legal action. Nas calls him “<a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/tom-ford">Tom Ford</a> before Tom Ford”.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/oct/27/fresh-dressed-fashion-hip-hop-kanye-west-louis-vuitton">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Madchester, grunge chic and Kate Moss: how the 90s shaped our world</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/sep/08/this-is-england-90-fashion-style-comeback</link>
      <description><p>The decade when youth culture exploded in defiant hypercolour lives on – and not just in Channel 4’s This is England ’90. Former editor of the Face Sheryl Garratt explains how the E generation’s style excesses are making a comeback</p><p>Early on in the <a href="http://www.channel4.com/programmes/this-is-england-90">new series of This is England</a>, we see Lol working as a school dinner lady and dealing with her old friend Gadget, who has arrived to cadge a free lunch. He is dressed in a bucket hat and an oversized hoodie in colours so bright you want to turn down the contrast on your screen. You immediately know that we’re in 1990, the era of “Madchester” T-shirts, bowl cuts and centre partings, and ridiculously flared Joe Bloggs jeans.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/news/2015/sep/08/nineties-90s-in-hedonism-out-with-believing-something">What the 90s meant: in with hedonism, out with believing in something</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/sep/08/this-is-england-90-fashion-style-comeback">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Chic or tech geek? The Apple Watch Hermes</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/sep/10/chic-or-not-chic-the-apple-watch-hermes</link>
      <description><p>The Guardian’s fashion editor gives her view of Apple’s most luxury-focused wearable yet</p><p>Apple HQ have announced the launch of an iPad with a pencil, and an iPhone that takes “emergency selfies” [sic] – but let’s cut to the chase, because the new Apple Watch Hermes, which goes on sale 5 October, is clearly the most interesting news from Cupertino. In the story of fashion-tech partnerships, that of Apple with Hermes, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/shortcuts/2014/oct/15/are-hermes-birkin-bags-putting-the-stink-in-stinking-rich">home of the Birkin bag</a>, is the most glamorous couple to date.</p><p>The <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/apr/28/apple-watch-jess-cartner-morley-phone">original Apple Watch is a good-looking watch</a>, but the Hermes Cape Cod is more elegant, more refined. This watch is Hermes on the outside, Apple on the inside. Look at the slightly deco font of the numerals, the lozenge-shaped face, stirrup-style connection to the leather strap, the second hand in Hermes’ signature orange. The price for the double-strap version (which is The One) is $1,250 (£808), which is considerably less than you’d pay for a <a href="http://uk.hermes.com/watches/cape-cod.html">non-Apple Watch original Hermes Cape Cod</a>. A bargain? Well, bear in mind that internally this is an Apple product, and unlike luxury watches, Apple products do not last for decades.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/sep/10/chic-or-not-chic-the-apple-watch-hermes">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>How Elizabeth I made red hair fashionable – in 1558</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/fashion-blog/2015/sep/08/how-elizabeth-i-made-red-hair-fashionable-in-1558</link>
      <description><p>Long before the pre-Raphaelites, the so-called Virgin Queen made red hair – which had been much-maligned – so fashionable that her courtiers started dying their beards to match. Here’s how she did it</p><p>There’s a painting in the National Portrait Gallery that has long been a source of fashion inspiration for me; it dates from about 1575, and is a peerless image of redheaded chic. Elizabeth I wears a gown of white and gold satin with dashing scarlet frogging across the breast, like a hussar, and she holds a particularly wonderful feather fan – whites and sulphurous yellows, dark iridescent greens, oranges and russet reds. That ghostly face is turned three-quarters of the way toward us; her expression reserved; her lips compressed. The line of that nose – “rising somewhat in the midst”, as Sir John Hayward described it – is clearly shown. My nose does the same. My hair is also red. Elizabeth I has been my pin-up girl since I was tiny. But it was only when I began researching my book <em><a href="http://bookshop.theguardian.com/catalog/product/view/id/328798/">Red: A Natural History of the Redhead</a></em> that I came to appreciate how revolutionary Elizabeth’s image-making truly was. </p><p>Elizabeth’s red hair was no accident. For most of her life, Elizabeth wore wigs, so she might have chosen hair of any colour she liked, but she chose red; she was so committed to the shade that she is even supposed to have dyed the tails of her horses to match. (Who says redheads don’t have a sense of humour?) </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/fashion-blog/2015/sep/08/how-elizabeth-i-made-red-hair-fashionable-in-1558">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>The 20 autumn fashion trends you need to know about</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/sep/01/20-autumn-fashion-trends-need-to-know</link>
      <description><p>Where can you get a decent maxi coat? What is school-bully hair and should you be scared? And which decade are you supposed to be chanelling? Here is our guide to the clothes that will fill the shops this season – and what you will actually be wearing</p><p>If you’ve seen any of the following in Zara or Topshop – shaggy faux-fur coats, pussybow blouses or floral dresses that look like 1970s upholstery – then you’ve already spotted the beginnings of the Guccification of the high street. This is all thanks to the brand’s new creative director, Alessandro Michele, who has <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/jun/23/milan-fashion-week-gucci-menswear-show-michele">transformed Gucci from a purveyor of bling-tastic yacht chic to a haven for glamorous geeks</a>, and has won the hearts of the fashion industry in the process. High-street homages are everywhere; spectacles and a bobble hat are the finishing touches.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/sep/01/20-autumn-fashion-trends-need-to-know">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Fashion has to do much more if it is serious about catwalk diversity</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/aug/29/fashion-industry-diversity-models-disabilities-jillian-mercado-jamie-brewer</link>
      <description><p>Models with disabilities – Jillian Mercado, Jamie Brewer – have made the headlines, but the handful of examples is just a drop in the ocean</p><p>Reading certain sections of the media over the past few weeks you might have thought that we were living in a golden age of diversity in fashion. Modelling – so the narrative goes – is finally opening its doors to people who reflect the eclectic beauty of the world’s population, with models with disabilities among those being welcomed to the fold.</p><p>This month <a href="http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/model-muscular-dystrophy-img_55d36257e4b07addcb442973">Jillian Mercado</a>, who has muscular dystrophy, was signed to IMG Models, the same agency as Gisele Bündchen. The American fashion blogger and editor has also featured in a Diesel campaign and has been photographed by the high priestess of fashion, Carine Roitfeld. Also this month, Madeline Stuart, an 18-year-old Australian who has Down’s syndrome, was announced as the face of cosmetics brand GlossiGirl and cast to walk at New York fashion week in September.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/aug/29/fashion-industry-diversity-models-disabilities-jillian-mercado-jamie-brewer">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Fabio: confessions of the original male supermodel</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/jul/15/fabio-confessions-original-male-supermodel</link>
      <description><p>Before Zoolander, David Gandy and <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/jul/11/up-all-night-to-get-lucky-blue-smith">Insta-fame</a>, there was only one male model worth knowing: Fabio Lanzoni, a man with flowing blond locks and a jaw as square as a packet of ham. Now 56, he talks about setting a new industry standard and shares his life lessons</p><p><strong>My career started when I was barely 14 years old</strong><strong>.</strong> I was in Milan, at the gym, and one of the two biggest photographers in Europe, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2005/sep/18/gayrights.italy">Oliviero Toscani</a>, came up to me and said, ‘You should model.’ I wasn’t in the industry, so I had no idea who he was. I remember giving him my father’s phone number. He called my father, hired me for a big campaign and things took off from there.</p><p><strong>I came to New York City at 19 years old</strong><strong>,</strong> walked into the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/jul/10/modelling-agent-eileen-ford-dies-92">Ford modelling agency</a> without an appointment and walked out with a contract. The next day, in the gym, I got a call and was asked to meet with Barry McKinley, then the biggest photographer in the world. He hired me for the biggest campaign in America – the launch of the Gap. At that time, if you were one of the top male models in the world, you could earn $120,000 a year. My first job, straight away, was close to $150,000. So I set new standards.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/jul/15/fabio-confessions-original-male-supermodel">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>What John Waters taught me about eyeliner</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/aug/31/what-john-waters-taught-me-about-eyeliner</link>
      <description><p>This September and October, the BFI will celebrate 50 years of John Waters’ work. Longtime fan Eva Wiseman explains how performers like Divine, the director’s muse, made make-up dangerous and provocative</p><p>Divine shaved back her hairline in order to have more room for make-up. If that’s not a handbook for living, then Christ, I don’t know what is.</p><p>I read about Pink Flamingos before I saw it – even in the 1990s, a film where the star literally eats shit was difficult to track down. I’d been introduced to John Waters’ films through a video of Hairspray, one of his first “mainstream” successes, a film about a fat white girl who defeats racism by dancing at it, a film that inspired my sister, four at the time, to ask my grandma if she wanted to “get naked and smoke”. In Hairspray, and Pink Flamingos before it, I found more than just excitement and politics and a right laugh – I found my glamour.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/aug/31/what-john-waters-taught-me-about-eyeliner">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Star Wars: why C-3PO is this season's fashion hit</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/jul/26/star-wars-why-c-3po-is-this-seasons-fashion-hit</link>
      <description><p>The films’ glossiest robot has become a cover model for both Love and GQ magazines, but he’s not the movies’ only style inspiration</p><p><strong>C-3PO</strong> is on the cover of the latest issue of style magazine Love, and, like all the best male models, he is deploying his signature look: wide eyes, square jaw and cheekbones as contoured as a Kardashian. Though the image was styled by the magazine’s editor Katie Grand – a Jedi master of the fashion industry – there is no need for clothes. Instead, this is a celebration of the protocol droid’s innate high-shine style. The only accessory – a dog the exact shade of this season’s Gucci handbag – is the stylist’s own.</p><p>Star Wars’ glossiest robot is having a bit of a moment in fashion right now. He’s <a href="http://www.gq.com/gallery/amy-schumer-photos-star-wars-trainwreck">also on the cover of US GQ</a>, working those preternatural angles with Amy Schumer. The comedian is resplendent in blond plaits and a Princess Leia bikini and assiduously sucks C-3PO’s index finger. Inside the magazine, the mood gets even more Terry Richardson: there’s a three-in-a-bed scene with R2D2 and a lightsaber blow job (“<a href="http://edition.cnn.com/2015/07/19/entertainment/amy-schumer-star-wars-gq-disney/">Lucasfilm &amp; Disney did not approve, participate or condone this inappropriate use of our characters</a>,” the studio tweeted afterwards).</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/jul/26/star-wars-why-c-3po-is-this-seasons-fashion-hit">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Kylie Jenner’s cornrows and the racial politics of hair</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/shortcuts/2015/jul/13/kylie-jenner-cornrows-racial-politics-hair</link>
      <description><p>When Kim Kardashian’s younger sister posted a picture of a new hairstyle, she had little idea of the cultural minefield she was entering</p><p>The Kardashian Klan are used to hairstyles that break the internet – <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/mar/05/kim-kardashian-blond-hair-paris-fashion-week-good-look">Kim’s platinum blonde dye job threatened to overshadow the whole of Paris fashion week</a> in March. So, when Kylie Jenner, Kim’s younger sister, posted an <a href="https://instagram.com/p/5AWcLYHGty/?taken-by=kyliejenner">Instagram selfie</a> on Sunday featuring a new hairstyle, a noisy reaction was to be expected.</p><p>But Jenner might not have bargained for accusations of cultural appropriation. These came from 17-year-old Hunger Games actor <a href="http://www.imdb.com/name/nm3964350/">Amandla Stenberg</a>, who <a href="http://www.justjared.com/2015/07/12/kylie-jenner-gets-called-out-on-instagram-by-amandla-stenberg/">posted a comment</a> that read: “When u appropriate black features and culture but fail to use ur position of power to help black Americans by directing attention towards ur wigs instead of police brutality or racism #whitegirlsdoitbetter”. By Jenner’s next selfie, the braids were gone.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/shortcuts/2015/jul/13/kylie-jenner-cornrows-racial-politics-hair">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Lucky Blue Smith: the Mormon model with a million fans</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/jul/11/up-all-night-to-get-lucky-blue-smith</link>
      <description><p>The menswear shows in June saw teenage girls camped outside. The reason? Meet Lucky Blue Smith, a 17-year-old Mormon model who has 1.2m Instagram fans and counting</p><p>From bizarrely dressed bloggers to Botoxed editors, there’s no place for people-watching quite like the entrance to a fashion show. But the models who walk in the shows are usually pretty anonymous: they slink from one job to the next with their backpacks on, unnoticed.</p><p>At last month’s menswear shows, something changed. Outside <a href="http://uk.versace.com/">Versace</a> in Milan, 50 girls in denim cut-offs lined the narrow streets. At <a href="http://www.bottegaveneta.com/gb?tp=62206&amp;gclid=CO7z0t3xvsYCFaPnwgodA6gKfQ">Bottega Veneta</a>, a cluster of teens stood by the entrance, craning their necks. At <a href="https://www.etro.com/en_uk/">Etro</a>, the excitement peaked as more than 200 teenagers colonised the road, brandishing iPhones and shouting: “Lucky!”</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/jul/11/up-all-night-to-get-lucky-blue-smith">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>From Lewis Hamilton to Marcel Marceau: celebrities falling foul of the dress code</title>

    <item>
      <title>Madame Carven obituary</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/jun/14/madame-carven</link>
      <description>Designer who breathed new life into postwar fashion and created the perfume Ma Griffe<p>At the end of the second world war there was a famine of fabric across Europe: almost no raw fibres were imported, almost none produced, mills and factories were in disrepair or ruins. Only a few major couturiers in Paris had small caches of prewar textiles, or strong connections with government sources and suppliers with some samples, to attempt a postwar collection.</p><p>Marie-Louise Carven, without those contacts, had to scrabble for every scrap for the debut of her fashion house in July 1945. (“Young women,” she remembered, “had nothing to wear and even less to eat.”) The star of the show – so much Carven’s favourite that she called it “<em>ma griffe</em>”, my signature – was a generous-skirted summer dress, created from a roll of cotton, striped mint-green and white, found in the attic of a chateau, and probably originally purchased before the first world war for the summer uniforms of housemaids. It was, like its designer, fresh and casual, a statement of intent about the way that fashion should go – and spring-like Carven green was the colour of late 1940s French fashion, just as Lanvin blue had been in the 20s or Schiaparelli pink in the late 30s.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/jun/14/madame-carven">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Rave foam, sci-fi sportswear and spanners as jewellery: the key trends from London Collections: Men, SS16</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/jun/16/moobs-sci-fi-sportswear-spanners-jewellery-london-collections-men-ss16-northern-soul-tinie-tempah</link>
      <description><p>The London men’s shows were all about looking good on the dancefloor – think mashed ravers, 90s slackers or northern soul boys. Plus, Tinie Tempah on how to build the perfect catwalk soundtrack</p><p>Fashion has had enough of box sets, supper clubs and <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/shortcuts/2015/mar/25/39-signs-kinfolk-cult">Kinfolk interiors</a>. Instead, it’s rediscovered staying out way past bedtime. At Christopher Shannon, this showed itself in the hair as remnants of a <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/jun/13/mens-fashion-rise-of-the-party-face-stylewatch">foam party</a>, and as a sweaty glow at Lou Dalton. Fashion East newcomer Charles Jeffrey turned his afternoon presentation – named Loverboy, after the club night he runs – into a daytime rave. Looking a little bit worse for wear has never been so stylish.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/jun/16/moobs-sci-fi-sportswear-spanners-jewellery-london-collections-men-ss16-northern-soul-tinie-tempah">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/fashion-blog/2015/jun/02/marilyn-monroe-what-to-wear-bfi-misfits</link>
      <description><p>The BFI is celebrating the screen siren with a month-long season, while The Misfits is being reissued on 12 June. It’s the perfect excuse to take some style inspiration from the the archetypal Hollywood star</p><p>A <a href="https://whatson.bfi.org.uk/Online/default.asp?BOparam::WScontent::loadArticle::permalink=marilynmonroe">season of Marilyn Monroe films at London’s BFI</a> is a cinematic treat and the perfect excuse to dress up in homage to a proper screen siren. Throw in the reissue of 1961’s The Misfits – released nationwide on 12 June – and adding a bit of Marilyn to your look is even more relevant this month. Here are six things to wear when watching the star’s back catalogue. Blond curls and smouldering expression are optional.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/fashion-blog/2015/jun/02/marilyn-monroe-what-to-wear-bfi-misfits">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Fashion’s obsession with running</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/apr/21/fashion-obsession-running-sports-shoes-editors-marathon</link>
      <description><p>With sports shoes on the front row and editors training for marathons, the fashion industry has fallen for running in a big way. So how do you look chic on the starting line?</p><p>Aside from the odd punchline (see: <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=B6nFhcI4tgI">the “yogging” scene in Anchorman</a>) you don’t hear much about jogging these days. “To jog” sounds like something Madge Bishop might do on a sunny day in Ramsay Street. Instead, in recent years, a far sleeker verb – “to run” – has taken over, conjuring up images of picturesque forest pathways and blurs of black lycra.</p><p>It is this athletic vision that the fashion industry is currently obsessed with. Magazines including <a href="http://www.elleuk.com/more/running-club">Elle</a>, <a href="http://thegentlewoman.co.uk/#/socialities">the Gentlewoman</a> and Grazia have all featured reader runners’ clubs; talk of specialist trainer brands has become an integral part of front row chatter (as it happens, Victoria Beckham thinks Asics are the best). A fair few fashion people are taking part in the London Marathon this weekend, including Hugo Boss PR manager Tamara Klien, whose workout buddies include fellow fashion PR <a href="https://instagram.com/runlikeelle/">Elle Hankinson</a>, an ultra marathon runner.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/apr/21/fashion-obsession-running-sports-shoes-editors-marathon">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Sunglasses and scruffy shoes: the style mistakes that can cost you a job</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/apr/24/sunglasses-and-scruffy-shoes-the-style-mistakes-that-can-cost-you-a-job</link>
      <description><p>From distracting blouses to jangling jewellery, nine bosses and style specialists reveal the fashion details that should never be seen in interviews</p><p>A report released last week claimed that job interview outfits can seriously boost a candidate’s chances of success (in the study, the applicant <a href="http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0148296314004093">who wore a Louis Vuitton logo on their top was deemed most employable</a>). Here, nine people who hire and fire in fashion – and know their sartorial semantics – reveal their interview bugbears:</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/apr/24/sunglasses-and-scruffy-shoes-the-style-mistakes-that-can-cost-you-a-job">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/fashion-industry">Fashion industry</category>

      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/money/money">Money</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/money/work-and-careers">Work & careers</category>

      <description><p>Elio Fiorucci – who died on Monday – championed glamour with a wink throughout the 70s and 80s.     <item>
      <title>The history of flares - in pictures</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/gallery/2015/jan/24/the-history-of-flares-in-pictures</link>
      <description><p>For the past few years, fashion designers have been telling us flared trousers are coming back. We’ll see. They’ve been around a long time, but only one decade really embraced them: the 1970s. Rich and poor, teeny boppers and football hooligans all wore their flares with pride. Here we look back at those halcyon, bell-bottomed days of yore</p><ul><li><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/jan/24/flares-rescued-from-dustbin-of-fashion-history-paris-milan">They’re back! Top designers rescue flares from dustbin of fashion history</a></li></ul> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/gallery/2015/jan/24/the-history-of-flares-in-pictures">Continue reading...</a></description>
